DOC.HEAD: Model of Honesty Wraps Up Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf to CORRECT that Magruder is Presbyterian, sted Baptist minister.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CO3
DOC.TEXT: A man who returned more than $50,000 after it fell from an armored car onto a busy highway said Friday his good deed has paid dividends. ``A lot of good tings have happened to me in the past couple years. ... But I'm the same person I always was,'' said Melvin Kiser. ``I think people like to look at the positive and expand on that, but I'm just average.'' Kiser was among honorees at a luncheon to mark the end of a 14-month campaign by the city's Commission on Ethics and Values to make honesty a citywide policy. Kiser gained national attention after he returned money that spilled on Interstate 71 near downtown Columbus in October 1987. He even portrayed himself in a television advertisement for Miller beer. He said he returned the money out of his admiration for a famous good guy _ movie star John Wayne. ``I was always a fan of John Wayne and still am,'' said Kiser, an Ohio Bell employee. Kiser's honesty was rewarded with more than fame. The armored car company gave him more than $5,000, and then there's pay for the Miller ad. Miller spokeswoman Beverly Jurkowski said Kiser didn't ask to be paid, but had to be given a standard union rate for actors. She said he made between $5,000 and $10,000, but was unable to give the exact amount. ``He was a superb example of the Miller High Life campaign saluting people who do the right thing or make a decision in a difficult situation,'' Ms. Jurkowski said of Kiser. In the commercial, Kiser is seen shooting pool in a bar with friends while telling them about the armored car incident. A man walks past him, and a $20 bill falls to Kiser's feet. Kiser picks up the bill and asks, ``Why me?'' The city's Commission on Ethics and Values was formed after the rear door of Metropolitan Armored Car Inc. truck swung open, dumping an estimated $1 million on a downtown freeway. Police estimate some 200 people converged on the highway, scooping up cash, while the truck continued north. Several people returned money they found, but police said Kiser's return of more than $50,000 represented the largest single amount. Police refused to say exactly how much money was lost or returned. The city's ``Take an Honest Look'' campaign was headed by Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former Watergate conspirator who is now a Presbyterian minister in suburban Marble Cliff. Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young, a candidate for governor of Georgia, was the featured speaker at Friday's luncheon. At a news conference, Young said the honesty campaign was ``reaffirming and reminding us of those values that have really made this a great nation.'' Also honored at the luncheon were Sandy Pittman, of Columbus a bank employee who turned in a bag of unused state lottery tickets last July, and six local students whose essays on honesty were judged best in a citywide competition.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Weighs Outlawing ``Bandogs''
DOC.TEXT: The government says it is ready to consider banning a dangerous breed of dog called ``bandog'' _ a cross between a pit bull terrier and a bigger breed, such as a rottweiler. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals described the 130-pound dogs as ``Darwinian nightmares'' capable of killing any human being in a one-to-one fight. Asked about a possible ban, Home Secretary David Waddington said Friday: ``I'm prepared to look at anything. I think it's a very, very serious situation.'' He said Britain strengthened legislation governing dangerous breeds last summer so courts now can order dangerous animals destroyed. ``But certainly one has got to look to see if the law is tough enough to give sufficient protection to the public against people who take around streets of the land these terribly fierce dogs,'' he said. He said there was a problem in naming certain breeds of dog in legislation because other breeds could then be developed.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Revived After Being Banned for 45 Years
DOC.TEXT: Forty-five years after Communist authorities banned it, the magazine of the Democratic Party of Yugoslavia reappeared on Belgrade newsstands. The front-page editorial in Friday's editions of Demokratija declared: ``Democracy means discussion _ the truth has many different faces and cannot belong to one man or one party alone.'' A Democratic official, Djurdje Ninkovic, said ``no consent for the publication ... was demanded or obtained from the authorities.'' He said the first issue had been financed by donations gathered at a recent party convention. About 22,000 copies were printed, he said. The fortnightly was reborn in a new political climate that has swept Eastern Europe. Yugoslavia's ruling Communists have adopted economic reforms and are debating political changes as well. Demokratija was the sole opposition publication in Yugoslavia after the Communist takeover in 1945. But it was able to print only seven issues because the government-controlled trade union refused to publish ``capitalist lies.'' It was banned after Communist activists organized attacks on distributors and burned copies.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Appeals to Save Indonesians From Execution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One name cq for Sukatno, Marsudi, Suharto and Sukarno
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International appealed to Indonesia not to execute six political prisoners who have been jailed more than 20 years for participation in a 1965 coup attempt. In a letter to President Suharto made public Friday, the human rights group's secretary-general, Ian Martin, said Amnesty International had received reports that appeals for clemency had been rejected. He said his London-based organization had heard the Suharto government was to execute Ruslan Widjayasastra, Sukatno, Iskandar Subekti, Asep Suryaman, I Bungkus and Marsudi on Sunday. Their executions would bring to 32 the number of prisoners slain since 1985, compared with four in the preceding 10 years, he said. Four other prisoners accused of involvement in the 1965 coup attempt were executed Feb. 13 after more than 24 years in jail. Martin said Amnesty International was concerned ``that it is political prisoners who have been the principal victims of these judicial killings.'' In the letter released to the news media, Martin said the six elderly prisoners had been convicted of membership in the Communist Party of Indonesia and of involvement in the failed coup in 1965. The attempt to depose President Sukarno began Sept. 30, 1965. It was crushed within 48 hours by troops led by Suharto, then a major-general. In the crackdown that followed, up to 500,000 people were killed. More than half a million people were detained before calm was restored in March 1966 and Suharto took power from Sukarno.

DOC.HEAD: Directors Guild Agrees on New Pact With NBC and ABC
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK (AP) The Directors Guild of America has reached tentative agreement with ABC and NBC on a three-year contract covering about 275 guild members at the networks, according to union and network officials. The new contract, to succeed one that expires on June 30, still must be approved by the guild's national board, and then submitted to guild membership for ratification. In addition to staff members and free-lance employees at ABC and NBC, the agreement covers guild members at facilities the networks own here and in Washington, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco. The proposed pact would boost salaries by 5 percent this July, with another 5 per cent increase beginning on Jan. 1, 1992, according to a statement issued Friday by the guild and the two networks. The guild still is negotiating a new contract with CBS, said Chuck Warn, a guild spokesman in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: The ever-candid material girl Madonna says she is sometimes wary about the oft-coupled Warren Beatty but has flights of fancy that her relationship with him could be an enduring one. ``Sometimes I'm cynical and pragmatic and think it will last as long as it lasts,'' Madonna says in the April issue of Vanity Fair. ``Then I have moments when I'm really romantic and I think, `We're just perfect together.''' The singer and actress said her moments of doubt are short-lived. ``He's been with the world's most beautiful, most glamorous, talented women,'' she said. ``I mean, how can I ever be as fabulous as Brigitte Bardot when she was 25. Or Natalie Wood. Or any of those people. ``Then there is the other side of me that says I'm better than all of them.''

Entertainer Yves Montand and Chinese student leader Wu'er Kaixi christened a 1,200-ton boat that will transmit pro-democracy radio broadcasts into China from international waters. The 262-foot boat, formerly a British oceanographic vessel, was renamed Goddess of Democracy after the statue erected by Chinese students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square last year before their protest movement was crushed. The boat christened Friday is to set sail next week from La Rochelle, a port in the center of France's Atlantic Coast, and is expected to begin its broadcasts by the end of April. It is equipped with two radio studios and a television studio. The project is sponsored by the French magazine Actuel, with assistance from news publications in several other countries. The budget for the operation is $1.4 million. Chinese authorities have demanded that the French government halt what they described as a ``subversive'' operation.

Fans of Connie Chung may have trouble keeping their television dates straight with the CBS correspondent this spring. CBS News said Friday it will air two special Monday editions of ``Saturday Night With Connie Chung'' in May. The Monday programs, a spokeswoman said, will be called ``A Special Edition of Saturday Night With Connie Chung.''

Blues singer Bobby Rush was ordered to pay a $20,000 fine after pleading guilty to possessing cocaine. Rush, 52, who lives in Jackson and whose real name is Emmett Ellis Jr., entered the plea Thursday before Warren County Circuit Court Judge Isadore Patrick. Patrick gave Rush a three-year suspended sentence and two years supervised probation. Rush was arrested after a Vicksburg policeman found a kilogram of cocaine when he stopped to help the singer, who was stranded when his van broke down. Some of Rush's more popular songs are ``Sue'' and ``Gotta Have Money.''

Comedian Pat Paulsen, a perennial presidential candidate, thinks he will have a fighting chance in 1992 if he makes his last run as a Democrat. ``They don't know which way is up,'' the 62-year-old Paulsen said. ``There will be lots of comedians in the race.'' His slogan is ``Pat Who? in '92.'' Paulsen unveiled his plans at a beach resort Thursday.

Actress Jennifer O'Neill says she is giving up on matrimony after six failed marriages. ``The only thing I can say is I don't give up. I think I have now, though,'' the 42-year-old actress is quoted as saying in a taping of ``The Joan Rivers Show'' to be broadcast Tuesday. O'Neill, who has been in 27 films and hit stardom with ``The Summer of '42,'' first married at age 17. She has three children, ranging from age 2 to 22, and is currently separated from her sixth husband, Richard Allen. ``I know Elizabeth Taylor said this, but I'll have to repeat it: `I didn't date them, I married them,''' she said. ``When I say that, I feel absolutely ridiculous because my parents have been married 44 years and they still bossa nova around at lunch,'' the actress said.

Mayor Tom Bradley's daughter is serving a 60-day jail term for drunken driving in quarters separate from other inmates at the Sybil Brand Institute for Women. Phyllis Bradley, 44, surrendered on Thursday, a day before she was due to begin her term, to avoid publicity, said sheriff's Lt. Charles Jackson. ``She is in separate housing because of the notoriety she would have attracted had she been identified,'' Jackson said. ``However, she is receiving no special privileges.'' A call made to the mayor's office for comment was not immediately returned. Ms. Bradley, who has a history of drug abuse problems, was sentenced in February by Municipal Court Commissioner Mitchell Green. Green also ordered her to spend 30 days picking up trash along freeways and to pay a $1,000 fine. She was arrested in December after making an illegal U-turn. Her blood alcohol level was found to be .19 percent, over the legal limit at the time of .10 percent. The limit now is .08 percent. Ms. Bradley was placed on five years probation and was instructed to spend one year in a rehabilitation program, while using her car only to drive to work and to attend the program.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer Transplant Patient Discharged From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, was discharged from the hospital 17 days after undergoing a second liver transplant. The 12-year-old Texas girl will remain in the city for about two weeks for outpatient treatment at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon said Friday. Stormie received her second liver transplant in a 10-hour operation Feb. 20. She had undergone a heart-and-liver transplant in 1984. The heart has not caused any problems, but she needed a new liver because the first was damaged by hepatitis. Ms. McMahon said surgeons are pleased with her progress. The sixth-grader told reporters Thursday she hoped to return home to the Fort Worth suburb of White Settlement within a month.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped Intelligence Agents Freed in Kashmir
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with agents released; CORRECTS to five sted four kidnapped; pickup graf 15 pvs `In neighboring...'
DOC.TEXT: Five police intelligence officers were released early Saturday after Kashmiri Moslem separatists pulled them from a jeep at gunpoint the day before, a state governor said. On Friday, a Cabinet minister, acknowledging the Moslem rebellion had reached an ``unprecedented point,'' said the government was opening negotiations with the separatists. The governor said the five men were released unharmed after government loudspeakers blared all-night warnings that ``strong action'' would be taken if the kidnapped officers were not freed. ``Our approach of firmness in dealing with the terrorists worked,'' said Gov. Jagmohan of Jammu-Kashmir state. He said the five men, members of the Jammu-Kashmir state police intelligence branch, re-appeared before sunrise in the same area they were abducted Friday night. No claims of responsibility or demands were made on behalf of the abductors. The five men had been in a jeep patrolling a congested residential area in the heart of Srinagar, core of the movement demanding mostly Moslem Kashmir's independence from predominantly Hindu India. A curfew was in effect, but a crowd surrounded the intelligence officers' jeep, Jagmohan said. He said three young men took the officers from the jeep at gunpoint and set fire to the vehicle. Jagmohan had said Friday that only four agents were missing. The agency United News of India had said the missing agents working in security units for senior government officials. Earlier Friday, Railway Minister George Fernandes told reporters the government was opening talks with the separatists. ``It is too early to say what shape the dialogue will take, but at least the process has begun,'' he said. Fernandes, selected by the government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh to initiate the talks, said he was meeting the ``right people'' through intermediaries. But, he said, ``we have a tough job here.'' Islamic militants have been fighting for secession of Jammu-Kashmir state from India for the last four decades. The latest round of violence began Jan. 20 after a government crackdown on the militants. At least 173 people have been killed and hundreds injured since then. A high-level political delegation, comprising leaders of all major parties, visited Srinagar on Thursday to assess the situation. The team returned to New Delhi on Friday but Fernandes, who was part of the delegation, stayed back, apparently to initiate the dialogue. Srinagar is summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state. ``The mood of the people is very obvious. The campaign for secession has reached an unprecedented point,'' he said Friday. It was not known who the government would negotiate with. The militants said earlier they will not negotiate their demand for independence. In neighboring Pakistan-held Kashmir, about 500 demonstrators demanded self-determination for their brethren in India during a protest march Friday to a Pakistani military checkpoint along the border. Protesters shouted ``Death to V.P. Singh!'' and ``Indian dogs, go home!'' but no violence was reported. Kashmir, once a fabled tourist area, is in far northern India, about 400 miles north of New Delhi. It has been under dispute between India and Pakistan since 1948, when the Hindu ruler of the former princely state decided to merge with India. Since then, Moslem-dominated Pakistan and India have twice gone to war over the region. The U.S. State Department on Friday warned Americans to avoid Indian Airlines flights to Srinagar because of the possibility of terrorist attacks. It said in a statement the warning was prompted by posters that appeared in the Srinagar area telling people not to take the airline's flights to the city.

DOC.HEAD: Terror Commission Looks at Impact of Moscow Embassy Notice
DOC.TEXT: A presidential commission is trying to find out how many people changed travel plans when the U.S. Embassy in Moscow disseminated a terrorism warning before the 1988 bombing of Pan American Flight 103. Two embassy witnesses testified under oath Friday that a notice from the Federal Aviation Administration of bomb threats against Pan Am flights en route to the United States was posted in several places around the diplomatic compound and outside and also was sent to Soviet officials. The State Department previously acknowledged only that the notice was improperly posted in the embassy a week before Flight 103 blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people on Dec. 21, 1988. Officials said the posting violated a policy against notifying government personnel when others are not told of a threat. The embassy notice said employees were left to their own discretion on whether to change travel plans, but it noted they still were required to fly on an American airline. Pan Am was the only U.S. carrier serving Moscow, although other airlines could be used from Europe to the United States. Raymond F. Smith, who was acting deputy chief of mission in Moscow at the time, told the Presidential Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism that he felt a ``moral obligation to let people know'' about the threat against Pan Am flights between Frankfurt, West Germany, and the United States. ``I said to myself, would I want my own family to take the information into account, and the answer was yes,'' Smith said, justifying the decision to inform all embassy personnel and other people who might fly of the threat. Smith said he knew of no other embassy that disseminated the notice publicly. State Department officials have said the threat turned out to be a hoax originating in Helsinki, Finland. Embassy officials decided in a top-level staff meeting to give the notice the widest distribution possible, Smith and embassy security officer Mark A. Sanna testified. At Friday's hearing, the commission disclosed a telex message from Pan Am's Moscow office saying that 80 percent of the airline's Moscow passengers were changing their bookings as a result of the posted threat. But Jennifer S. Young, the airline's former Moscow manager who sent the telex, testified that she had no direct knowledge of any cancellations and used the 80 percent figure to give her telex some impact because she needed advice on what to tell travelers. Ms. Young said a part-time reservations clerk at Pan Am's office in the U.S. Embassy had told her there were several inquiries about the notice and she got the impression there also were cancellations. Commission Chairwoman Ann McLaughlin said the panel staff has yet to find hard evidence of any changes in bookings as a result of the threat but has asked Pan Am for passenger data and is continuing its investigation. Relatives of some of the victims of the Flight 103 bombing have questioned the fact that the plane, a Boeing 747 jumbo jet, had more than 160 empty seats even though the flight was during a busy holiday period. They say they believe government personnel cancelled because of the selective warning.

DOC.HEAD: Idaho House Approves Toughest Anti-Abortion Bill Yet
DOC.TEXT: The state House approved a bill that would outlaw abortion as a method of birth control and provide the nation's strongest challenge to a 1973 Supreme Court ruling legalizing abortion. ``We're really excited,'' Nancy Myers, a spokeswoman for National Right to Life Committee in Washington, D.C., said after Friday's 47-36 vote. ``We consider it to be extremely significant.'' The measure was forwarded to the Senate after more than three hours of debate before a gallery packed with activists from both sides of the issue. The bill could come to a final Senate floor vote as early as Friday, and opponents said it stood a good chance of passing. The GOP controls both houses of the Legislature. The bill, like legislation rejected recently in Minnesota and Utah, would outlaw abortion as a method of birth control. It would allow abortions only in cases of rape, incest, ``profound and irremediable'' fetal disabilities, or to save the life or prevent ``severe and long-lasting physical health damage'' to the mother. Sponsors contend that would prevent more than 90 percent of some 1,600 abortions performed each year in Idaho. Penalties of up to $10,000 for a first offense, $30,000 for a second and $50,000 for each additional violation could be assessed against any physician performing or attempting to perform an abortion. Women undergoing the procedure would not be legally responsible. Gov. Cecil Andrus has yet to comment on the bill, but he has come out strongly against abortion in most cases. Along with a 1989 Pennsylvania law, which has been partially blocked by a federal court injunction, the Idaho bill would be the most restrictive in the nation, according to its sponsors and the National Right to Life Committee. ``I'm just so proud that Idahoans are taking the lead in returning protection to our unborn children,'' said Kerry Uhlenkott, legislative coordinator for Right to Life of Idaho Inc. ``The Supreme Court is inviting us to send up legislation, and that's what we're doing.'' Advocates of legalized abortion were disappointed that legislators ignored arguments the measure would fail to pass constitutional muster, and that most Idaho residents want the Legislature to stay out of the issue. ``I consistently heard the word `morality' used, always ascribed to the life of the unborn,'' said Sally Trott of Freedom Means Choice. ``I never heard it used in reference to the state's obligation if it's going to coerce a woman to carry a pregnancy to term.'' On Thursday, the House approved and sent the Senate legislation repealing the state's controversial ``trigger law,'' which sets criminal penalties including prison terms up to five years both for physicians and women receiving abortions. The statute would have taken effect only if the U.S. Supreme Court completely overturned its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion during the first two trimesters of pregnancy. After nearly 17 years of relative inactivity on abortion, Idaho got back into the fray after last July's U.S. Supreme Court ruling in a Missouri case, Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services, which gave states greater freedom to set limits on abortion. Opponents of the bill cited Richard Wilkins, a Brigham Young University law professor who advised the Utah Legislature against similar legislation. Wilkins opposes abortion, but contends the birth control bill goes too far in challenging the Supreme Court's stand and would be found unconstitutional on a number of grounds, including the test that state restrictions should not impose an ``undue burden'' on the mother. ``I am honestly and genuinely convinced that if we pass this bill, it will hurt the pro-life movement, that it will be struck down,'' said Democratic Rep. Patricia McDermott. But the bill's sponsors said it balances privacy concerns and the state's responsibility to intervene. ``How can any act that involves the consent of one party, the participation of a second and the destruction of a third be a purely private matter?'' asked House Majority Leader Gary Montgomery.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Chief Sees Space Station Partnership Endangered by Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The United States risks losing its international partners in the manned space station project if Congress cuts back on the $2.6 billion requested for the project in 1991, NASA Administrator Richard H. Truly says. ``I think a major reduction would cause them to look very seriously at our commitment to the project,'' Truly told the Senate science, technology and space subcommittee Friday. The space station Freedom is part of the Bush administration's $15.1 billion request for space programs in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. The project, with European, Japanese and Canadian partners, has been called the largest international research and development enterprise ever undertaken. Relations with the project partners were strained by the United States' decision last year to delay completion of construction for one year without consulting them. The administration blamed the delay on congressional funding cuts and design changes, even though the $200 million cut was half as large as the administration first alleged. The European Space Agency complained that its projects were given a back seat in the new plans. Truly said the project, scheduled for the first launch in five years and permanent manning capability in 1999, is critical for further exploration of space, especially the moon and Mars. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget request is 23 percent higher than the 1990 spending plan, and the administration expects to call for similar increases in 1992 and 1993. Subcommittee chairman Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., questioned the feasibility of getting that much money. Gore also suggested NASA might be biting off more projects than it can chew, leaving many open to the risk of underfunding during critical years. Space projects tend to have lower startup costs. The dollar amounts begin to balloon the farther along the projects get. Gore also raised the issue of the space station when he asked Truly whether the foreign partners were willing to ``sit still for a further whittling away'' at the station project, a reference to previous budget cuts. The 1991 request for the space station represents a 36 percent, or $699 million, increase over the 1990 amount. ``This is a critical time for the space station,'' Truly said. ``The program is transitioning from the preliminary design to the fabrication and testing of development hardware.'' He said ``all major contractors are on board, as are many of the subcontractors.'' Addressing the overall NASA budget, Gore questioned the administration's economic assumptions behind it: economic growth, capital gains tax reduction, more user fees and lower interest rates. ``There is still an air of unreality in the administration's approach to the budget,'' Gore said.

DOC.HEAD: Burleigh Elected Executive Vice President of E.W. Scripps
DOC.TEXT: William R. Burleigh has been elected executive vice president of the E.W. Scripps Co. and nominated to serve on its board of directors, the communications company announced. Burleigh previously was senior vice president for newspapers and publishing at Scripps. ``Bill Burleigh has proved himself to be one of the newspaper industry's top managers,'' Lawrence A. Leser, Scripps president and chief executive officer, said Friday. ``In his new role, he will work closely with me on all facets of corporate affairs, as well as continue to supervise our publishing operations.'' The E.W. Scripps Co. operates 19 daily newspapers, nine television stations, five radio stations and cable television systems with 558,000 basic subscribers. The company also is a worldwide syndicator and licenser of news features and comics. Burleigh was elected executive vice president Thursday. Shareholders will elect directors at their May 14 annual meeting here. Burleigh, 54, has been with Scripps more than 38 years, beginning his career while still in high school as a part-time sportswriter at The Evansville (Ind.) Press. After his service with the U.S. military and graduation from Marquette University, Burleigh returned to the newspaper as a reporter. He was named editor and president of the newspaper in 1975 and served as editor of The Cincinnati Post from 1977 to 1983. He joined the Scripps corporate staff in 1984 as vice president and general editorial manager. In 1986, he was promoted to senior vice president. Burleigh is a member of the board of directors of The Associated Press, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors Foundation and on the advisory board of Marquette's College of Communications. He and his wife, Anne, have three children.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Shelve Clean Air Bill Until March 20
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is taking a week-long respite from its clean-air debate as lawmakers and the White House try to work out an agreement on providing help to coal miners made jobless by stricter pollution controls. Unable to resolve the dispute, Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, canceled plans Friday to continue consideration of the clean air legislation into the weekend. The Senate, instead, adjourned for a previously scheduled recess until March 20 when, Mitchell said, the bill will be the first order of business. Senate leaders had been prepared Thursday to bring the coal miner amendment, offered by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., to a vote, but action was postponed when they grew uncertain about their strength to defeat the proposal. The amendment is one of a string of proposed changes that would significantly alter the compromise reached between Senate leaders and the White House in private negotiations. Senate leaders have said they would oppose any such amendments. Byrd described his proposal as a ``safety net'' for up to 5,000 miners who stand to lose their jobs because of tougher controls on acid rain pollution, caused by emissions from coal-burning plants. It would provide miners with up to four years of full or part salary when their job loss is attributed to the new controls. Originally Byrd had sought assistance costing nearly $1.4 billion over six years, but he then cut that in half in a bid to gain support. Nevertheless, the administration told Senate leaders the measure was still too expensive. ``If this amendment is passed, it's over'' because President Bush will not support a compromise bill that includes the coal miner provision, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said during debate Thursday night. ``The administration doesn't like this amendment one bit and that would be an understatement.'' Mitchell said Friday that negotiations were under way among Senate leaders, Byrd and the administration to try to work out a settlement. ``I'm willing to let the dice roll'' by putting the matter to a vote, Byrd said. Mitchell had threatened all week to hold the senators in session into today if necessary to work out key provisions of the clean air legislation. But he canceled those plans Friday because of the impasse over the coal miner assistance issue. Amendments still pending include several that would strengthen the pollution controls, including those upon automobiles. Several of those measures, especially a call for a second round of auto emission controls and broader alternative fuels programs, are opposed by the administration. Mitchell said he hoped the Senate could move swiftly when it returns March 20, because then ``we are going to stay on this bill until we finish it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Experts in Laos on Search For Missing Servicemen
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military experts today arrived in Laos to try to recover the remains of American airmen whose planes crashed during the Vietnam War, a spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Bangkok said. The 16 Americans will work with Laotian specialists in excavating the area in southern Laos where March 1989 survey ``found evidence that (it) may yield the remains of Americans missing in action,'' said the spokesman, James Williams. The joint excavation will take 2-3 weeks, he said, quoting a Pentagon statement. U.S. and Laotian specialists also will conduct surveys at several other sites during this time, he said. The 16 Americans are from the U.S. Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory, Hawaii-based units entrusted with accounting for America's wartime missing. In January, another joint excavation in Communist Laos recovered remains that are still being analyzed, Williams said. Williams said 2,304 Americans are listed as missing from the Vietnam War, which also involved fighting in neighboring Laos and Cambodia. Of those, 1,679 are missing in Vietnam, 537 in Laos, 82 in Cambodia and six in coastal waters off China. On Tuesday, U.S. and Vietnamese specialists completed a joint search in five northern Vietnamese provinces for information on 12 missing American airmen, the official Vietnam News Agency reported. It did not say if anything was found.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Fight Called Another No-Win War for Military
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military is widening its role in the war on drugs, but critics say the Pentagon may be battling a foe it cannot defeat. ``American troops will be entering a quagmire more complex than Vietnam,'' said Kevin Zeese, vice president of the Drug Policy Foundation, a Washington think tank that emphasizes the economic and social issues behind the drug problem. Zeese commented after the Defense Department announced Friday that it was adding warships, aircraft, radar equipment, dog teams and other military resources in the Atlantic, Pacific, Caribbean and along the southern U.S. border. The plan greatly extends the military's involvement in efforts to stem the flow of drugs into the United States and to help Colombia, Bolivia and other Latin American countries combat their drug cartels on land, sea and in the air. ``Deploying appropriate elements of the armed forces ... should, over time, help reduce the flow of drugs into the country,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in a written statement. Cheney, who did not attend a news briefing on the program, made clear in his statement that the impetus for wider military involvement in the drug war came from the White House, not the Pentagon. ``President Bush gave the Defense Department a clear set of marching orders when he issued his National Drug Control Strategy'' last September, Cheney said. ``These plans carry out those orders.'' The Pentagon's civilian and military leaders had resisted diverting military forces to the drug war during the Reagan administration. Cheney's announcement won praise from some members of Congress. Rep. Charles B. Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics, applauded Cheney for providing an assurance that no military people or resources would be used in a Latin American country without that nation's approval. ``I am extremely pleased the military is becoming a full partner in the war on drugs, as directed by Congress,'' Rangel said. Stephen M. Duncan, Cheney's coordinator of drug enforcement policy, said the drug-fighting plan would cost nearly twice the $450 million appropriated by Congress for Pentagon anti-drug efforts this year. He said the services would have to ``cough up out of their hide'' the extra funds. The administration has asked Congress to approve $1.2 billion in Pentagon spending on the drug war next year. Duncan outlined the following plans for increased military action in the drug war: _Four or five naval ships are being used exclusively for tracking and stopping drug traffic in international waters in the Caribbean and Atlantic. None had been dedicated to this use before this year. More of the Air Force's Airborne Warning and Control Systems, or AWACS, surveillance aircraft also will be used in the Atlantic. _The U.S. Atlantic and Pacific commands each plan to use more than eight classes of aircraft and six classes of ships for the drug-interdiction strategy. The aircraft include P-3 Orions, F-4 Phantoms and F-14 Tomcats. Ships include destroyers, frigates, aircraft carriers and amphibious and logistic support ships. _The North American Aerospace Defense Command will use a network of 44 ground radars designed to warn of high-altitude penetrations of U.S. airspace. It also will increase its patrol of the U.S. southern border and coasts by using AWACS planes and 50 interceptor alert aircraft positioned at 25 locations nationwide. _The Pacific Command will greatly increase its use of ships and aircraft to provide intelligence data on drug trafficking. It also will use military dog teams, when requested by civilian police authorities, to help detect illegal drugs at air and sea ports of entry. _The U.S. Southern Command in Panama will provide training and other support to Latin American nations asking for help against their drug cartels. It also will use a Caribbean Basin radar network that consists of a series of early warning radars, some already in place, to detect and monitor drug traffickers. Duncan refused to say how many U.S. troops will be used in Latin America.

DOC.HEAD: Fellow Captain Comes to Hazelwood's Defense
DOC.TEXT: ANCHORAGE, Alaska _ Joseph Hazelwood had set up a ``very nice maneuver'' and should not be faulted for leaving the bridge of the Exxon Valdez before the tanker went aground, a veteran captain said. In testimony for the defense Friday, Shiras Walker of Jacksonville, Fla., said he would have acted much as Hazelwood did on the day of the nation's worst oil spill. Hazelwood did no wrong in leaving the ship in the hands of the third mate after giving instructions to avoid channel ice, Walker said. ``It was a very gentle turn. ... He was setting himself up for a very nice maneuver around the ice,'' said Walker. ``He was never putting his vessel in grave danger.'' Walker, who commanded ships through the Valdez Narrows for nine years and now works as a river pilot, rebutted earlier testimony from prosecution witnesses on these key points: _ The third mate's lack of pilotage endorsement. Although Walker obtained the Coast Guard endorsement required to pilot in Prince William Sound, he said he understood the requirement for this license had been waived whenever visibility was two miles or more. Exxon captain Andre Martineau, who testified before Walker, agreed: ``At that point in time, there were so many vessels running up there without pilotage that there didn't seem to be much point in monitoring the pilotage requirements.'' _ Coast Guard monitoring. Walker said he understood the Coast Guard always kept an eye on tankers to avoid collisions and groundings. If they noticed anything wrong, he said, ``they would really give the pilots hell.'' Coast Guard monitors said they lost sight of the Exxon Valdez on their radar and gave the ship no warning. _ The 10 degree right rudder turn which was not executed, causing the tanker to run aground. Walker said it is one of the simplest commands for a helmsman to carry out. ``It's a very simple thing. It's even easier than steering some cars.'' _ Hazelwood's failure to sound a general alarm for the crew. Walker said it would have created panic. ``I would have done exactly what captain Hazelwood did.'' _ Hazelwood's post-grounding behavior. ``I think he was really thinking,'' Walker said of the skipper's orders to gather information, lower lifeboats and check the engine room. ``It's amazing. With all the crushing problems on him to be able to think that quickly.'' ``I've been through groundings,'' Walker said. ``The feeling is equivalent to being punched in the stomach. And I'm talking about a one-to-two barrel spill, not something of this magnitude. To bear up under that _ it's amazing.'' Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., faces up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines if convicted of the four criminal charges he faces. The Exxon Valdez went aground March 24, spilling almost 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into Prince William Sound, polluting the rocky shore and killing countless birds, fish and other widlife. A central issue confronting jurors is whether Hazelwood was reckless when he allowed third mate Greg Cousins to take control of the ship while the skipper went below. Hazelwood was the only officer on board who had the Coast Guard pilotage endorsement. Walker said Hazelwood was not reckless, noting, ``He left proper instructions with his mate.'' Also Friday, Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone dismissed a juror and replaced her with an alternate during a secret session with lawyers for both sides. Johnstone refused to disclose why the woman had been excused. ``It's not a big deal,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former People's Temple Lawyer Runs For Congress
DOC.TEXT: A former chairman of the Rev. Jim Jones' People's Temple is running for Congress as a Republican on an environmentalist platform. ``Having witnessed the abuse of power, I will give my all to being the most responsible of public servants,'' said Tim Stoen, a candidate in the June primary for the seat held by Democratic Rep. Doug Bosco. Stoen's 6-year-old son, John Victor, was among the more than 900 people who perished in the mass suicide-murder at Jonestown in the Guyana jungle in 1978. Stoen, 52, a former prosecutor, also served as Jones' legal adviser but the two parted ways a year before the Jonestown tragedy. Jones held onto his son ``to show people what happens to `traitors,''' Stoen said Friday. The primary problem facing his district, in the redwoods country north of San Francisco, is over-cutting by the timber industry, Stoen said. ``We must save timber jobs by cutting the harvest rate,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: North Says Lying to Congress Was His Own Idea
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North says he lied repeatedly to Congress after national security adviser John Poindexter told him to ``take care of'' inquiries into whether he was secretly assisting the Nicaraguan rebels. But ``nobody ever told me to lie to Congress,'' North testified Friday at Poindexter's trial, insisting that he decided on his own to make the false statements after his boss sent him to meet with House Intelligence Committee members on Aug. 6, 1986. Poindexter watched intently while North spent the day on the witness stand in U.S. District Court, reluctantly testifying against his former boss on the National Security Council staff. North, the government's first witness, returns Monday to face questioning about the Iran initiative. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb led North through his recollections of a conversation with Poindexter, in which North said he didn't think it would be a ``very good idea'' to meet with the congressmen. North testified at his own trial last year about the conversation in some detail, but he said Friday he was unable to remember much of his earlier testimony. Under prodding by Webb, North said he had ``a general recollection'' of telling Poindexter that there were things that could not be revealed to the congressmen and that meeting with them would create ``vulnerability.'' ``I didn't want to be in that predicament,'' said North. He recalled that Poindexter told him something like ``you can handle it or you can take care of it. I do not remember the specific preambular language on either side.'' Asserting that neither Poindexter nor anyone else had ordered him to tell falsehoods, North said, ``I didn't walk into the meeting intending to lie.'' He said he made false statements when he told the congressmen he wasn't providing military advice to the Contra rebels, hadn't been in frequent contact with Contra liaison Robert Owen and hadn't been in touch with rebel supporter John Singlaub in 20 months. ``I recall deceiving them about the full measure of my involvement,'' North testified. North balked when Webb showed him a computer message from Poindexter sent several days after the meeting in which the national security official told North, ``Well done.'' North suggested that the message sent on the computer may not have been a reference to his false statements to the congressmen. At that point, Webb pulled out North's testimony to the congressional Iran-Contra committees on July 8, 1987. North told that hearing that he informed Poindexter what he had told the congressmen, and that in response his boss said, ``Well done.'' ``Do you recall that?'' Webb asked North. ``I do not,'' North replied. ``Did that surprise you that you got a note saying `Well done?''' Webb continued. ``Not particularly,'' said North. While defending himself at his trial last year, North was much more emphatic in recalling the conversation in which Poindexter directed him to meet with the congressmen. ``I said ... I don't think this is a very good idea,'' North testified on April 7, 1989. ``I had told him ... that he and I both knew ... that there were all kinds of things that just could not be revealed, that could not be divulged, and that he and I both knew what they were,'' North testified at his trial. North said one of the things was Saudi Arabia's aid to the Contras, which President Reagan had admonished must never be revealed. Poindexter's response, said North, was, ``You can handle it ... you can take care of it. Not in the sense that it was going to be unlawful, just in the sense, you can take care of it.'' In his trial testimony, North went on to say that ``I felt like a pawn in a chess game being played by giants.'' Poindexter is accused of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements for allegedly concealing North's secret Contra resupply network and U.S. involvement in a 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran. North is appealing his conviction on charges of conspiracy, aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress and accepting an illegal gratuity.

DOC.HEAD: Fog Almost Scuttles Heart Transplant
DOC.TEXT: A relay of troopers from two states rushed a heart to a 13-year-old transplant patient after fog forced doctors to land at an airport 50 miles away. Three doctors flying the heart from Tulsa, Okla., to Detroit were forced by fog to land Friday in Toledo, Ohio, said Dr. Michael Deeb, director of the University of Michigan Medical Center's heart-transplant program. Ohio state troopers drove the doctors and their heart to the state line, 50 miles from Ann Arbor. ``We jumped out of one (cruiser) and into another with our little heart, but these people couldn't take us all the way to Ann Arbor, only to the Washtenaw County line,'' Deeb said. Another state police trooper met the surgeons and drove them to the hospital in Ann Arbor. The patient was fine after the transplant. A transplant organ is only good for about four hours; doctors arrived with one hour to spare, Deeb said.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Pressing Rich-Get-Richer Argument in Capital Gains Fight
DOC.TEXT: Democrats in Congress are zeroing in on the rich-get-richer argument as they battle President Bush's proposal to cut taxes on capital gains. Changes in federal tax laws since 1977 have shifted considerably more of the tax burden away from the wealthiest taxpayers and a capital-gains cut would worsen the inequity, the Congressional Budget Office says in a new report. In releasing the study Friday, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, described as ``staggering'' the tax shift and the increases in incomes of the richest Americans. The non-partisan CBO estimated that 59 percent of the capital-gains tax cut would go to the richest 1 percent of Americans, whose incomes average $162,000. The top 5 percent, averaging almost $59,000, would get 85 percent of the reduction. Other analyses by CBO, the Ways and Means Committee staff and a labor-financed group, Citizens for Tax Justice, released in recent days reached the same conclusions. Senior aides to Rostenkowski said that without such analyses, the heated debate over cutting taxes on capital gains _ which are profits from the sale of investments _ would be conducted solely on administration claims that the reduction would boost the economy and lower the budget deficit. ``The administration is not raising the other issue: what has happened to tax progressivity in the 1980s,'' said one aide, who like others briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Progressivity refers to a tax system based on ability to pay. The aides acknowledged that Rostenkowski does not now have the votes to defeat a capital-gains tax cut. Bush has proposed to lower the current 28 percent and 33 percent tax rates on capital gains by nearly one-third. Meanwhile, Rostenkowski carried his fight against the cut to a convention of securities dealers in Boca Raton, Fla. He said the proposal is neck-and-neck with a Social Security tax cut in the race for dumbest idea of the year. ``I was left nearly speechless by this competition until I finally decided to simply call both proposals political junk food and just let them go at that,'' Rostenkowski said. Democratic leaders in the House and Senate are weighing how to respond to a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut Social Security taxes in order to keep the government from using surplus taxes to make the budget deficit look smaller than it is. The Democratic response on that issue will be included in a plan, expected soon, setting out the party's policy on a broad array of tax and budget issues. Rostenkowski is getting the jump on his fellow Democratic leaders. In an article written for Sunday's editions of The Washington Post, he is expected to call once again for a sharp increase in the gasoline tax and perhaps for higher taxes on tobacco, alcohol and crude oil. The CBO report released Friday concluded basically that major tax laws enacted in 1978 and 1981 cut taxes significantly for the wealthiest Americans but not nearly so much for those at other income levels. The conclusion is essentially the same as was reached in a study released Citizens for Tax Justice. That study found that if the tax laws were made as fair today as they were in 1977, all but the richest 10 percent would pay less and the government would still collect $67.5 billion a year more. The Bush administration prefers to point out that the richest Americans are paying a greater share of the total tax burden than they were in 1977. Congressional economists agree _ but say the reason is that incomes of the wealthiest 10 percent have soared during the same period.

DOC.HEAD: Another Computer Glitch Holding Up Tax Refunds
DOC.TEXT: For the second time this week, hundreds of thousands of tax refunds have been delayed by the Internal Revenue Service's outdated computer system. The IRS said Friday that 171,000 returns filed into the Ogden, Utah, service center from 25 Midwestern and Northwestern states were delayed because of a faulty computer tape. That number included 31,000 returns filed electronically. ``What this is going to mean is that these people who have filed electronically will still get a refund within the two- or three-week time frame promised, but it will be more toward the end,'' said Ellen Murphy, IRS public affairs director. Filers of paper returns have been getting refunds in five to six weeks. On Tuesday, the IRS said 53,000 electronic returns and as many as 200,000 paper returns filed into the Cincinnati and Memphis centers had been delayed two weeks because of a breakdown in the transportation of several reels of computer tape. The IRS service-center computers used to process returns cannot communicate with those at the Martinsburg, W.Va., center where refunds are certified. Tapes from the service centers must be flown to Washington National Airport and trucked from there to Martinsburg. The Ogden service center tape containing data from returns filed in late February was shipped to Martinsburg, where it was found to be faulty. A backup tape was received at Martinsburg within 24 hours. But since processing is done on a weekly basis, Ms. Murphy said, refunds had to be delayed into the following week. Of 6,000 reels of tape processed this year, she said, about a dozen have had to be reshipped because of faulty ``formatting'' or other glitches. Through March 3, the IRS had received 38.6 million returns, up 3 percent from the 37.5 million in the same period last year. Processing is up 15 percent, 25.3 million compared with 22 million a year ago. Just under 3 million electronic returns have been received, a 281 percent increase over 777,000 at this time last year. The IRS expects about 110 million individual returns to be filed this year.

DOC.HEAD: Full-Scale Production at Plutonium Plant Not Likely Before Fall
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department is aiming at a June restart of production at its Rocky Flats, Colo., plant, the sole supplier of plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. The plant, 16 miles from Denver, has been closed since last November. The department ordered safety and management improvements, although it insists the facility poses no threat to public health. On Friday, the department said it had approved a restart plan submitted by EG&G Inc., which operates Rocky Flats for the government under contract. The restart plan calls for a phased resumption of plutonium production by the end of June, with all six plutonium buildings back in operation by the end of September. The announcement did not say exactly when full production would be restored, although department officials said in late February that it probably would be sometime this fall. Catherine Kaliniak, an Energy Department spokeswoman, said a firmer estimate of the restart schedule dates might be announced as early as April. Among the improvements that EG&G said it will make before resuming production are better procedures for verifying safety and alarm systems, better training, new management oversight and an environmental compliance review. Implementation of the improvements will be monitored by EG&G officials and department headquarters officials. Progress will be assessed by an independent oversight board and then Energy Secretary James D. Watkins will be asked to give the final OK for restart. Rocky Flats has been plagued by a variety of operating and waste-handling problems in recent years. Last June, the FBI raided the facility in search of evidence of criminal violations of laws governing the handling of radioactive wastes. A grand jury was impaneled last August but no indictments have been returned. EG&G, a longtime weapons industry contractor based in Wellesley, Mass., officially took over Rocky Flats on Jan. 1 from Rockwell International Corp., although EG&G has been working on a plant-improvement strategy since last September. Rockwell quit operating the plant last September in a dispute with Watkins over legal liability for environmental violations.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Offers Teacher No Retribution
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Gaston Caperton offered to pay teachers for the class they missed during a three-day walkout if they end West Virginia's first teacher strike and return to schools Monday. Leaders of the biggest union, the West Virginia Education Association, declined to comment on Caperton's offer Friday. Bob Brown, executive director of the smaller West Virginia Federation of Teachers said representatives of his 3,000-teacher union were meeting today to discuss the proposal. Capterton had earlier refused to negotiate until teachers returned to work. Attorney General Roger Tompkins on Thursday said local school boards could suspend, fire or file criminal charges against striking teachers. Education Secretary Steve Haid said it would be up to each of the 55 county school boards whether to follow the governor's recommendation of clemency and pay for the strike days, but he said he expects all to comply. ``We're trying to create an atmosphere of cooperation,'' Haid said. Caperton said negotiations on pay and benefits can begin once the teachers return to work. He acknowledged that a pay raise will require a tax increase, and Haid said a special legislative session later this spring is possible. ``That's a very, very important conciliatory offer on the governor's part, because I am sure there are a lot of people out there who think it's overly generous,'' said Education Secretary Steve Haid. The strike began Wednesday after the governor and legislative leaders withdrew a 5 percent pay raise offer, saying the package couldn't win legislative approval because the WVEA refused to say it wouldn't strike. The WVEA says the average West Virginia teacher salary of $21,904 ranks the state 49th in the nation, ahead only of Mississippi. West Virginia teachers received a 5 percent pay raise last month. The strike spread to 40 of the 55 counties Friday, and the state Education Department said there was no class at all in 24 counties, with five others reporting some schools closed and some open. West Virginia Education Association President Kayetta Meadows said earlier Friday her 16,000-member organization was willing to resume talks but was not ready ``at this time'' to go back to class. More than 1,000 striking teachers, most wearing bright red, swarmed through the Capitol on Friday for the third straight day. The teachers have begun wearing anything red _ from sweaters to coats to hats _ as a symbol of unity, much as striking coal miners wear camouflage. An additional 3,000 teachers in the state are not represented by either union.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Michelle Jones' ``crime'' of planting unauthorized marigolds has brought her a $50 fine and could result in summary execution by trimmer for the felonious flowers. She plunked down $6 for the yellow flowers and planted them around a bottlebrush tree and a ficus tree in front of her townhouse. ``I just thought it looked nice,'' said Jones. But she failed to get permission from the homeowners' association, which requires prior permission to plant trees in the common ground, said association lawyer David Black. ``I think the people in the complex should live by their own rules and regulations, which are for the benefit of them,'' said Black. Jones got the notice of her fine in a registered letter last week.

It was a case of mistaken identity. A man dressed as a woman was arrested after his underwear, stuffed with allegedly stolen women's clothing, fell around his ankles and tripped him, police said. After leading a store manager, witness and police officer on a chase through a parking lot, Darryl Willums, 23, was charged with robbery for the theft of 14 clothing items worth $457. The manager had noticed a bulge under Willum's clothing and several empty hangars in the Lerner's store and asked him not to leave, said officer Dusty Cutler. But Willums threw some money at a clerk, shoved her out of the way and ran from the store, Cutler said. Cutler said she was driving through the lot when she spotted the manager and a witness chasing Willums, and joined the pursuit in her cruiser. Willums fell when his clothing-filled drawers dropped to his ankles, but he pulled off the undies and continued running, throwing clothing from his purse as he went, Cutler said. Cutler said she finally cut Willums off with her car.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Allows Arrests for Rap Sales
DOC.TEXT: A judge's ruling will allow sheriffs to arrest shop owners for selling a rap album that allegedly contains obscenities. Gov. Bob Martinez last month made an unsuccessful effort to get state prosecutors to investigate the Miami rap group 2 Live Crew over the lyrics in ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' Broward Circuit Judge Mel Grossman on Friday ruled there was probable cause to believe the record was obscene, and therefore to ban its sale in Broward County, north of Miami. A Fort Myers judge last month ordered the album pulled from the shelves in Lee County, on the Gulf. Sales to juveniles would be punished as a felony, adults sales as a misdemeanor, said Broward sheriff's spokesman Al Gordon. At Q Records and Tapes in Boca Raton, sales are up because of the publicity the album is getting, night manager Pete Scharlatt said.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Leader Agrees To Consider Sweeping Political Changes
DOC.TEXT: In a major victory for Mongolia's pro-democracy movement, its Communist leader proposed a plebiscite for the party-controlled legislature and called for a revamped party Politburo, a foreign source said today. The Soviet news agency Tass said President Zhambyn Batmonh would consider ousting the entire Politburo. Batmonh, also the party chief, called for a party Central Committee meeting Monday. His televised address Friday came amid increasing pressure from the 3-month-old reform movement and raised the odds Mongolia would become Asia's first Communist country to undergo sweeping political change. The events brought the wave of political reform to the doorstep of China, which has crushed its own democracy movement last spring with the army attack on protesters in Beijing. In his speech, Batmonh also appealed for opposition groups to respect law and order and end a three-day hunger strike, said the foreign source, speaking in a telephone interview from the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator. The source said the hunger strikers, gathered in a roped-off area on the capital's central square, ended their fast Friday night. There were about 30 participants at the end. A general strike proposed for today by demonstrators who gathered in the square Friday was also likely to be called off in response to the concessions made by Batmonh, the source said. Batmonh, a former university rector who took power in 1984, said the Central Committee will consider calling a special party congress. He said he hoped the meetings would result in the election of a new ruling Politburo but did not say what kind of leaders he had in mind. Monday's meeting will also take up the question of holding a referendum on the Great People's Hural, which under Communist rule has little power and is not directly elected. The party's 69-year monopoly on power may also be on the agenda. The opposition, which first took to the streets in peaceful demonstrations in December, complains that Mongolia is moving too slowly in its version of perestroika, the Soviet word for restructuring that is used to describe Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform policies. Two newly formed opposition parties _ the Mongolian Democratic Party and the Social Democratic Party _ have demanded the resignation of the Politburo, the dissolution of the legislature for new elections and recognition of a multiparty system. They and smaller opposition groups have also blamed the party for the nation's economic stagnation and its heavy dependence on Moscow. About 50,000 advisers and 60,000 troops are in Mongolia, which lies between the Soviet Union and China. They say the Soviet Union doesn't pay enough for Mongolia's natural resources and has saddled the nation of 2 million people with a debt estimated by Western economists at $6 billion. The government, which began a cautious restructuring program in 1988, has taken a conciliatory stance toward the opposition demands and has not interfered with street rallies, but has urged the reformists against pressing too hard for rapid change.

DOC.HEAD: 150 Injured in Clashes Over Local Elections
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of rival candidates in local council elections hurled rocks and homemade bombs at each other in two southwestern cities, injuring at least 150 people, newspapers said today. The clashes occurred Friday in Khulna, a river port city 85 miles southwest of Dhaka, and in Jessore, about 30 miles northwest of Khulna. The independent Bengali newspaper Khabar said about 100 people were injured in the Khulna clashes between supporters of two candidates from President Hussain Muhammad Ershad's Jatiya Party. The trouble started when the two sets of supporters tried to welcome Civil Aviation Minister Abdul Gaffar, who had come to Khulna to address a public rally, the newspaper said. Both groups claimed their candidate had the Jatiya Party's support. The local council elections, which traditionally are the most violent in Bangladesh, are scheduled for March 14-25. They are non-partisan, but clashes usually erupt along party lines because local voters know the party affiliations of the technically independent candidates. In Jessore, at least 50 people were injured in clashes between supporters of the Jatiya Party and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, according to another independent Bengali daily, Bangla Bani. The Nationalist Party, headed by Khaleda Zia, is one of the country's biggest opposition parties. Last week, two people were shot to death in campaign violence in the country's northwestern Pabna district.

DOC.HEAD: San Diegans Seek Alternative to Cramped Lindbergh Field
DOC.TEXT: A cramped and nerve-wracking airport and no room to build a new one has San Diego in a tight spot. It's hard to imagine a more picturesque setting for an international airport _ on a bayfront flanked by rolling hills, glassy skyscrapers and the gray magnificence of a Navy fleet. But to pilots who are forced by downtown buildings to descend steeply on approach to Lindbergh Field, the setting for the airport serving the nation's sixth largest city is all wrong. ``It's the worst airport in the world,'' said Tom Carroll of the Air Line Pilots Association. Some would call than an exaggeration, but a 1988 survey of 1,360 pilots found Lindbergh Field tied in fith place with Denver's Singleton Airport as the least safe airport in the United States. Transportation planners and civic leaders, who eye the land that Lindbergh sits on for downtown expansion, have spent 30 years searching for a replacement. The most frequently discussed option is to convert the Miramar Naval Air Station to a commercial or joint-use airport. The Navy is adamantly opposed to any such plan. Unless an alternative is found by the turn of the century, Lindbergh, built in 1928, could throw a wrench into the region's robust economy. ``San Diego is running into an economic buzz saw if we wait any longer,'' said Dan Pegg, president of the San Diego Economic Development Corp. ``It's absolutely the toughest issue in San Diego,'' said Jack Koerper, the director of special projects for the San Diego Association of Governments, the regional planning agency conducting the airport search. Squeezed onto 485 acres, Lindbergh is surrounded by San Diego Bay, the Marine Corps Recruit Depot, businesses, residential areas and rolling hills. ``One pilot likened it to landing in a shoebox,'' said Dick Russell of the pilots association. ``I cannot and will not say it's unsafe, but I will say a pilot flying into Lindbergh has to be on the ball at all times. There's very little room for error,'' he said. Lindbergh handled 11 million people last year, but planners say its saturation point may come in five to 10 years, the time to make another airport operational. A new airport would have to serve about 40 million passengers by 2050, aviation planners and civic leaders say. Despite some 40 studies since 1960, no consensus has developed on an alternative to Lindbergh. One proposal called for a binational airport on Otay Mesa, at the Mexican border, but that would require the negotiation of international agreements with Mexico. Other possibilities include a ``hub-and-spoke'' concept in which a main airport would be constructed in Imperial Valley, some 100 miles to the east, with travelers shuttled to San Diego on smaller planes or a high-speed train. An offshore, or ``floating'' airport also has been discussed. Around San Diego, options have dwindled as urban sprawl gobbled undeveloped land. ``The only place that development hasn't preempted is Miramar and that's because the Navy has preserved it,'' said county supervisor Brian Bilbray. But the cost of replacing the air base, home to the ``Top Gun'' pilot school, would be $10 billion, said U.S. Rep. Bill Lowery, R-San Diego. ``Miramar is not an option,'' said Lowery. ``The Navy's not just said `no.' They've said, `Hell, no.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Government Retraces Cross-Country Path of Radioactive Cargo Shipment
DOC.TEXT: Officials are trying to find dock workers, truck drivers and others who may have been exposed to an intensely radioactive pellet found in cargo shipped from Korea to California to Massachusetts. ``There is no need for panic but there certainly is reason for concern,'' Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokesman Karl Abraham said Friday. ``People could have received significant exposure.'' Abraham could not say how many people may have been exposed, nor what radioactive isotope was involved. He said the radioactive material was used for making X-ray-type pictures of welds, structural steels and other industrial objects. The pellet _ the size of a pencil eraser _ was discovered lying loose and unshielded in the bottom of a container that was supposed to be empty. The container was being sent back to a manufacturer for reuse in shipping new pellets, Abraham said. The pellet was in a shipment of containers that arrived in the Boston area two weeks ago, more than a month after it was sent from South Korea to Los Angeles for storage. The shipment then was trucked from California to Pennsylvania, Maryland and Massachusetts, Abraham said. A preliminary survey of the truck as it arrived at Amersham Inc. of Burlington revealed some radioactivity and, on closer examination, technicians found 1,500 times more radiation within six inches of the source, Abraham said. He said tests 4 to 6 inches from the pellet found the level of radiation to be 150 rems per hour, millions of times higher than normal background levels. A rem is a measure of the estimated damage done to living tissue by radiation; people generally receive about one-tenth of a rem, or 100 millirem, of radiation annually from natural sources, while the average American is exposed to an annual dose of 77 millirem from medical X-rays. U.S. Department of Transportation investigators were working with the NRC to establish the shipment's route and track down dock workers, cargo handlers, truck drivers, warehouse managers and other people who may have been exposed to the pellet, Abraham said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Swears In Surgeon General
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has sworn in Dr. Antonia Novello as the nation's surgeon general, making it clear he expects no break in the anti-smoking and anti-drug abuse crusades of her predecessors. In a brief White House ceremony Friday, Bush saluted both the new appointee and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, himself a fervent critic of tobacco use. ``My respect and appreciation of my good friend Lou Sullivan grows every day as he fights for the good health of our people,'' Bush said. ``In the few minutes we've been here, 11 people have died from smoking, 390,000 people each year.'' Novello declared her motto would be ``good science and good sense.'' She thanked Bush for an appointment that she said should be an inspiration to women and minorities. ``The American dream is well and alive,'' Novello, the first woman and first Hispanic to serve as surgeon general, said. ``Once a dream, it is now my pledge: to be a good doctor for all who live in this great country.'' Novello, who succeeds C. Everett Koop, is a pediatrician who has specialized on AIDS and kidney disease in children.
DOC.HEAD: Senate Confirms Dunne for Civil Rights Post
DOC.TEXT: John R. Dunne has been unanimously confirmed by the Senate to be assistant attorney general for civil rights, filling a 15-month vacancy at the Justice Department. Dunne, a former New York state senator with little prior involvement in civil rights issues, was confirmed by voice vote Friday. The Senate Judiciary Committee had recommended Dunne the day before despite criticism over his former memberships in clubs that excluded women and stock holdings in a company that does business in South Africa Dunne, 60, of Garden City, N.Y., was nominated in January for the post, which had been vacant since December 1988 when William Bradford Reynolds resigned. President Bush's first choice for the job, William C. Lucas of Michigan, was rejected by the Judiciary Committee last August. Dunne played a minor role in Bush's New York campaign. He was a New York state senator for 24 years, resigning last year after losing a race for majority leader, and is a partner in the Uniondale, N.Y., law firm of Rivkin, Radler, Dunne & Bayh. Civil rights groups criticized Dunne's almost nonexistent civil rights record, but none opposed his nomination. But Dune drew fire for having held longtime memberships in the Fort Orange Club in Albany, N.Y., and the Garden City Golf Club on Long Island, N.Y. The Fort Orange admitted women in 1988; the golf club is still sex-segregated.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Faulty On Delay for Lab Rules
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress are criticizing the Bush administration for missing the deadline for setting out regulations to ensure the quality and accuracy of all medical laboratory tests. Lawmakers were not appeased by the Health Care Financing Administration's announcement that final rules to bring 12,000 medical labs under uniform national testing standards would be published next week and could take effect after a 60-day comment period. By HCFA's own estimate, there are between 300,000 and 600,000 medical testing facilities _ including labs in physicians' offices, employer health units, public health departments, blood banks and public screening labs. Most of those would be covered by other rules HCFA is drafting, but has not yet formally proposed. ``It is critical that all laboratories be regulated,'' Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., said Friday at the joint hearing of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee and the Governmental Affairs subcommittee on oversight of government management. ``Each month the implementation ... is delayed, more cases of cancer go undetected, more men and women receive erroneous laboratory reports and more tragedies result.'' Gail Wilensky, head of HCFA, told the lawmakers the rules covering 12,000 labs that receive payments from Medicare and Medicaid ``will make a tremendous difference'' in the way those labs operate. She said those rules were already being drafted when Congress passed a law in 1988 giving HCFA authority to regulate all testing labs and directing the agency to have rules in place to implement the law by Jan. 1, 1990. The main reason for the delay in meeting that deadline, she said, was ``major unexpected dissension within the scientific community'' over the amount of regulation various types of tests should require. She said HCFA expected to propose rules to meet the 1988 law in three stages.

DOC.HEAD: No Talks Planned as Strike Enters Second Week
LaserPhoto CD1
DOC.TEXT: Striking Greyhound bus drivers entered their second weekend of picketing today with no talks scheduled to resolve the walkout at the only nationwide bus company. Bullets, a beating and a bomb threat disrupted Greyhound bus travel Friday, while striking drivers held memorial services at terminals around the country for a driver killed last Saturday when a bus crushed him against a wall in Redding, Calif. Members of the House Education and Labor Committee, meanwhile, urged Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole to help resolve the dispute. A Greyhound bus carrying 29 passengers was hit by three shots fired from a passing car. No one was injured in the shooting on Interstate 71 about 25 miles southwest of Columbus, Ohio. The bullets struck a window near the driver, a window at the back of the bus, and above the baggage bin, said Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale. The bus was operated by a driver from a company that is helping Greyhound during the strike, she said. The striking union condemns violence, spokesman Nick Nichols said. ``I hate to think the public would point the finger at any of the people on the picket lines,'' Nichols said. ``I can tell you that the union in no way condones violent acts or property damage.'' In Pittsburgh, strikers claimed that police beat a striking driver as officers struggled Thursday night with pickets who were attempting to block a bus bound for Columbus, Ohio. Allegheny County sheriff Eugene Coon denied the charges of brutality. The driver, 43-year-old Carl Masi, was charged with inciting a riot, assault and other charges. A Greyhound bus en route from Las Vegas to Los Angeles was stopped in the California desert and the passengers evacuated after an anonymous caller reported hearing two men in a Las Vegas casino restaurant talking about a bomb on the bus. A search with bomb-sniffing dogs on Interstate 15 outside Baker, Calif., failed to find a bomb. The 24 passengers finished their trip on another bus, said Nevada Highway Patrol trooper Philip Dart. Memorials and prayer services were held across the country Friday for driver Bob Waterhouse, 59. In Cleveland, Mayor Michael R. White walked with several hundred strikers and other labor activists in a rush-hour march in memory of the dead driver. The protesters chanted ``Don't ride the bus'' as they walked by the bus terminal. ``We're here to show solidarity against union busting,'' said Dan Strahinich of the Health Care Employees Union at a rally in Hartford, Conn. ``That's what Greyhound is trying to do.'' Federal mediators will meet next week with the union, and later with company representatives, said Greyhound spokesman George Gravley. ``There will absolutely be no talks whatsoever with Greyhound this weekend,'' Gravley said. ``The federal mediators will let us know sometime next week when they or the union want to talk to us again.'' A judge on Friday ordered limits on picketing by striking Greyhound drivers at the company's depots in Oregon. Multnomah Circuit Judge Robert W. Redding directed that strikers post no more than four pickets at any entrance to Greyhound's bus depots. Non-picketing demonstrators were ordered to stay at least 120 feet from the company's property. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 of Greyhound's office and maintenance workers, went on strike March 2 when it failed to reach agreement with the company on a three-year contract. Greyhound executive vice president P. Anthony Lannie said the union's last offer would cost $205 million over three years, but the union has said the pact would total less than the $63 million the company has offered.

DOC.HEAD: Police, US Troops Make House-to-House Sweep for Weapons, Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Police and U.S. troops swept through Panama City, seizing weapons and drugs and rounding up hundreds of suspects to try to stop a crime wave. ``We want to get criminals off the street so our citizens can once again walk around without fear of being held up,'' Vice Minister of Government and Justice Ramon Lima said of the raids Friday. Widespread looting broke out after U.S. forces invaded Dec. 20, ousted Manuel Noriega and effectively disbanded his Defense Forces, which served as police and army in the country.
