While widespread looting has ended, citizens complain of robberies at stoplights, among other assaults, and say more firearms are being used. Authorities say the murder rate has quintupled. Lima said 760 people were arrested in the Friday raids, but they yielded none of the large caches of weapons believed still hidden by ex-members of the Defense Forces. He said many people apparently were tipped off in advance and fled. ``We did not confiscate the amount of weapons we had expected,'' Lima told a news conference. He said police found 47 shotguns, pistols and revolvers but no military weapons. Police also seized undisclosed amounts of cocaine, marijuana and crack, he said. About 260 American soldiers took part in the operation ``in support of the Panamanian police,'' William Ormsbee, a spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command, said. The soldiers worked with about 400 Panamanian law enforcement officers, whom they have been training in police work since the new civilian government abolished the Defense Forces and created a police force. Many of the new policemen are former members of the Defense Forces. Government officials express concern about hidden weapons they fear could be used if Noriega's paramilitary organizations regroup. Capt. Leslie Loaiza, head of the operation, said the crime rate is frightening. ``A few months ago, we had an average of five murders a month in the capital,'' he said. ``We now have 30. We had an average of 240 crimes of different types every month. We now have more than 1,000.'' Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon, who also is government and justice minister, said there were no casualties in the operation. Residents in the neighborhood of Curundu said they heard some shooting. Arias said people in the neighborhoods had opened fire on law enforcement officers earlier in the week, wounding two police. Several vehicles heading for the canal area also were fired upon, including some belonging to canal employees. About 12,000 U.S. troops are stationed in Panama, down from a peak of 28,000 during the invasion. Noriega is being held in Miami for trial on drug trafficking and money laundering charges.

DOC.HEAD: Redoubt Belches Plume of Ash and Steam
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano spewed a column of steam seven miles long on a day when three moderate earthquakes jolted the region. Shallow tremors around the volcano late Friday led scientists at the Alaska Volcano Observatory to keep a close watch on the volcano. Scientists predicted another explosion in the next few weeks as Redoubt rebuilds its dome. Accompanied by a rare lightning storm, Redoubt belched steam at 9:51 a.m. AST. The plume carried little ash and drifted mostly to the north and northwest, away from population centers. A quake centered 50 miles beneath Redoubt and measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale hit at 3:24 a.m. Friday, seismologists said. The second quake, at 8:03 a.m., was centered about 170 miles southwest of Fairbanks and registered 5.5 on the Richter scale. A third quake, registering 5.2 and centered 65 miles southwest of Anchorage, struck at 5:11 p.m. It shook office fixtures in Anchorage but caused no apparent damage, authorities said. Redoubt, 115 miles southwest of Anchorage, began erupting in mid-December after slumbering for 25 years. On Feb. 28, an eruption of abrasive ash reached Anchorage, closing schools, forcing precautionary evacuations at an oil terminal on the banks of the Drift River, which flows off the volcano.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Arrested After Coup Attempt; Najib Nearly Killed
DOC.TEXT: State radio urged residents turn in ``traitors,'' and officials said scores of soldiers and employees were detained after a coup attempt in which President Najib narrowly escaped death. Sporadic clashes erupted in the capital Friday, three days after the failed coup, although officials said the situation was generally quiet. The location of the coup leader, Defense Minister Shah Nawaz Tanai, remained unknown. Tanai teamed up with guerrillas from one of the seven Moslem guerrilla groups battling Najib's Soviet-backed government. The government said at least 56 people died and 200 were wounded in Tuesday's coup attempt. It said 25 of the dead and half the wounded were civilians. Damage to the city was severe. It appeared almost every window was broken, indicating heavy bombing by renegade air force pilots. Bombs had blasted several government buildings, including the Presidential Palace. After a 9 p.m. curfew took effect Friday, security forces arrested scores of people in a neighborhood populated mainly by government employees, said a government official who lives in the area. Radio Kabul urged all citizens to turn in ``traitors'' who it said were hiding in houses throughout the capital. A government source said intelligence agents killed a military officer believed loyal to the coup leader and arrested another near the Presidential Palace Friday. One agent from the security service, Khad, was wounded, the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The status of the Shindand air base in southwest Herat province was in question. A government official said the base had yet to pledge loyalty to Najib. Lt. Col. Mohammad Hassan said he was on duty in the Presidential Palace on Tuesday when four clusters of bombs landed on the grounds, killing four soldiers from the presidential guards. A cluster of three small bombs landed yards from Najib's office, he said. Najib, who had just eaten lunch, was at his desk, and the explosion cracked walls and shattered glass, Hassan said. ``We are lucky our leader escaped death,'' he said. The Bakhtar news agency reported two more high-ranking officials had been purged from the Central Committee of the ruling Democratic People's Party of Afghanistan. At least nine top officials have lost their jobs, including five from the Politburo, the most powerful party body. Some of those removed from power were missing and apparently had fled to neighboring Pakistan. Naqib Sameer, a government spokesman, said some had been arrested, but he could not say which ones. Death sentences were widely expected for people found guilty of supporting the attack. Najib established a special tribunal to hear treason cases, and Bakhtar said punishment would be carried out ``in accordance with Afghan tradition.'' Afghanistan accused Pakistan, which supports the anti-Najib guerrillas, of masterminding the coup attempt and said it could not tolerate such interference, Bakhtar said. Tanai, a Marxist hard-liner, was involved in the 1978 coup that brought the Communists to power in Afghanistan. He disagreed with Najib's attempts to make peace with the anti-Communist guerrillas that began fighting the government 11 years ago. Despite this, Tanai this week teamed up with Hezb-i-Islami, one of the most radical of the guerrilla groups. It had split from a fractious coalition with the other six guerrilla groups and its leader, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, backed the coup attempt. Hekmatyar and Tanai appeared to be linked only by their desire to overthrow Najib.

DOC.HEAD: Tibetans Protest Chinese Rule on Anniversary of Failed Uprising
LaserPhoto DEL1
DOC.TEXT: The Dalai Lama, addressing more than 10,000 Tibetan exiles on the 31st anniversary of a failed uprising against Chinese rule, today said Tibetans must maintain the quest for freedom. ``The positive changes that took place in Eastern Europe are a clear indication that truth and desire for peace cannot remain suppressed,'' said the Tibetan temporal and spiritual leader, winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize. The Dalai Lama, revered as a god-king by his followers, fled the Tibetan capital of Lhasa on March 17, 1959, a week after the start of the revolt against China. He made his way across the snow-covered Himalayan mountains to India and eventually to Dharmsala, which serves as the seat of his government-in-exile. ``Being political refugees, we must work towards political freedom,'' he told the crowd gathered outside the Buddhist Thekchen Choeling Temple. ``The Tibetans in Tibet have a greater responsibility for the future of Tibet, especially the youngsters and even those Tibetan cadres working for the Chinese.'' After the ceremony at which the Tibetan flag was raised, thousands of Tibetans and hundreds of foreigners who had traveled here for the anniversary staged an five-mile march through this town in the Himalayan foothills of northern India. In New Delhi, about 1,000 Tibetans burned a Chinese flag and chanted their demands for freedom at India Gate, a soaring stone arch commemmorating Indians who died in military service for their colonial British rulers. Tibet, a rugged and remote enclave high in the Himalayas, was invaded by Communist Chinese troops in 1950. China maintains Tibet has traditionally been part of China, but the Dalai Lama and his followers say Tibet has been independent for centuries.

DOC.HEAD: Post-Dispatch Offers New Contract to Employees
DOC.TEXT: The St. Louis Post-Dispatch submitted a new contract to negotiators representing some 630 newsroom employees who have been on a ``byline strike.'' Post-Dispatch publisher Nicholas G. Penniman IV said Friday the latest proposal was a response to concerns among employees. Most of the newspaper's reporters and columnists have withheld their bylines from stories since Wednesday. ``They said, `Tell us what you need to remain competitive and give us a chance to vote.' And basically, that's what we did,'' Penniman said. ``We listened to our employees and put on the table a very fair offer.'' Herb Goodrick, executive secretary of The Newspaper Guild Local 47, said he would withhold comment until The Guild received a written version. About 630 newsroom employees, including reporters, some editors, photographers and advertising sales staffers, have been working without a contract since the last one expired Feb. 28. The Guild is the largest of 11 unions at the newspaper and one of six seeking a new contract. The Post-Dispatch is owned by Pulitzer Publishing Co. Penniman said the new proposal was for three years and included a 4 percent pay raise for each year and a $600 signing bonus. It also eliminated many demands that Guild members had objected to in the past few months. In October, The Guild rejected a proposal for a five-year contract. It offered the same pay raise but called for drug-testing, which the union said was unclearly defined, and a two-tier wage system that would have meant lower wages for some new employees. The company's subsequent contract offer included no wage increases, a reduction in sick leave and vacation benefits, and a number of other clauses denounced by the union. The paper said that offer was made because of a drop in advertising and competition from the St. Louis Sun, a new daily published by Ingersoll Publications that started up in September.

DOC.HEAD: Three Die As Planes Crash Into Neighborhood
DOC.TEXT: Two small planes collided and crashed into two homes, killing all three people aboard the planes and showering a residential neighborhood with grisly debris. The planes, one trailing an advertising banner and the other piloted by a trainer and his student, collided Friday at an altitude of about 1,000 feet. They crashed into the houses about a block apart in this suburb of Fort Lauderdale. Rought and Mary Ruth Blevins were eating dinner when one of the planes hit their home. ``I saw the man lying in the plane,'' said Mary Ruth Blevins. ``I saw his arm sticking out. The plane was just crushed flat. I was scared to death.'' Next door, Jeannie Brooks, 22, was bringing in groceries and her two small girls. ``It looked like confetti in the sky,'' she said. ``It looked like it was coming down right on top of me. You fear for your kids, just like yourself.'' Miramar police officer Grace Cooper said there were no reports of injuries to anyone on the ground. Fire trucks doused the wreckage to prevent explosions and police sealed off several streets, some littered with debris. The crash involved a Piper Super Cub coming from the southeast and a westbound Cessna 152. National Transportation Safety Board investigator Jeff Kennedy said the Cessna apparently was in a landing pattern for North Perry Airport. He would not release other details. It was the latest of several fatal plane accidents in recent years at North Perry, which serves small planes in the neighboring city of Pembroke Pines. ``North Perry's a very busy training airport,'' said Jack Barker, spokesman for the southern region of the Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta. The Piper pilot was identified as Jeffrey Hairfield, 29, an employee of Aerial Sign Co. who had quit Eastern Airlines after the start of the Machinists strike last year. The names of the Cessna pilot and student were not released. Both were Japanese, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: 77 Students Taken to Hospitals After Gas Leak
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious gas leak sent 110 people to area hospitals after they complained of nausea and vomiting, officials said. Among the victims of Friday's leak were 77 students from Woodland Middle School in nearby Galena Park. Three remained in the hospital overnight, officials said. ``Something made a lot of people sick out there, but we may never find out what it was or where it came from,'' said Acting Fire Capt. Bill Wilcox. ``It just blew through and disappeared.'' Inspectors from the Harris County Pollution Control Bureau were trying to determine whether the leak came from the Houston Ship Channel or some other source. ``We strongly believe it was an ammonia-type gas and released for a short amount of time because it dissipated. Or it could have been a barge going down the channel,'' said Katherine Oates, spokeswoman for the Galena Park Independent School District. About 700 students from the middle school and an elementary school were evacuated, Ms. Oates said. Those not taken to hospitals were transferred briefly to an area high school. Classes at both schools resumed Friday afternoon, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Moscow is menacing us. We hope it's only with words.'' _ Anderus Kubilus, secretary of Sajudis, Lithuania's pro-independence movement.

``How can any act that involves the consent of one party, the participation of a second and the destruction of a third be a purely private matter?'' _ Idaho House Majority Leader Gary Montgomery, urging approval of a bill that would outlaw abortion as a method of birth control.
``American troops will be entering a quagmire more complex than Vietnam.'' _ Kevin Zeese, vice president of the Drug Policy Foundation, on Defense Department efforts in the drug war.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls on Pacific Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain dampened the Pacific Northwest early today, while thunderstorms rumbled over Chicago. A storm nearing the northern Pacific Coast brought rain to Seattle and other parts of Washington early today. Rain was changing to snow in the mountains. Winter storm warnings were posted for the Washington Cascades and Olympics, where up to a foot of snow was expected. Snow advisories were posted in Oregon over the Cascades and Siskiyou mountains. A light rain fell over parts of Kentucky. On Friday, showers and occasional thunderstorms extended over the western portion of the Texas Panhandle into west-central Texas and across southeast Louisiana. Rain dampened Maryland, western New York, western North Carolina, Tennessee and Michigan. Rain also fell over the Pacific Northwest. Parts of the Midwest enjoyed unseasonably warm weather Friday, with record highs of 80 in Dodge City, Kan., and 71 in Ottumwa, Iowa. The high temperature for the nation Friday was 88 degrees at McAllen, Texas. Today's forecast called for rain along the Pacific Coast; snow over Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana and northern California; showers over Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, South Dakota, Minnesota, Nebraska and Iowa; and thunderstorms from Nebraska through Texas. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST: _East: Albany, N.Y. 34 partly cloudy; Atlanta 52 foggy; Boston 33 fair; Charleston, S.C. 60 fair; Chattanooga 49 foggy; Cincinnati 55 foggy; Cleveland 41 foggy; Detroit 38 foggy; Hatteras 52 fair; Jacksonville 57 fair; Key West 70 fair; Knoxville 52 foggy; Macon 56 partly cloudy; Miami 68 fair; New York 40 cloudy; Philadelphia 42 foggy; Pittsburgh 40 foggy; Portland, Maine 25 fair; Richmond 46 fair; Tampa 60 fair; Washington, D.C. 48 foggy. _Central: Birmingham 59 cloudy; Bismarck 25 fair; Chicago 45 thunderstorms; Denver 34 partly cloudy; Des Moines 51 foggy; Indianapolis 56 foggy; Kansas City 67 windy; Little Rock 65 fair; Louisville 57 drizzle; Memphis 64 partly cloudy; Nashville 59 foggy; New Orleans 64 foggy; North Platte 31 fair; Oklahoma City 65 cldy; Omaha 43 foggy; Rapid City 27 fair; St. Louis 63 cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 32 foggy; Sault Ste. Marie 35 foggy; San Antonio 67 cloudy. _West: Albuquerque 49 cloudy; Anchorage 13 fair; Boise 42 partly cloudy; Casper 40 fair; Fairbanks -3 fair; Great Falls 32 fair; Honolulu 73 fair; Las Vegas 52 fair; Los Angeles 53 partly cloudy; Medford 44 rain; Pendleton 49 rain; Phoenix 60 partly cloudy; Portland, Ore. 46 rain; Reno 39 fair; Salt Lake City 41 fair; San Diego 55 cloudy; San Francisco 51 cloudy; Seattle 44 rain; Spokane 39 showery. _International: Calgary 36 cloudy; Montreal 23 fair; Toronto 34 foggy; Winnipeg 30 fair; Mexico City 55 hazy; Acapulco 77 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Planned Executions Of Coup Plotters Draw Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INCORPORATES parts of a0407 PM-Indonesia-Rights, which stands as sidebar. Single names cq for Suharto, Sukarno, Murdiono, Sukatno, Marsudi
DOC.TEXT: Western European countries and human rights organizations protested reported plans to execute six prisoners jailed for decades after being convicted in connection with a Communist coup attempt in 1965. The chief of the armed forces today rejected the criticism as interference in Indonesia's domestic affairs. Lawyer Johannes C. Princen, director of the Institute for the Defense of Human Rights, said the six were taken from their cells in Jakarta's Cipinang Prison on March 5 and their families were notified of the planned executions. The executions, by firing squad, of the men ranging in age from 53 to 70 were believed planned for today or Sunday, Princen said in an interview today. In addition to Princen's organization, protests to the government of President Suharto were lodged by the 12-nation European Community, London-based Amnesty International and the Netherlands government. If the executions are carried out, said Amnesty International, they would bring to 32 the number to go before the firing squad since 1985, compared to four in the previous 10 years. Four former palace guards were executed in mid-February for their part in the aborted coup against the late President Sukarno that began Sept. 30, 1965 and was crushed 48 hours later. The coup was put down within 48 hours by troops led by then-Maj. Gen. Suharto. In the bloodbath that followed, 450,000 to 500,000 people were slain in the name of anti-communism, officials have said. More than half a million more were detained, among them some of the country's best known writers, poets, educators, journalists, film directors and intellectuals. Premier Ruud Lubbers on Friday offered political asylum in the Netherlands for the six. The Netherlands froze a $12.5 million aid package to its former colony after the February executions, but a $90 million assistance program is continuing. ``This is a matter for the attorney general,'' Justice Minister Ismail Saleh told reporters today at the installation of a new Air Force chief of staff. At the same ceremony, Foreign Minister Ali Alatas and State Secretary Murdiono avoided questions by reporters. Those facing execution are Rusland Widjayasastra, 70, Sukatno, 60, Iskandar Subekti, 67, Asep Suryaman, 62, I. Bungkus, 61, and Marsudi, 53 _ all convicted of aiding the coup attempt. The coup attempt was by far the most momentous event in the history of Indonesia, with 147 million people the world's fifth-most most populous nation. Six army generals were killed during the uprising, which was blamed on the Indonesian Communist Party. When calm was restored in 1966, Sukarno relinquished executive power to Suharto and the military, a situation that prevails 24 years later. Indonesia, once the Dutch East Indies, gained independence in 1949 after four years of fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Racetrack Reverend Says Backstretch Ban Is Discrimination
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: A racetrack reverend who has performed weddings in the winner's circle says he has been barred from the backstretch at Arlington International Racecourse for backing a lawsuit filed by members of his flock. The Rev. Dave Krueckeberg, 46, has made it his mission for the last two decades to minister to the grooms, hotwalkers, feed workers and their families at Chicago-area race tracks. But officials at Arlington International told him last July he was no longer allowed on the grounds, he said, and security guards escorted him off the premises just as he was beginning a weekly service. An attorney for the track said Friday that Arlington had hired a chaplain trained in racetrack ministry. Krueckeberg is welcome as a guest preacher, said the attorney, Richard Burke. But Krueckeberg's complaint to the Illinois Department of Human Rights contends he is being discriminated against because he signed an affidavit against the track three weeks before he was escorted off the property. The affidavit supported a lawsuit by track workers who are trying to overturn a management ban on families with children in the apartments on Arlington's backstretch. The migrant workers say they cannot afford to live anywhere else, but management contends it is a dangerous area for children. ``I feel like a shepherd who has been separated from his flock,'' the Lutheran minister said in a recent interview. ``I love the people, and I'm in a relationship with them. I'm baptizing the children of children I baptized.'' Burke said the track opted for hiring a chaplain from the Race Track Chaplaincy of America, a nationwide organization based in New Jersey. The track's attorney said such chaplains receive special training in helping racetrack workers, and travel with the workers from state to state. ``It had nothing to do with Rev. Krueckeberg. We have no quarrel with him,'' Burke said in a telephone interview Friday. ``It's just that we were attempting to handle the problem of the needs of the track on a professional basis.'' Krueckeberg's Lawyer, Alan Chen of the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois, said the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod clergyman ``had been ministering to people on the backstretch at Arlington Park for 20 years, without any problem.'' Krueckeberg, who wears boots, a flannel shirt and a ski cap on the job, has baptized babies in trailers and performed weddings in the winner's circle. Whatever the outcome of Krueckeberg's complaint, which the two sides are negotiating to try to settle, or the workers' lawsuit, Krueckeberg will continue to minister at Hawthorne Race Course in Stickney, Balmoral Park in Crete and at Sportsman's Park in suburban Cicero. Charles Bidwill Jr., president of Sportsman's, said Friday that Krueckeberg approached him 20 years ago and told him what he hoped to accomplish at the track. ``All he wanted to do was preach the word of God to these people and help wherever he could,'' said Bidwill. ``He's helped a lot of people, and he's done a lot of good.''

DOC.HEAD: 10 Die When Giant Statue of Buddha Slides Off Barge
DOC.TEXT: At least 10 people drowned today when a mammoth stone statue of Lord Buddha slid off a barge in a lake at the central Indian city of Hyderabad, United News of India said. About 50 people were aboard the barge at the time of the accident, which the news agency said. Many of them managed to swim to shore, about 300 feet away, it added. United News quoted witnesses and a survivor as saying the giant statue slid off its trailer and the barge broke up. The news agency quoted Hyderabad Police Commissioner Prabhakar Rao as saying some bodies may have been trapped under the 350-ton red granite statue, which sank in 80 feet of water in Hussain Sagar Lake. Navy divers were dispatched to Hyderabad, 745 miles southeast of New Delhi, to assist in search and salvage operations. The barge was being towed to a rock in the center of the lake, where the statue was to be installed. Those aboard were construction company workers in charge of moving the statue. About 130 sculptors worked on the statue, which cost $3.5 million to make, United News said. It was to have been unveiled at a ceremony May 9 as part of a beautification project at the lake. Hyderabad, the capital of Andhra Pradesh state, was a major Buddhist center in the time of King Ashoka in the 3rd century B.C. before the Hindu and Moslem conquests.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Supreme Court Upholds Drug Conviction Of Ferraro's Son
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court upheld the drug conviction of John Zaccaro Jr., son of 1984 vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro. Zaccaro's attorney, Kathleen Sullivan, said the court's decision Friday showed it didn't realize the importance of protecting the home from undercover searches. Zaccaro, then a student at Middlebury College, was arrested Feb. 20, 1986, at his Middlebury home after selling $25 worth of cocaine to an undercover state police officer. Police searched Zaccaro's home and car before making the arrest. In a unanimous decision, the court rejected defense arguments that the undercover operation was illegal or that Zaccaro was the victim of selective prosecution because of his mother's fame. Zaccaro, convicted in 1988, was sentenced to one to five years in prison, but was permitted to serve three months under house arrest. The program he was sentenced under came under fire when it was learned that he served his time in a $1,500-a-month Burlington apartment with maid service. Zaccaro also completed more than 500 hours of community service by working at the King Street Youth Center, in a program for troubled youths.

DOC.HEAD: Hammond Sentenced to Death for Julie Love's Murder
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted in a murder that was cited by the group claiming responsibility for two deadly mail bombs was sentenced to die in the electric chair. Emmanuel Hammond, 24, was sentenced Friday by the jury that had convicted him Wednesday of the kidnapping, murder and armed robbery of Julie Love, a 27-year-old Atlanta preschool fitness teacher. A racist letter from a group claiming responsibility for the pre-Christmas mail bomb deaths of Judge Robert Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and Savannah lawyer Robert Robinson said the attacks were motivated by outrage over Miss Love's killing. Hammond is black. Love was white. Miss Love's father, Jerry Love; her stepmother; and her fiance were in the courtroom when the sentence was announced. ``I'm very grateful to the jury, the prosecutor and the judge for what they did, and I feel that justice was done,'' Love said. ``It's a victory of sorts, but a very shallow victory.'' The victim's fiance, Mark Kaplan, said, ``An impartial jury, black, white, male and female, made a decision that sent out a strong signal _ that society is not going to put up with this type of savage behavior.'' The judge ordered the execution to take place next month, but the conviction and sentence automatically will be appealed. Miss Love disappeared in July 1988. Her body was found in a wooded dumping ground 13 months later. She had been shot in the head. Hammond's co-defendant and cousin, W. Maurice Porter, has pleaded guilty to murder, armed robbery and rape in the killing. He has not been sentenced.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Protesters Attack Police For Fifth Night
DOC.TEXT: Tax protesters burned an effigy of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and pelted police with bricks and paint bombs in a fifth straight night of violence against new higher tax bills. Ten officers were injured and 37 people arrested in the violent confrontations that ended early today in Brixton in the south London borough of Lambeth, Scotland Yard said. The clashes were the latest in a popular revolt against the new community charge, dubbed the poll tax by opponents, which takes effect in England and Wales on April 1. Unlike income tax, or the property tax it replaces, it must be paid by everyone over the age of 18 regardless of their income or earnings. In recent opinion polls, Mrs. Thatcher's party has plunged to its lowest level in a decade of rule, and the tax is considered a leading factor. The Chartered Institute of Public Finance Accountants says the average household paying about $830 under the current local property tax system will pay about $1,110 under the new tax. Friday night's confrontation started as a carnival-type protest outside Lambeth town hall, where Lambeth Council was meeting to discuss an individual community charge of $900, which would be one of the highest in Britain. It ended without a rate being set. During the meeting, the crowd swelled to about 2,000 and an effigy of Mrs. Thatcher was burned, but police described the mood as good-natured. Later, however, groups of protesters broke away and moved into nearby Brixton, throwing eggs, cans, bottles and paint-filled balloons at police, stoning a police van, and overturning a police car, trapping an officer inside. Scotland Yard said he suffered a concussion and broken jaw. A group of about 200 demonstrators continued throwing objects at police armed with riot shields as well as at passing civilian cars, Scotland Yard said. Police also came under attack from youths throwing objects from a pedestrian overpass in a public housing project. The violence ended shortly after midnight, Scotland Yard said. Anger at the new tax has sparked protests across the country, many turning violent. Mrs. Thatcher on Friday blamed leftist militants for the protests. ``Any conduct intimidating or violent is absolutely contradictory to democracy,'' she said. Labor leader Neil Kinnock denounced 28 Labor lawmakers who advocate non-payment of the new tax as ``toytown revolutionaries'' who were playing into the government's hands. He told the Scottish Labor Party's conference that a Labor government would abolish the poll tax, which he dubbed ``Maggie's tax,'' and replace it with a tax based on property and the ability to pay. But he urged that opposition supporters pay it and stay within the law. The community charge varies widely from area to area. London's Conservative-controlled Wandsworth Council set a charge of $240 per adult for the year. London's Labor-controlled Haringay Council on Friday set a charge of $975 per adult.

DOC.HEAD: Mom: Son Set Afire During Game of `Chicken'
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager was doused with gasoline as he slept and set ablaze by two friends apparently playing ``chicken.'' Shaun Woods, 15, suffered first- and second-degree burns over his chest and neck and was listed in critical condition Friday night at the Erie County Medical Center's burn unit, hospital officials said. The teen-ager's mother, Margaret Woods, said Shaun will need extensive skin grafting. Woods said two boys _ one age 13 and the other age 17 _ poured gasoline on Shaun as he slept Thursday night and then tossed a match in his direction. ``My son and two other boys he has been associated with have been playing this stupid game lately,'' Mrs. Wood said. ``It's like a game of chicken. If they fall asleep, they throw a lighted match at each other.'' Shaun was at one of the boys' home when the incident occurred. There were no adults in the home at the time, Mrs. Woods said. No arrests have been made and police were not releasing the boys' names. Mrs. Wood said she would press charges. The incident was the second of its kind reported this week. David Opont, 12, was set on fire on Wednesday by a 13-year-old in his New York City neighborhood. The boy underwent a four-hour operation Friday to graft a thin layer of skin from his lower legs onto his badly burned arms. Hospital officials said he faces numerous other operations.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Skirmish Despite Aoun's Conciliatory Move
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces skirmished with machine guns in east Beirut overnight, despite Gen. Michel Aoun's declared readiness to negotiate peace. Police today said four people were wounded. The command of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia blamed the violations of the week-old cease-fire on Aoun's troops and demanded ``strict measures to prevent such attempts that jeopardize security.'' Aoun's command said the militia fired four mortar rounds into territories held by the general's 19,000 troops in east Beirut. A police spokesman, who requested anonymity in line with regulations, said the four casualties were wounded in militia-controlled districts. By police count, 750 people have been killed and 2,093 wounded since Jan. 30, when the inconclusive showdown began for mastery of the 310-square-mile enclave. The overnight exchanges, the fiercest since a mediation committee called a cease-fire March 3, came after Aoun, in an unexpected conciliatory move, called for dialogue with Geagea as well as with the various other Moslem and leftist leaders to end the nation's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun on Friday also dropped his outright rejection of an Arab league-brokered peace plan worked out by Lebanese legislators in the Saudi Arabian resort of Taif last fall. However, the 54-year-old general proposed that the plan be amended, calling for a ``Taif accord No. 2.'' Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, rejected Aoun's proposal to amend the peace accord, declaring: ``we adhere to the Taif agreement both in letter and spirit.'' Voice of the People Radio, which is close to Hoss' government, said Aoun was ``maneuvering and stalling for time.'' The Taif accord called for a redistribution of political power in Lebanon, doing away with Christian domination and dividing power equally between Moslems and Christians. Aoun earlier had rejected the pact because it did not provide for the immediate withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops, in Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate. Aoun also has ignored orders by President Elias Hrawi to step down as army commander and turn over the Presidential Palace. The intra-Christian showdown has forced one-fourth of the enclave's 1 million population to evacuate and seek refuge in safer areas. The police spokesman said the estimated 250,000 evacuees who had fled the Christian enclave due to the clashes ``do not seem to trust the cease-fire.'' ``Some of the evacuees return to the enclave early in the day to check on their damaged property, but leave before dark,'' the spokesman said. A mediation committee is meeting separately with Aoun and Geagea in an effort to consolidate the cease-fire and form a ``national authority'' grouping representatives of the warring factions and independent figures to work out a political settlement to the intra-Christian conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Explode In Capital On Eve of Inauguration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with explosions; picks up 3rd pvs, `Pinochet, however...'
DOC.TEXT: At least 10 bombs exploded near the U.S. Consulate, the state-run communications company, the home of an army colonel and other buildings in the capital, police said today. One person was wounded. There was no claim of responsibility in the attacks Friday night, and police did not say whether they believed the attacks were connected to Sunday's inauguration of a civilian president after 16 years of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's military rule. Pinochet will turn over government to President-elect Patricio Aylwin. The blasts, within 45 minutes of each other, damaged some of the buildings, police said. The wounded man, a night maintenance worker, was hurt in a blast in a park near downtown about 200 feet away from the U.S. Consulate. Bombs also went off at a courthouse in Santiago, at a building belonging to the state National Communications Co., another one at a Mormon church in a working-class neighborhood in the south. Others exploded off near the house of an army colonel who was not identified, at a public school, at a government tourist office, at a suburban city hall, and in front of two private businesses. In an emotional farewell, Pinochet on Friday pinned ``Mission Accomplished'' medals on his Cabinet ministers and said his 16 -year-old military government restored order. The general said he called the final Cabinet meeting Friday to ``reaffirm the absolute peace of mind that we should feel for having fully accomplished our mission.'' Pinochet, however, has said he remain commander of the military despite Aylwin's call for him to hand over control. In a low voice charged with emotion, Pinochet said his right-wing military government was leaving behind ``a society that is free, at peace and orderly.'' Pinochet presented each minister with a ``Mission Accomplished'' medal. The award was recently minted by the government and Pinochet received the first medal. International human rights organizations have repeatedly criticized the government for grave human rights abuses since Pinochet led the Sept. 11, 1973, coup that toppled elected President Salvador Allende. Also Friday, in a separate ceremony to decorate the new commander of the navy, Pinochet said the armed forces will remain strong and united after he gives up power. ``We can never be defeated, no matter how treacherous the actions of those who try to destroy us,'' he said. He did not elaborate, but in other recent speeches Pinochet and other military leaders have warned of alleged efforts by anti-Pinochet political groups to infiltrate and destroy the armed forces. Under a 1980 constitution written by his administration, Pinochet, 74, cannot be replaced for eight years as commander of the powerful 60,000-member army. The Constitution also makes the armed forces the ``guarantor'' of Chile's internal security and legal framework. Since the Dec. 14 national elections, Pinochet has pushed through legislation that limits the president's power to promote or retire military officers and restricts the civil leadership's role in making military appointments. Aylwin, a 71-year-old lawyer and veteran politician, is backed by a coalition of leftist and centrist parties that battled for an end to Pinochet's long reign. In the elections he won 55 percent of the vote, compared with 29 percent for a pro-Pinochet candidate. On Friday, preparations for Aylwin's weekend inauguration were in full swing. In the Pacific port city of Valparaiso, workers were busily outfitting the new congressional palace, still under construction, where the ceremony is to take place. Vice President Dan Quayle will represent the United States at the inauguration and will stay at the U.S. ambassador's residence. In Santiago, the presidential palace was nearly empty, as members of Pinochet's administration vacated their offices and military officials moved back to army facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Inspection Finds Improperly Installed Pins
DOC.TEXT: The motorman who operated a subway train that derailed and killed three people tested postive for cocaine, and mechanics inspected cars to make sure their motors are installed correctly. John K. Lauber of the National Transportation Safety Board on Friday said urine tests uncovered traces of cocaine in the motorman's system. Louis Gambaccini, general manager of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, said the motorman would be suspended as of Monday. No other details about the employee, including his name, were released. Lauber said inspectors examined 76 motors on 19 cars Friday. They found 27 cotter pins, which help hold the motors in place underneath the cars, installed improperly. Lauber said the cotter pins are designed to slip through a nut and the bolt the nut is screwed onto. The improperly fitted cotter pins were turned down too far on the bolts, failing to lock the nuts. ``That is not the proper way of securing that mechanism,'' he said. The NTSB recommended that the transit authority immediately inspect the motors on all 240 subway cars. Gambaccini said the recommendation would be carried out. Investigators believe a motor on a car came loose Wednesday, hit a switch and sent half of a six-car train onto another set of tracks. The fourth car smashed into steel support beams, killing three passengers and trapping survivors. Of 94 injured, 10 remained hospitalized Friday, all in good or satisfactory condition, hospital officials said. Within three hours of the accident, the train conductor and motorman underwent tests for alcohol and drugs, Lauber said. Both tested negative for alcohol use. A urine test on the conductor for other drugs also was negative. Investigators have not determined whether cocaine played a role in the accident, he said. ``We have no idea when the cocaine was ingested, at what time and whether or not it had an effect or was a factor in this accident,'' Lauber said. That question, he said, would receive ``further analysis.'' Lauber declined to comment on whether the worker had been disciplined for or had tested positive for drug use in the past, saying the investigation was continuing. Gambaccini said the transportation authority has initiated a comprehensive drug-testing program. ``It is our understanding that SEPTA is only one of two of the larger urban transit authorities that conducts random drug testing,'' he said. He also insisted Philadelphia's rail system was safe. ``Transportation in all modes has accidents,'' he said. ``I believe that it is safe. This is the single, most tragic accident in the history of'' the system. The accident was the worst since the Market-Frankford Line began operation 21 years ago. A 37-block stretch of that line remained closed Friday. Service was expected to resume Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Paper Says U.S. Raising Hostage Issue For Its Own Purposes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Fadlallah, Peggy Say; picks up 6th pvs, `Rafsanjani said...'
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian newspaper today said a ``media blitz'' on U.S. hostages in Lebanon was designed in part to prepare the American public for a military mission to try to free the captives. In Beirut, a key Shiite Moslem leader, Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, said of the hostages: ``We believe there are encouraging elements regarding readiness to deal with this issue.'' Fadlallah, spiritual leader of the pro-Iran Hezbollah, or Party of God, was answering a question from the newspaper al-Liwa if he thought the hostages would be released in 1990. On Feb. 23, after returning from a trip to Iran, Fadlallah had called for ``realistic and humanitarian means to free the hostages.'' Hezbollah is believed to be an umbrella for groups holding some of the 18 Western hostages. The newspaper Kayhan International, in an editorial, said a U.S. military rescue mission, involving Israel, would ``end the so-called crisis with the death of at least the American hostages.'' The newspaper cited no source or facts to back its assertions. Eight American hostages are among the 18 Westerners being held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, called the Iranian newspaper report ``rather bizarre.'' ``There's so much flying around out there, that one doesn't know what to put stock in,'' said Mrs. Say, who recently completed a trip to Europe and the Middle East to discuss the hostage issue with political leaders. But she added: ``I think the `media blitz' remark is well founded because the media have built themselves into a frenzy that something will happen by March 16, and neither I nor anybody else can do anything to dissuade them.'' Kayhan International, which is often at variance with Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, said: ``If the U.S. and Israel embark on military adventurism, the hostages will in fact be a pretext for crippling the Islamic movement.'' Rafsanjani said earlier this week that the hostage issue was nearing solution, and recent editorials in the Tehran Times have also said the hostages were near release. The Iranian president, attempting to consolidate his hold on power, is opposed by radicals who disagree with his wish to end Iran's isolation and gain Western participation in rebuilding the country after an eight-year war with Iraq. Kayhan's editorial today said said other reasons for the current media campaign in the U.S. press is to evaluate the reaction of Iranian officials and to use the humanitarian aspect to put pressure on Iran. It said another reason for the U.S. ``hostage propaganda'' was aimed at positioning American firms to take part in rebuilding Iran. ``That is why (America) is looking red-eyed and sullen at the lively competition being waged by Italians, Germans, Russians and Japanese,'' Kayhan said. The editorial was reported by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia. It said recent stories on the hostages were ``a media blitz designed to create activity and certain conditions that at present are non-existant,'' Kayhan said without elaborating. Kayhan mentioned the February incident in which Bush was persuaded to talk to someone he thought was Rafsanjani but was not. The incident was first reported Thursday. It called the Bush attempt at diplomacy ``callow.'' In a Friday sermon, Rafsanjani said the phone hoax showed the ``confusion of leaders inside the White House.'' He said that although the United States needs to talk to Iran, Iran is not ready to talk to the United States. Iran denies any connection with the kidnappings but has said it would use its influence for their release if the United States fulfilled certain conditions such as freeing frozen Iranian assets.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Adbucted Intelligence Officers Freed
DOC.TEXT: Moslem separatists in Kashmir freed five police intelligence officers today after the government promised ``strong action'' if the hostages were not released, state Gov. Jagmohan said. The governor said the five men, abducted at gunpoint from their jeep on Friday night, were released early today after government loudspeakers blared all-night warnings. Jagmohan said they had not been harmed. The kidnappings were the latest example of unrest that has occurred since a Jan. 20 crackdown on the separatist movement. At 173 people have died, mostly Moslem separatists killed in clashes with federal security troops. ``Our approach of firmness in dealing with the terrorists worked,'' Jagmohan said of the releases. He said the five men, members of the Jammu-Kashmir state police intelligence branch, reappeared without warning in the same area where they were abducted. No reponsibility claims or demands were made on behalf of the abductors. The five officers had been in a jeep patrolling a congested residential area in the heart of Srinagar, core of the movement demanding mostly Moslem Kashmir's independence from predominantly Hindu India. A curfew designed to confine people indoors was in effect at the time of the abduction, but suddenly the intelligence officers' jeep was surrounded by a crowd, Jagmohan said. He said three young men took the officers from the jeep at gunpoint and set fire to the vehicle. ``Had we succumbed to their pressure, we would have surrendered to the terrorists, but this time we did not,'' said Jagmohan, who uses only one name. He was referring to December's abduction of the daughter of the federal home minister. The young woman, a Srinagar medical student who was taken from a van by armed men, was freed unharmed when the government bowed to the kidnappers' demands and released five detained members of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front. Jagmohan, a Hindu with a reputation as a tough administrator, was appointed governor of Jammu-Kashmir state on Jan. 18. The curfew in Srinagar was lifted between 5 a.m. and 10 a.m. today for the first time in 48 hours. An around-the-clock curfew had been in effect from midday Thursday and throughout Friday while a high-powered delegation from New Delhi, including ex-Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, visited Srinagar to assess the situation. On Friday, the government said it had opened indirect talks with the militants in an effort to resolve escalating violence and demands for independence.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets To Move Nuclear Test Site, Cut Back On Explosions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last graf, The Soviet, to CORRECT Baltic to Barents and place north of Arctic Circle
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will cut back on underground nuclear testing and move the site for the explosions from Asia to an island inside the Arctic Circle, says a report published today. The move to the Arctic location will force the Soviets to conduct fewer tests and will hamper development of weapons that could be used against the United States, The Washington Post reported in today's editions. The decision came after strong political pressure inside the Soviet Union, The Post said, citing unidentified Soviet and U.S. sources. Col. Gen. Vladmir Gerasimov was reported as telling committees of the Supreme Soviet, the national legislature, that the defense ministry plans to conduct 27 more tests at the Semipalatinsk site in south-central Asia before closing it in 1993. That rate is roughly 40 percent below the current pace of testing. U.S. officials were quoted as saying the Soviet announcement came as no surprise and added that it still may not curb pressure within that country for a complete moratorium on underground nuclear explosions. The Soviet test site will be moved to Novaya Zemlya, a large island in the Barents Sea within the Arctic Circle, the newspaper said. The inhospitable surroundings will make work difficult and will further slow testing, U.S. officials told the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Dead in New Unrest, Widespread Arrests Reported
DOC.TEXT: Police said today that at least 10 people were killed in factional clashes, and authorities reportedly arrested more than 70 suspects in nationwide raids to curb growing violent unrest. Meanwhile, police firing shotguns, tear gas and rubber bullets clashed with protesters in several parts of the country, but no serious injuries were reported, a police report said. The black-on-black factional fighting came amid the worst violence in South Africa since the mid-1980s. More than 200 people have died in the past month. The state-run South African Broadcasting Corporation reported today that more than 70 people were detained nationwide to try to halt the violence. The report gave no other details. In the factional fighting overnight, nine protesters died and one police officer was killed by gunmen, the police report said. The worst violence in recent days was in the black township of Kathlehong outside Johannesburg, where police reported finding three more bodies today, bringing the death toll in the devastated township during the past week to at least 22, with scores injured. A fight between rival taxi companies in the township exploded into a major factional fight, and hundreds of residents have fled the area. The South African Police sent extra units into the area to protect residents and halt the fighting, police said. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told Parliament on Friday that the government was determined to end unrest and was prepared to use its extensive powers under the 3{-year-old state of emergency to quell the violence. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party blamed the government for the violence. Opposition leaders said President F.W. de Klerk's decision to legalize the African National Congress and other opposition groups encouraged radicals to attempt to seize power. De Klerk legalized the ANC last month to try and clear the way for talks on ending white minority rule and sharing political power with the black majority. The government has charged that some anti-apartheid groups are behind the outbreak of violence in South Africa and some tribal homelands because they are not ready to participate in negotiations with the white government. But ANC leader Walter Sisulu said Friday that the government was reverting ``to the old approach of looking for scapegoats and hidden `instigators.''' ``The primary reason for the unrest, conflict and confrontation has always been the poverty and violence caused by apartheid,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinians Killed, Clashes in Jerusalem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 5th, `Israeli radio...' to UPDATE with Kollek's remarks, MOVE up background. Pickup 6th, `Both President...' TRIMS.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli police shot and killed two Palestinians at stone-throwing protests in a refugee camp in Arab east Jerusalem, Arab reports said, prompting other skirmishes and a strike today. The shootings Friday night and early today and were among the worst in Jerusalem during the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Police confirmed one dead and two wounded, saying in a statement that the incidents are being investigated. Arab and U.N. reports said two people were killed. The trouble occurred after Israeli leaders repeated their claim to the Arab sector of Jerusalem despite recent U.S. statements that the status of the land was in dispute and should be resolved by negotiation. Israel radio linked the violence to the U.S.-Israeli dispute over the status of Jerusalem. It said camp residents ``were encouraged by U.S. statements.'' Jerusalem mayor Teddy Kollek also linked the violence to the dispute, and noted ``the impatience of radical elements in east Jerusalem with the slowness and uncertainty of the Israeli government in advancing the peace process.'' Israel captured the Gaza Strip from Egypt and the West Bank and east Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. It has since annexed east Jerusalem, home to 140,000 Palestinians, and has been building Jewish neighborhoods around the Arab enclave to strengthen its hold on the land. Both President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III have said in the past 10 days that Israel's policy of settling Jews in the occupied lands is an impediment to peace. The incidents apparently began Friday night when Palestinians in the Shufat refugee camp, the only camp within Jerusalem's city limits, tried to barricade entrances and threw stones at police, Arab reports said. The reports said stones also were thrown at passing Israeli cars on a nearby highway, damaging 14 vehicles. Police said only that ``there was damage to a number of vehicles.'' Arab reports said police opened fire in Shufat on Friday night and again today to quell stone-throwing protesters. Residents of the camp identified the victims as Mahmud Fawzi Abu Khalife, 21, who was shot in the stomach, and Sufian Mohammed Abdullah Khalil, 25, who was hit with a bullet in the head. Officials with the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, which oversees aid programs for the refugees, confirmed both deaths and said at least two other Palestinians were wounded, one critically. As word of the deaths spread, scattered stone-throwing clashes broke out this morning in east Jerusalem and merchants shuttered their stores in protest at the deaths. Barricades were put up by camp residents again this morning, the Arab reports said. Students were seen blocking city streets with boulders and overturned trash cans and hurling stones at police. Passing cars and police squads also were stoned, and several windows were reported broken, merchants said. Tear gas was used to disperse demonstrators outside at least two east Jerusalem schools. After the shooting today, paramilitary border police ordered residents to remain in their homes and rounded up hundreds of young Palestinians in a schoolyard for questioning. Reporters were blocked from entering the camp and could see some of the police activity from the camp entrances. The deaths raised to 661 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the uprising, which began in December 1987. A total of 194 other Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Forty-three Israelis also have been killed. The toll in Jerusalem rose to at least 10 dead, including six Palestinians and four Israelis.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement on Total Withdrawal of Troops Signed
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and Hungary today signed an agreement calling for all Red Army troops to be withdrawn from Hungarian territory by the middle of next year, Hungarian radio reported. The pullout will begin Monday, according to the agreement signed in Moscow by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his Hungarian counterpart, Gyula Horn, the report said. Hungary is the second Warsaw Pact country to negotiate a complete withdrawal of Soviet troops. Prague and Moscow reached an agreement last month on the removal of 73,500 Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia. The pullout there began Feb. 26. Such pullouts were requested after pro-democracy revolutions swept Communists from power across Eastern Europe late last year and early this year. The signing of the Hungarian-Soviet agreement came just one day after negotiations were completed on its terms and a timetable for the withdrawal. There had been initial disagreement over the date for the pullout to be completed, but the two sides finally agreed that all troops and equipment should be withdrawn by June 30, 1991. That's the same date that the withdrawal from Czechoslovakia is to be finished. The Soviets reportedly had wanted the Hungarian withdrawal to be completed on Aug. 31, 1991, to give them more time for dismantling military stockpiles but agreed to the earlier date sought by the Hungarians. There are 49,700 Soviet soldiers in Hungary as well as 27,146 combat vehicles, including 860 tanks and 1,500 armored personnel carriers, accoriding to Hungarian military officials. According to the Hungarian radio report, two-thirds of the withdrawal of Soviet forces and equipment is to be completed by the end of this year. Horn traveled to Moscow today. The agreement was initialed Friday by the heads of the two delegations negotiating the terms of the withdrawal. Attending the final round of talks that ended in Moscow on Friday were three Hungarian observers representing opposition parties competing in national elections March 25. They are to be the first free, multiparty elections since the Communists consolidated power in 1948.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Communist's Presidency Disputed On Eve of Independence Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Sajudis wanting to replace republic's Communist president. Pickup 5th, `The resolution...'; SUBS grafs 19-20, `With the...' with 2 grafs to CONFORM and ADD details on secession process.
DOC.TEXT: Georgia has become the fourth Soviet republic to condemn its annexation to the Soviet Union, calling the move ``an international crime'' and demanding talks to secure independence, a local news agency reported. In Lithuania, meanwhile, activists preparing for an expected declaration of independence said the powerful Sajudis movement wants to replace the republic's Communist president, who could stand in the way of immediate secession. Lithuania would be the first of the Soviet Union's 15 republics to declare independence and would confront President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with one of the worst crises in five years of governing. The Soviet Parliament is to vote Monday on his proposal to increase presidential power over unruly republics. All three Baltic republics _ Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania _ have condemned the Soviet annexation of their lands a half century ago and have strong pro-independence movements. Sajudis, the pro-independence popular movement that dominates Lithuanian politics, will probably back one of its three leading figures for president of the republic, activists said as tonight's legislative session neared. Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas backs independence and his Communist Party broke away from the national party in December. But Sajudis activist Haroldas Subachius said the group decided it would be unfitting for him to be reelected because the Communists lost their majority in elections last month. Many Sajudis members also fear Brazauskas is ``not firm enough'' in his support for independence, Subachius said. As chairman of the republic's 141-seat Supreme Soviet, Brazauskas conceivably could stave off immediate confrontation with the Kremlin by delaying debate on the secession issue, which is expected to begin Sunday. The resolution by the Georgian Supreme Soviet legislature, quoted by the Independent News Agency of Georgia, ``denounces the occupation and annexation of Georgia by Soviet Russia and considers it to be an international crime.'' It calls the entrance of troops ``a military interference, intervention and occupation with the aim of overthrowing the existing political order'' and says: ``It is necessary to start talks on restoration of an independent state of Georgia.'' The official news agency Tass, in a four-sentence report on the resolution, said nothing about the sections condemning the Red Army's occupation of Georgia in Feb. 1921 and the subsequent treaties that made Georgia part of the Soviet Union. The mountainous Caucasus republic, the birthplace of former Soviet ruler Josef Stalin, has 5 million residents. It first became a part of the Russian empire in the early 1800s. It was briefly independent again after the Bolshevik revolution. It has long had an active independence movement. In April, Soviet troops armed with gas and sharpened shovels killed 19 pro-independence demonstrators while chasing them off the main street of Georgia's capital Tbilisi. The Georgian resolution calls ``inadmissible'' Gorbachev's proposal for the president to declare a state of emergency and martial law. The declaration says that would ``introduce an authoritarian presidential rule, which may be interpreted as the president's right to remove organs of power in a union republic and thus to completely eliminate the republic's sovereignty.'' The resolution says the republic's deputies' participation in approving the draft law also would be ``inadmissible.'' Gorbachev hopes to win approval of the constitutional amendment in Monday's special session of the Congress of People's Deputies, despite progressives' complaints that the draft would give him ``dictatorial'' powers. The resolution says presidential measures taken to protect the nation's territorial unity ``should not conflict with the realization of a republic's right to secede from the USSR.'' Lithuania moved up its vote on declaring independence to Sunday precisely because activists fear Gorbachev will use his new powers to forcibly prevent them from splitting from the Soviet Union. Lithuania's newly elected lawmakers on Friday pressed on toward a showdown with Moscow, discussing how to take the reins of power after a declaration of independence. ``Moscow is menacing us. We hope it's only with words,'' said Anderus Kubilus, secretary of Sajudis, Lithuania's pro-independence movement. ``We don't think there will be an acute economic blockade. It wouldn't be profitable for them, either economically or in terms of international opinion. But we don't know.'' In comments reported Wednesday by official Radio Vilnius, Gorbachev appeared to accept Lithuania's right to secede, but cautioned that the once-independent state would have to pay $34 billion in compensation for factories built and money invested during a half-century of Soviet rule. The republic's parliament will be asked to reaffirm an act first passed on Feb. 16, 1918 declaring the state independent. Lawmakers already have declared illegal Lithuania's incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940 under a secret Nazi-Soviet pact. Lawmakers also will be asked to restore the 1938 constitution that was swept away by Josef Stalin's Kremlin in favor of a Soviet-style law.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Embattled Haiti Military Ruler Expected to Step Down
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with reports today Avril to leave; Edits to trim; No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A Western ambassador and a high-ranking army source said today that Haiti's ruler, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, will step down in the face of violent anti-government demonstrations. Avril was to resign today and hand over power to the army chief who will preside over a transition to civilian rule, the sources said on condition of anonymity. The Western ambassador said Avril will relinquish power to Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army's commander-in-chief. Abraham, in turn, will have 72 hours to hand over the government to a civilian council headed by a Supreme Court justice, the ambassador said. The Army High Command source said Avril would remain in Haiti after stepping down and a 48-hour curfew would be imposed to prevent disorder. The prediction came after five days of anti-government demonstrations and calls by an opposition coalition that Avril relinquish power. The army source said the main problem facing the High Command was how to handle possible resistance among the 1,000-member Presidential Guard, many of whom are hostile to the idea of democratic government. A palace source said, however, that the guards would not resist the transfer of power. The source also spoke on condition of anonymity. If Avril steps down, it will be the fifth change in leadership in Haiti since 1986, when President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled the impoverished country during widespread protests, ending a 29-year family dictatorship. The idea of setting up a civilian council headed by the Supreme Court's vice president, Gabriel Volcy, was proposed last week by the Unity Assembly, an umbrella group of 11 opposition political parties and a civic organization. The council is to prepare for legitimate elections. On Friday night, the Unity Assembly issued a statement calling for an ``unlimited total paralysis of the country'' if Avril didn't resign by Monday. Also Friday, troops fired on 250 student demonstrators in Port-au-Prince, and three protesters were reported wounded. State television said Avril met with his Army High Command and with church leaders about ``bringing peace'' to Haiti. A U.S. Embassy diplomat said the United States was not involved in negotiations with Avril but added without elaboration that the talks were expected to be successful. ``We are keeping in touch with them but we are in no way involved with negotiations. We are not putting together a deal. It is up to Haitians to decide if there's to be a change in government,'' the diplomat said on condition of anonymity. Avril, who came to power in a soldiers' revolt in September 1988, promised political reform and elections after taking power, but he exiled seven opposition activists and arrested scores of people in a crackdown in January. Avril scheduled general elections this year, but most parties refuse to participate, saying they don't trust him to give up power. The latest round of mass protests in Haiti began Monday after troops killed an 11-year-old girl studying on her porch. On Friday, witnesses and radio reports said soldiers opened fire on about 250 students protesting at the state university, wounding three. Three people were killed Thursday, including a soldier beat to death by an angry mob. Demonstrations also broke out Friday in the outskirts of Port-au-Prince and continued until sundown with protesters putting up flaming tire barricades and soldiers shooting in the air to break up crowds. In the heart of Port-au-Prince, groups of heavily armed soldiers guarded the National Palace and two manned anti-aircraft guns were positioned on the palace's front lawn. The capital of 1 million, usually teeming with people on weekend nights, was deserted Friday night and early today. The remnants of smoldering tire barricades remained in many intersections and there was sporadic gunfire heard around the palace.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Sentenced to Death For Alleged Espionage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Iraqi also sentenced, paper's reaction, details. Pickup 10th pvs, `Trelford said...' Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: A journalist for a British newspaper has been sentenced to death in Iraq for alleged espionage, and a British nurse has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for allegedly helping him, the Foreign Office said today. Farzad Bazoft, a 31-year-old stateless Iranian exile who travels with British documents and works for London's weekly Observer newspaper, was arrested in September while investigating reports of an explosion at an Iraqi military plant. Nurse Daphne Parish, 52, was accused of helping him by driving him to the plant. An Iraqi who was in contact with Bazoft in Baghdad was also given a 10-year sentence for communicating government secrets to a foreigner, the Foreign Office said. Bazoft and Mrs. Parish went on trial Thursday in a revolutionary court, charged with committing hostile acts against Iraq. The Iraqi, identified only as Rahim, was tried with them. The proceedings, which were not open to the public, adjourned after five hours, and the Foreign Office said it received a report by telephone this morning of the sentences. Under Iraqi law, no appeal is allowed. ``We utterly deplore these harsh and excessive sentences,'' a Foreign Office statement said. Iraq's ambassador to Britain, Dr. Azmi Shafiq Al-Salihi, was being summoned to the Foreign Office to hear the government's ``utter dismay'' and an appeal for clemency was being made to Iraq's President Saddam Hussein, the Foreign Office said. ``No evidence was produced at the trial which would justify sentences of this severity,'' the Foreign Office said. ``They come ill from a regime which is trying to show a more liberal face to the world.'' In November, Bazoft appeared on Iraqi state television and said he had been spying for Israel. Mrs. Parish, a senior nursing administrator for the Irish-run, Ibn al-Bitar hospital in Baghdad, did not appear in the broadcast. Observer editor Donald Trelford said the paper was certain that Bazoft was not spying for anyone. He said the statement must have been made under duress and noted that Bazoft appeared to be in poor physical shape. Trelford said today that although Bazoft said at his trial that the TV confession was made under duress, it was admitted as evidence nonetheless. ``The sentences are barbaric and unjust,'' Trelford said. ``Our first objective is to have the death sentence lifted prior to their release and return to Britain.'' Trelford said Bazoft had sought official permission to visit the Al-Iskandaria military complex south of Baghdad, had told the paper of his movements, and had talked openly about the visit to colleagues on his return to Baghdad. ``None of this conduct is consistent with espionage. It is entirely consistent with journalism,'' he said. Trelford said Iraq refused to allow a British lawyer to attend the trial or The Observer to be represented. As Bazoft is an Iranian, the Foreign Office said it was not in the same position to argue on his behalf as it was for Mrs. Parish, who is British-born. But it said it was appealing on Bazoft's behalf for humanitarian reasons and because he lived in Britain for years. Britain has brought up the case with every prominent Iraqi minister or official who has visited London in the past few months, the Foreign Office said. It said it had also complained to Iraq about ``shortcomings in the treatment'' of the two, particularly the denial of consular access to Mrs. Parish for almost three months. The explosion at a military complex was reported in London to have killed up to 700 people, but the Iraqis later said 19 people were killed in a fuel depot blast.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Says It Will Defend Disputed Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Libyan legislature has issued a strong defense of the plant the United States says is producing poison gas, the official Libyan news agency reported today. Libya's people will ``stand as a shield to protect'' the Rabta ``pharmaceutical factory,'' the JANA news agency quoted the General Poeple's Congress as saying. JANA, in a dispatch monitored in Rome, also said the congress denounced chemical weapons, saying the Libyans are ``against all types of weapons of mass destruction'' including ``nuclear, bacteriological and chemical'' ones. The congress, made up of representatives from local grass-roots governing committees throughout the North African nation and roughly the equivalent of a parliament, met Friday night in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, JANA said. The White House has charged that the plant at Rabta, 65 miles southwest of Tripoli, is apparently producing poison gas. Other U.S. officials said the plant was making some mustard gas and nerve agents. Libyans made similar vows early last year following the first round of U.S. accusations that the facility was gearing up to produce chemical weapons. The congress reiterated previous Libyan statements that the country supports international inspection, provided that controls are universally applied, JANA said. Last year, Col. Moammar Gadhafi's government offered to open the plant to inspection provided the United States also lets its facilities be inspected. Gadhafi has insisted the plant was built to produce pharmacueticals. In 1987, Libya was accused of using poison gas against Chad.

DOC.HEAD: King of Lesotho Going Into Exile
DOC.TEXT: King Moshoeshoe II of Lesotho is going into exile in Britain after a bitter dispute with the country's military government, palace officials said today. The king of the mountainous African nation left for London today, according to palace officials who declined to be named. But government officials, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the king was going on vacation to rest for an indefinite period. The palace officials said the king decided to go into exile after Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya, head of the military government, stripped him of all constitutional powers last month and arrested some of his friends and relatives. King Moshoeshoe has protested Lekhanya's steps, but has been powerless to resist. Lekhanya and his allies on the ruling military council control the country, which is completely surrounded by South Africa. The king went into exile in 1970, spending several months in the Netherlands, during a dispute with the authoritarian civilian government that controlled Lesotho at the time. The Lesotho military took power in a 1986 coup headed by Lekhanya, ousting the authoritarian regime of Leabua Jonathon. The military government and the king have been locked in a struggle for power, with the monarch attempting to assert his control over the country.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Talks Trade, Nicaragua with Caribbean Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in first four grafs to show meeting with Caribbean leaders began; picks up 5th graf, Quayle said; Informatively, departure for Santiago expected mid-afternoon EST and this should stand for PMs
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle turned to economic and trade talks in a meeting today with leaders of Caribbean nations as he continued his weeklong trip to shore up American relations in Latin America. Quayle arrived Friday in Barbados after discussions in Venezuela on the prospects of moving the Nicaraguan Contra rebels from their Honduran border camps to enclaves within Nicaragua as an interim step in demobilization. Quayle also discussed Central America with Barbados Prime Minister Lloyd Erskine Sandiford. And he was briefing the leaders of five other Caribbean nations on his talks with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez and Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, who also was in Venezuela. The meeting today, held against a backdrop of palm trees and an ocean view at the official residence of the American charges d'affaires, included Sandiford and the leaders from Barbados, Dominica, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, St. Kitts, St. Lucia and Antigua. Quayle said he promised Sandiford on Friday that he would pursue a resolution to the ``very important subject'' involving a U.S.-Barbados taxation agreement. The issue centers on U.S. taxes on American insurance and banking companies that lose incentive to locate in Barbados unless they can escape those taxes. Quayle was flying later today to Santiago, Chile, where he and his wife Marilyn will represent the United States at the inauguration Sunday of President-elect Patricio Aylwin. On the first day of his week-long trip to Barbados and South America, the vice president was pressed by Perez and Gonzalez on the need for rapid disbandment of the U.S.-built Contra army. ``They were pressing very hard for very early disbandment,'' said Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., who is accompanying Quayle to Chile and who sat in on the meetings Friday. Kennedy said he agrees the Contras should be demobilized immediately, regardless of the Bush administration's insistence that their security must be assured for reintegrating into Nicaragua. One official traveling with Quayle indicated the administration is leaning to the idea of interim relocation in designated areas. United Nations peacekeeping troops would insure order under that scenario, making sure there were no clashes between the Contras and members of the Nicaraguan army, which is still controlled by the outgoing leftist Sandinista government. ``That might be a way station to disarmament,'' the official said when asked whether the administration envisions having the Contras keep their weapons in such camps. The official spoke on condition of anonymity. The official reiterated that the administration wants the Contras to disband before Violeta Chamorro, the U.S.-backed candidate who defeated Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in the Feb. 25 election, takes office April 25. He said the United States expects at the same time, however, that the Sandinistas will submit to a peaceful transfer of power, including relinquishing control of the 70,000-man army. But Quayle later said in Barbados, ``I'm not saying everything will be accomplished by the 25th of April. We hope to accomplish a lot by then. I don't believe it's important to focus on whether it's the 25th or the 26th. I think it's important to focus on the concept, and the goal,'' of having the new government succeed. Quayle's discussions in Venezuela focused almost entirely on how to ensure a peaceful transfer of power in Nicaragua after a decade of Marxist rule. Quayle said the administration will announce next week its aid package to help get the country's desperate economy moving again. The package will weigh heavily on agricultural assistance, because Nicaragua is largely agrarian, and will include trade assistance as well, said the official traveling with Quayle.

DOC.HEAD: Many Jews Feel Uneasy and Helpless About the New Germany
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: After the speakers had finished wrestling with the subject of their symposium _``Germany in the 1990s; Jewish Hopes and Fears'' _ an old, white-haired man in the audience struggled to his feet. ``Everybody says reunification of Germany is unavoidable, but is everybody really happy about this forthcoming reunification?'' he said. ``I, a refugee from Vienna in 1939, am not, and I suspect that there must be many people here who equally are not happy.''
