His remarks encapsulated the unease and helplessness felt by many Western European Jews _ although clearly not all _ at the prospect of a united Germany. ``It is happening too soon; it is happening too fast,'' said Claude Lanzmann, the Frenchman who made the epic Holocaust documentary ``Shoah.'' ``Germany is a special country,'' he said in a telephone interview from Paris. ``One cannot guess now what this new Germany will be, what the contradictions and the tensions will be inside this country. The new German nationalism will have, in my opinion, a very strong revival. ``Nobody can say calmly today that this new Germany will behave like the former Federal Republic'' of West Germany, Lanzmann said. The London symposium's audience consisted mostly of elderly Jews _ Holocaust survivors, refugees, people who had achieved peace and prosperity in Britain but were still sufficiently preoccupied with the Nazi past to crowd into a basement auditorium and air their fears. Reassurances that there could never be another Hitler were coupled with vaguely expressed fears for the future. A man spoke of ``this feeling of impotence'' in the face of a German giant risen again. Like a dark backdrop to the proceedings lay the fears Jews feel about reawakened anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union and in Eastern and Central Europe. ``No matter what the structure will be, at this moment, as Jews, as people who have often experienced Germany at its worst, we have great fears that cannot be easily laid aside,'' said Albert Friedlander, a London rabbi and Holocaust survivor. There were moments when the panel of rabbis and scholars seemed sharply at odds with the audience. When a speaker, professor Geoffrey Alderman, remarked that Germany was not wholly responsible for the two world wars, there were angry mutterings of ``nonsense'' and ``rubbish.'' Friedlander said he was more worried about French anti-Semitism than about a reunited Germany. Alderman declared that some remarks he had heard privately from orthodox Jews about Germany ``quite frankly strike me as racist.'' In a letter last month to Rabbi Marvin Hier of Los Angeles, who demanded measures by a united Germany to preserve the memory of the Holocaust, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany sounded aggrieved. He listed the many measures already taken and said: ``To my mind, there is no doubt that these provisions will also apply in a united Germany. This certainly does not require any special demand.'' European Jews readily acknowledge West Germany's record of liberal democracy and support for Israel. They also are gratified by East Germany's apparent new-found readiness to share the blame for the Nazi era and make amends to the Jews. ``I don't think a democratic German state will represent any danger for Jews or Israel,'' said Leo Eitinger, a Czechoslovak survivor of the Holocaust who is a psychiatrist in Norway. Jean Bloch, a Belgian Jew who experienced the Hitler era, noted the conditions that spawned Nazism _ economic crisis and national humiliation _ do not exist now. ``We must be careful not to stir the same feeling of humiliation by opposing unification,'' he said. Ronnie Naftaniel, a spokesman for Dutch Jewry, said: ``The fact that Israel is on the map makes Jews everywhere sleep better.'' Many Jews, when asked, admit to an instinctive anxiety. It is shared by many non-Jews in Europe, but for Jews it is compounded by memories of the Holocaust that stripped them down to tiny minorities in many European countries. An oft-heard remark, laced with bitterness, is that if there's no anti-Semitism in Germany it must because so few Jews are left there _ about 41,500, compared to 560,000 before World War II. ``The Germans always were unpredictable,'' said Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi hunter. ``They become foolhardy as soon as they feel strong. They have to be careful not to repeat mistakes.'' Alderman told the London symposium that, to orthodox Jews, the division of Germany was not just a product of the Cold War, but a punishment ``visited by the Almighty upon the Germans for their unspeakable crimes toward the Jews.'' Now that the division is ending, he said, ``the Jewish people will have to take stock again of their attitude toward Germany.'' One sensitive theme is the fear that unification will embolden Germans to shrug off their awareness of the Holocaust. Professor Peter Pulzer, a refugee from Vienna now at Oxford University, worries that, once Germany is united, ``a lot of Germans who aren't racists or neo-Nazis may say, `OK, that's over; we've drawn a line underneath the nasty bits.''' If one reason for dividing Germany was its Nazi past, Lanzmann said, ``today this seems to be, if not forgotten, left aside. It has become unimportant in a way.'' Fears seem most acute among the generation old enough to remember Nazi Germany. Shalom, an Italian Jewish monthly, surveyed opinion and concluded: ``In general, optimism prevails among the young and pessimism among those less young.'' Most Jews acknowledge there is nothing they can do to stop unification. ``What we must avoid at all costs ... is nostalgia'' for the old, Cold War order, said Alain Finkielkraut, a French Jewish intellectual. Lord Jakobovits, chief rabbi of Britain, has been quoted as calling for ``a chair for a Jewish spokesman'' at an international conference on the shape of a new Germany. Other Jews say the Jews could never agree who should represent them. ``We hope that Jewish victims of the Holocaust will have their say in laying down rules and laws forbidding exclusion, discrimination, racism and anti-Semitism of any kind,'' said Jean Kahn, head of the Representative Council of French Jewish Organizations. The European Jewish Congress, meeting last month in Brussels, said the Jewish communities of Europe, ``which suffered so much under the Third Reich, must express their preoccupations about a reunited Germany.'' It said Germany should ``recognize now and forever its collective responsibility for the Holocaust and its victims.''

DOC.HEAD: Quotes from European Jews on German Reunification
With AM-Europe-Jews, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some quotations from European Jews who have reacted in speeches, interviews and articles to the prospect of German reunification: ``It is happening too soon; it is happening too fast.'' _ Claude Lanzmann, French filmmaker who made the Holocaust documentary ``Shoah.'' ``Amongst religious Jews ... there has been for a long time a feeling toward Germany and toward Germans which is almost apocalyptic in its implications. That is to say that the division of Germany was somehow visited by the Almighty upon the Germans for their unspeakable crimes toward the Jews, and that that division is a symbol of divine wrath. That division is now coming to an end .. . and the Jewish people will have to take stock again of their attitude toward Germany.'' _ Geoffrey Alderman, British university professor. ``It would be unwise to oppose unification. On the contrary, we must welcome it with good will as a deep desire of the German people. But we must get assurances that the new German generation will respect all human values and any minority.'' _ Albert Guigui, Belgian chief rabbi. ``You cannot argue from the past. If we were to argue from the past, we would have to say that the major danger we perceive is that the French will get to Moscow again as Napoleon did.'' _ Lord Beloff, British historian. ``The Germans always were unpredictable. They become foolhardy as soon as they feel strong. They have to be careful not to repeat mistakes.'' _ Simon Wiesenthal, Nazi hunter based in Vienna. ``The Germans don't think any more about us. My feeling is that the great majority of (German) people have other things on their minds.'' _ Fiamma Nirenstein, Italian journalist. ``The fact that Israel is on the map makes Jews everywhere sleep better.'' _ Ronnie Naftaniel, a spokesman for Dutch Jewry.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Officials Prosecuted for Corruption Leading to Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Criminal proceedings are under way against 20 officials in connection with the deaths of 42 gold miners in a snowstorm last year, the official Xinhua news agency reported Saturday. The 20 were among 41 officials charged with corruption as part of a nationwide campaign against wrongdoing that has badly tainted the Communist Party's reputation. The charges were filed as a result of an investigation into the miners' deaths last May. For more than a month, 8,000 gold prospectors were stranded on the 16,400-foot-high Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Xinhua said an investigation into how the miners came to be stranded revealed that provincial and municipal officials had issued licenses to 28,000 individual gold miners last year, violating a government ban on private prospecting, and had either embezzled funds or accepted bribes worth $325,500. Those accused of wrongdoing include former Qinghai Gov. Song Ruixiang and former Vice Gov. Ma Yuanbiao, Xinhua said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope To Meet With Havel Next Month While In Prague
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will meet with President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia next month during the pontiff's visit to Prague, the Vatican said Saturday. The pope's 33-hour trip to Czechoslovakia will be his first visit to a Warsaw Pact country other than his native Poland. The April 21-22 visit will include a visit to Havel in the official presidential residence. Havel, a playwright, was a vigorous opponent of the former Communist regime of Czechoslovakia. He came to power in the peaceful revolution late last year that ended the Communists' monopoly on power. Since the revolution in Czechoslovakia and similar upheavals in East bloc countries, the Vatican has moved quickly to take advantage of the new climate to boost the position of local Roman Catholic churches. Last month the pope named five bishops for Czechoslovakia, filling the country's 13 dioceses for the first time since World War II. In the past, Communist regimes had blocked the nomination of new bishops.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Unravel Tangled Tale of Seamanship at Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: On the brink of its finale, the trial of Joseph Hazelwood has become a battle of expert, high-priced witnesses trying to unravel the tangled tale of the Exxon Valdez skipper's seamanship. Prosecutors spent more than $140,000 to hire five experts. The defense will spend perhaps half that on more experts to give opinions on how well the skipper performed his job. ``You can't build a case totally on experts,'' said Thomas Russo, one of Hazelwood's lawyers. ``But in any case where the issues are not within common knowledge, experts are useful to explain things to jurors.'' Russo said the defense has tried to use experts less likely to confuse or intimidate jurors: sea captains who sail, a naval architect who builds ships and a computer expert who had never before testified in a court. Prosecutors appeared to go for impressive credentials. Their toxicologist, Dr. Richard Prouty, spent more than an hour reciting his qualifications before venturing the opinion that Hazelwood probably was drunk on the crucial night. He said he has testified more than 1,000 times. The case, with its discussions of rudder angles and nautical miles, fathom markers and buoyancy, soundings and engine thrust, has not been easy for a non-mariner to understand. For weeks, the courtroom of Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone has been littered with huge nautical charts and diagrams tracking the Exxon Valdez on its disastrous voyage through the Valdez Narrows into Prince William Sound. There is a detailed, beautifully painted, color mockup of the 987-foot tanker that would be the envy of amateur model makers. Expert witnesses carry it around and point out its features to the jury. Another pull-apart model shows the ship's bridge. Lift off the top and you can look down to the deck where the skipper sat in his cabin during the grounding on March 24. It was just after midnight when the fully loaded tanker struck Bligh Reef, spewing nearly 11 million gallons of oil into the clear waters of scenic Prince William Sound. The spill, largest in U.S. history, devastated the area's rich fisheries and wildlife and fouled hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Was it an accident or a crime? That question underlies five weeks of testimony. The jury's answer is likely to have repercussions beyond the fairly mild charges against Hazelwood. Civil suits abound and federal criminal charges have been filed against Exxon. Hazelwood, 43, from Huntington, N.Y., is accused of one felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The trial began with testimony from those who saw Hazelwood in the port town of Valdez on the day the ship sailed, crew members who accompanied him and officers who carried out the ship's carefully organized functions. Coast Guard officers and a state trooper related their investigations. Then, Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole brought on his experts. George Greiner Jr., a retired Coast Guardsman with a consulting firm, said he figured Hazelwood had tried to move his stranded ship off the reef after the grounding, risking capsizing and killing the crew. The defense elicited his statement that the Exxon Valdez was so deeply impaled that it could not have moved. Robert Beevers, a retired tanker captain, told jurors everything that Hazelwood did was reckless. William Milwee Jr., a salvage expert, said the Exxon Valdez could have capsized and sunk. On the crucial question of whether Hazelwood was drunk, the state presented Prouty who ``calculated backwards'' to conclude Hazelwood probably was drunk. He conceded there is dispute on his technique among scientists. The defense is expected to offer an alcohol expert this week. The defense has called a naval architect, Edward Hoffman, to say the ship would not have sunk even if dislodged from the reef. They brought in computer whiz Peter Shizume who simulated the voyage and found a simple rudder turn by the helmsman would have saved the ship. A marine surveyor, Joseph Winer, analyzed charts to support the conclusions. When court recessed for the weekend, a former tanker captain, Shiras Walker, had declared Hazelwood was not reckless. ``I would have done exactly what Captain Hazelwood did,'' he said. Walker faces cross-examination on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Pricey Birds Targeted for Theft
DOC.TEXT: A red-violet eclectus parrot, a green-wing macaw and an ostrichlike emu are among the missing _ victims in a rash of 40 exotic birds thefts in the Miami area over the past five months. The popularity of the valuable tropical birds and federal limits on imports have combined to produce a profitable black market in birds, Ron Magill, assistant to the curator at Miami's MetroZoo, said Friday. ``You see these birds that are stolen being sold everywhere from classified advertising to flea markets,'' he said. ``I wouldn't be surprised from what's going on now that some of these birds aren't sold before they're stolen.'' The 9-year-old zoo lost a female eclectus parrot valued at more than $1,000 to someone who ducked into a screened breeding cage two weeks ago while the staff member on duty was gone for about 20 minutes. ``The only other time that I know of that we had a theft of an animal at MetroZoo since we opened was about five years ago at the bird show area,'' said Magill. But the law of supply and demand is at work, even at the criminal level. ``The population of these birds in the wild is becoming so depleted that federal regulations are making it extremely difficult to import them. Therefore the price is becoming very high on these birds,'' he said. ``What's happening now is people are starting to steal from the private owners and collectors in this country.'' Warren and Jude Werner, stars of their Gold Coast Mime Co., used a macaw named Miami Beak in their act until the $3,000 bird was stolen from their Miami Beach home March 3. ``These were people who knew birds,'' Werner said. ``They didn't take anything but the bird.'' Susan Boyd, president of the Miami Parrot Club, improved security after two blind eclectus parrots, two lovebirds and a cockatoo were taken from her home Feb. 21. Two days later, birdnappers struck again, this time making off another cockatoo and a blue and gold macaw. Bird dealer Joe Wasilewski of Natural Selections lost four birds in a break-in at his warehouse Dec. 27 but recovered three in a police sting that resulted in two arrests. But he still misses the fourth bird, a 7-year-old African gray named Lola. African grays are considered the best talkers, or mimics, among parrots. ``She used to talk and sing and whistle and drive around with me,'' he said. ``It's part of my family.'' Victims suspect a ring is behind the spate of thefts dating back to late October, Wasilewski said. ``If you don't have the training to handle them, you're going to get bit,'' he said. ``They have to have training to steal all the wide variety that they are.''

DOC.HEAD: First Big Show of Rembrandt Landscapes Opens in Washington
DOC.TEXT: Legend has it that Rembrandt once bet he could prepare an etching of the Dutch countryside before a friend's servant could fetch mustard from a nearby village. Rembrandt won the wager, according to the Frenchman responsible for the tale, although it was not said how long the waiter took to run his errand. The old master's spontaneous touch with a normally slow and painstaking medium is known, and the results can be seen Sunday through May 20 at Washington's National Gallery of Art. The etching, ``Six's Bridge,'' is part of the first major exhibit devoted to Rembrandt's landscape prints and drawings. The etching shows a canal, two boats, two bushes, a church, a bridge and two men standing on it _ all on a plate 5 inches by 10 inches. Rembrandt is better known for his oil paintings, but only eight of his surviving oils are landscapes. Largely scattered among European museums, they are not among the 99 works in this exhibit, though one of them can be seen in another part of the gallery. Etching can be one of the most difficult, time-consuming processes, lending itself to tightly controlled, highly detailed works. The works are begun on metal plates coated with a soft wax formula. The artist cuts through the mixture with a needle so that acid can bite into the resulting scratches on the plate, from which the etching is later printed. Rembrandt took prepared plates with him during his long walks around the city. Because of its self-imposed narrow scope, the exhibit contains much of Rembrandt's most intimate work, homely scenes that roused his personal interest: boats, bridges, churches, towers, cottages, a man rowing a boat and an artist sketching by the road. This is the story told by Edme Francois Gersaint, who made the first catalogue of Rembrandt's works more than 80 years after the artist died in 1669: One overcast day in the year 1645 Rembrandt sat down to lunch at the country house of his friend Jan Six, later mayor of Amsterdam, when they made a discovery: there was no mustard. Six sent a servant to the village. ``Rembrandt knew how slow servants usually are in his country: when they reply `anstons,' which means `right away,' they take at least half an hour to appear,'' wrote Gersaint in one of the few stories about the artist. So Rembrandt made the bet. Art history professor Cynthia P. Schneider of Georgetown University calls the story ``apocryphal.'' But she added in the catalogue for this exhibit that the work was a miracle of artistic economy. ``The swift and spare strokes of the etching have all the freedom of a sketch from life,'' she said. She also pointed out that it is done from a low viewpoint, as if the artist were sitting on the ground. Gersaint said it was the scene from the window of the room the two men were in. A Dutch scholar has claimed to identify the church and Six's property along the Amstel River in the suburbs of Amsterdam. Then it was called Klein-Kostverloren, ``Little Money-Lost.'' How much was the bet? Are those the two friends on the bridge? The show will not travel elsewhere after closing in Washington. Roger Mandle, the gallery's deputy director, said he expected large crowds but did not intend to use a ticket system unless they get too big for comfortable viewing.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion-Rights Side Seen Winning Three Seats in Congress
DOC.TEXT: Abortion-rights advocates can expect to have at least three new allies in Congress next year, according to a survey of candidates running in 79 key House and Senate races. The survey by Congressional Quarterly magazine also found the abortion issue is causing internal conflicts among party members in both Democratic and Republican primaries. The magazine found many candidates are trying to stake out positions somewhere between ``pro-choice'' and ``pro-life.'' In at least three cases, the magazine reported, anti-abortion incumbents are retiring and all the candidates running to succeed them favor abortion rights. The races are for the Senate seat from Colorado being vacated by Republican Sen. William Armstrong, the House seat held by retiring Rep. Wes Watkins, D-Okla., and the New York seat vacated by Republican Rep. Guy Molinari, who resigned to become borough president for Staten Island. The survey focused on open seats and close contests for 16 Senate and 63 House seats. It found 23 races in which abortion-rights Democrats face anti-abortion Republicans. But it also found the issue is not purely partisan: _In 15 contests, the leading candidates of both parties support abortion rights; in 14 races, both oppose abortion. _Democratic candidates disagreed on abortion in 10 of the primary races surveyed, while Republicans disagreed among themselves in 12 primary contests. _In at least one competitive House race, an anti-abortion Democrat faces a pro-choice Republican. The Democrat is Rep. George Sangmeister of Illinois. His opponent is insurance broker Manny Hoffman. Congressional Quarterly said its survey found many candidates are trying to find a middle position that will appeal to voters not allied with either side in the abortion debate. In nine of the 14 races that involve only abortion opponents, the magazine said, at least one candidate supports federal funding of abortions for poor women in cases of rape or incest. It said many pro-choice candidates, meanwhile, are wary of opposing parental involvement in abortion decisions by minors. CQ, a weekly publication about Congress, conducted its telephone survey between Feb. 16 and March 8. Some candidates' positions may have changed since then, the authors said.

DOC.HEAD: Chiang Kai-Shek's Son Withdraws From Election
LaserPhotos TPE1,3
DOC.TEXT: The son of Nationalist Chinese leader Chiang Kai-shek withdrew his candidacy Saturday for vice president in a contest that had threatened an unprecedented split in the governing party. Chiang Wego pulled out of the race a day after his running mate, popular judicial chief Lin Yang-kang, decided against challenging President Lee Teng-hui in the presidential election March 21. ``I will follow the steps of Mr. Lin Yang-kang,'' Chiang, 73, told reporters. The Nationalist Party's 180-member central committee unanimously backed Lee's candidacy for a six-year presidential term last month. But Lee, 67, angered elderly party members when he rejected their choice of Chiang as his running mate and instead selected presidential adviser Li Yuan-zu, 66. The elderly party members retaliated by endorsing Lin, 62, and Chiang as a rival team to contest the election. Taiwan's 752-seat National Assembly, which will elect the president, is dominated by the elderly legislators. They fled to Taiwan in 1949 when the Nationalists lost a civil war on the Chinese mainland to Communist forces. The elders have been frozen in office to support the Nationalist claim of being the legitimate government of all China. They are concerned that Lee's pragmatic policies toward the rival Communist government will weaken their dream to reunify China under Nationalist rule. Lee is the first native Taiwanese to head the Nationalist government. He was elevated to the post from the vice presidency in 1988 when President Chiang Ching-kuo died. Chiang Wego, a retired general and Chiang Ching-kuo's half brother, is viewed by many of the older assemblymen as the defender of their nationalistic ambitions. He is the sole surviving son of Chinese leader Chiang Kai-shek. He said earlier that he would not actively campaign for the vice presidency, but would not discourage the electoral college from supporting him. His stand has been criticized, most recently on Friday when his nephew, Chiang Hsiao-wu, accused him of ``wanting to be elected but claiming he would not campaign.'' Chiang Hsiao-wu, the son of Chiang Ching-kuo, is head of Taiwan's unofficial diplomatic mission in Japan. The opposition Democratic Progressive Party has accused Chiang Wego of using his influence with Taiwan's military to block native Taiwanese from gaining power in the government. The Democratic Progressive Party, formed three years ago by Taiwanese, does not have enough members in the National Assembly to nominate its own candidate for president.

DOC.HEAD: Police Firing, Curfew at Site of Militant Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire and killed two Hindu fundamentalists Saturday in an attempt to break up a fight between political groups protesting the killing of 34 Hindus by Sikh militants, authorities said. An indefinite curfew was clamped on the town of Abohar in Punjab state after the shooting, which also injured 15 people, said Deputy Commissioner Rakesh Singh. He said members of the opposition Congress Party and the Hindu fundamentalist Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or National Self-Service League, were separately protesting the killing of 34 people Wednesday in an attack by Sikh militants. The two groups began throwing stones at each other, Singh said, and police opened fire to control the situation. The officer did not know why the two groups began fighting. Singh was contacted by telephone from Amritsar, a town about 100 miles to the north of Abohar. Amritsar is the focal point of the 8-year-old Sikh militant campaign for an independent nation in Punjab state. The campaign has resulted in at least 318 deaths in Punjab this year. Most were killed in attacks by militants. On Wednesday, Sikh militants opened fire in Abohar's main market and left timed explosives before escaping from the area. All the victims were Hindus. Sikhs are in a slight majority in Punjab state but form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Sikh militants claim their community is discriminated against by Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the nation's population.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Burned in Indian Airlines Crash Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old girl who suffered severe burns in the crash last month of an Indian Airlines jet near Bangalore died Saturday, bringing the death toll to 93 people. Rakhee Patel died at Mount Vernon Hospital in Northwood, Middlesex, just north of London, a hospital spokesman said. Surgeons on Feb. 20 performed a rare graft using skin from a dead donor in an effort to save her life. ``Despite the efforts of a team of plastic surgeons, Rakhee succumbed to her very serious burn injuries,'' said the spokesman, who was not identified. The senior plastic surgeon, Dr. Nigel Mercer, said Rakhee suffered burns over 85 percent of her body when the Indian Airlines Airbus crashed short of the runway at the Indian city of Bangalore on Feb. 14. The jet carried 146 people, including Rakhee's parents, Jaisukh and Neeta Patel. They were injured. Their relatives raised thousands of dollars to fly Rakhee, her parents and younger sister to Britain for hospital treatment. A relative said the other members of Rakhee's family were hospitalized in stable condition. The cause of the crash has not been determined.

DOC.HEAD: New Foreign Minister Named
DOC.TEXT: The government has named Wilson Ndolo Ayah as Kenya's new foreign minister. He replaces Robert Ouko, who was slain last month. President Daniel arap Moi announced Ayah's appointment on Friday along with three other Cabinet changes. Ayah had been Moi's minister for water development. Ayah, 57, entered politics in 1969, winning a parliamentary seat from western Kisumu, the same region Ouko represented in Parliament. He was named assistant minister for finance in 1987 and later served as minister for research, science and technology. He was given the water portfolio in 1988. Ayah holds a master's degree in agricultural economics from the University of Wisconsin. Ouko's partly burned body was found near his home in western Kenya three weeks ago. He had been shot once in the head. An investigation into his slaying continues. In other Cabinet changes, Onyango Midika, an assistant minister for labor, was named minister for regional development. He replaced John Okwanyo, who took Ayah's former chair in the water ministry. John Ryalo, a member of Parliament, was named minister of state in the president's office. He replaced Johnstone Makau, who was fired last week.

DOC.HEAD: Government Claims Rebel Attacks Repelled on Southern Town
DOC.TEXT: The army said Saturday that it repelled three rebel attacks on the strategic southern town of Yei last week in fighting that killed 40 rebels and one army soldier. A military communique said six government soldiers and scores of rebels were wounded in the battles Tuesday and Wednesday. The official Sudan News Agency distributed the communique. Forces of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army attacked Yei, 800 miles southwest of Khartoum, three times using tanks, artillery and rocket launchers, according to the communique. Government soldiers captured a rebel tank and its driver, as well as large quantities of ammunition and arms, it said. Yei is near the borders of Zaire and Uganda. It is important because many supplies for Juba, the region's capital, are trucked to Yei across the borders before going on to Juba. The rebels claimed several weeks ago that they controlled the Yei-Juba highway, but the government denied this. Elaborating on the communique, Chief of Staff Gen. Ishak Ibrahim Omar said that two rebel battalions were routed in the Yei fighting. He said the army also had repulsed two rebel attacks in other areas of the Equatoria and Bahr el-Ghazal regions with unspecified ``heavy losses'' on the rebel side. The rebel army took up arms against the government in 1983. It demands greater autonomy in the south from the Moslem-dominated government, as well as administrative and economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: `We Cannot Stop,' Selma Marchers Told
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruoughout with marchers on last leg toward Capitol, Jesse Jackson quotes, removes outdated and redundant material. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights activists commemorating the 25th anniversary of the Selma-to-Montgomery march began their final walk toward Alabama's Capitol today, chanting and singing their way through the Cradle of the Confederacy. ``We could not stop in Montgomery in 1965. We cannot stop today,'' Jesse Jackson told marchers lining up. ``We've got to go on to Washington, where there's the budget to shift national priorities.'' A mostly black crowd of about 1,000 marchers began the two-mile walk to downtown Montgomery, where 25,000 people gathered in 1965 to demand voting rights for blacks. In both marches they headed for the white-domed Capitol, where Jefferson Davis was sworn in as president of the Confederacy. The Rebel banner still flies over the building, despite protests by blacks. Jackson and others, including Coretta Scott King, the widow of the Martin Luther King Jr., and U.S. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., were scheduled to speak on the Capitol steps. On Friday night, actor Lou Gossett Jr. acted as master of ceremonies for a program featuring musical styles ranging from Broadway to rap in an attempt to draw a huge crowd for today's march. Singer Melba Moore, rap artist Jessie West and civil rights activist-comedian Dick Gregory were some of the celebrities on hand. ``You have to carry it on,'' Gossett told the cheering crowd of about 2,000 people. ``You have to carry it in your hearts, in your lifestyles ... You have to think about it and carry it on.'' In 1965, Peter, Paul and Mary, Harry Belafonte, Joan Baez and other entertainers performed the night before the march to help drum up a crowd. This week about 150 people made the 50-mile walk along the four-lane highway linking Selma with Montgomery, and an organizer said it was an invigorating experience for young and old. ``I think we're talking about reclaiming the values of the past,'' said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. ``I don't think the 1990s will get by like the 80s.''

DOC.HEAD: Nations Raise Holdings of Foreign Currencies
DOC.TEXT: The United States led the way last year as central banks around the world raised their holdings of foreign currency to a record $768 billion, the International Monetary Fund reported. The holdings reflect efforts by industrialized countries to influence trade through international exchange rates and by Third World countries to stockpile cash for emergencies. Last year's worldwide level was $726 billion. The holdings do not include gold. The largest increase was in total U.S. holdings of foreign currency, especially West German marks and Japanese yen, IMF said in its March compilation of international financial statistics. Total U.S. holdings at the end of 1989 were valued at $63.3 billion, up from $36.9 billion in 1988, IMF reported. Japan held $83.7 billion worth of reserves, down from $97 billion at the end of 1988. ``The United States and Japan were both trying to keep the price of the dollar low so that the United States could sell more goods, and Japan and others would buy more,'' said Robert Solomon of the Brookings Institution, a private policy studies group. ``So the United States sold a lot of dollars to push the price down and got a lot of yen and marks in return.'' Solomon is a former adviser to the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, the American central bank. ``The Japanese were trying to buy more American goods, so they sold some of their dollars to push the price down,'' Solomon explained. A lower price for the dollar makes American goods cheaper and more attractive to Japanese. When the dollar is cheaper, the yen is more expensive. That makes Japanese goods less attractive to Americans. Both effects tend to lower the U.S. deficit in world trade, which dropped to $108.6 billion in 1989. That deficit was still a major world problem though it was down by more than $10 billion from the year before. Like other market operations, government buying and selling of currencies does not always work as well as intended. Japanese authorities have been complaining that the dollar has risen lately despite the intervention. It rose once again on Friday, to more than 151 yen and 1.7 marks. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and finance ministers of six other major industrial countries have just called a meeting in Paris for April 7. Ups and downs of the dollar and other currencies will be a major topic. In most of the Third World, reserves are an insurance against a rainy day when a country needs to buy more goods abroad than it can earn by selling its own products. Reserves rose for 130 Third World countries to a record $267 billion, the fund reported.

DOC.HEAD: Daytona Officials Seek `Managed' Spring Break
DOC.TEXT: Ah, spring: When young folks' fancies lightly turn to thoughts of suds, sex, sunburn, loud music, wet T-shirt and belly flop contests at this, ``The World's Most Famous Beach.'' A local task force, hoping this year to minimize the bacchanalian havoc wrought by 400,000 booze-guzzling collegians, is trying to slow down the fast times with a campaign to ``Party Smart'' in Daytona. ``The theme means enjoy yourself, have a great time, be safe, go home safe and having had a wonderful time, come back in 1991,'' said Ray Eddy, chairman of the task force. Beach Police Chief John Kirvan said laws barring alcohol on the beach will be strictly enforced, and his officers will take a ``no-nonsense approach to drinking and rowdyism.'' Little else has changed in this year's student pilgrimage, which began in early March and continues through mid-April. MTV, the cable TV music channel which helped establish the area as a spring break mecca, is returning. So is Playboy magazine, National Lampoon and the rock concerts, product displays, beauty pageants and sporting events. Breweries, automakers and sun product companies will vie for student attention. This year, condom manufacturer Carter-Wallace Inc. will introduce ``Trojan Man'' to promote the need for safe sex. Parker Brothers is unveiling its new water- or air-filled Oopee ball. And there's 28 miles of hard-packed beach, where each year the swimsuits of men and women get a little more daring and ogling is a popular pastime for both sexes. Daytona Beach has been the spring break mecca for sun-starved Northern college students for about three years, since Fort Lauderdale let it be known that spring breakers were not welcome. Last year, some Daytonans grew tired of drunken excesses, property destruction, under-age drinking, gridlocked traffic and public urination. They urged officials to pull in the welcome mat. Hoping to keep the economic boon that will put an estimated $120 million into the local economy this year, the Daytona Beach Spring Break Festival Task Force was formed to make the partying more bearable for the locals. It has tripled available parking, increased trash receptacles and planted 100 portable toilets and hopes to control illegal drinking. It has organized activities for students and even created a code of conduct, Eddy said. The Daytona Beach police and the Volusia County Beach Patrol are pledging beefed-up forces and stringent enforcement of laws, especially those involving alcohol. Noise-control ordinances also will be enforced. ``Our problems haven't been with the college kids,'' said Daytona Police Chief Paul Crow. Contrary to public perceptions, Crow said, about 65 percent of those arrested last year were Florida youths, many under-age high schoolers. The task force is doing its best to ``un-invite'' high schoolers who skip classes and try to participate in activities designed for college-age students. As a result, the names of rock groups giving spring break concerts will not be publicized to anyone other than those staying at the beach. This year, Crow said police will restrict traffic to the beaches when they fill to help prevent gridlock. ``We are going to close the gate,'' Crow said. New city ordinances aimed at maintaining a more orderly crowd will close bars at 2 a.m., instead of 3 a.m. Hotels and motels cannot serve beer on pool decks until after 2 p.m. and must close the taps at 11 p.m. Wristbands will be issued to identify students who are 21, the legal drinking age in Florida. Task force members hope their plans will save spring break at Daytona. The first of an estimated 100,000 spring breakers also have begun arriving at coastal Texas' South Padre and Mustang islands, where Chamber of Commerce officials report 90 percent occupancy next weekend at hotels and motels. Police and Nueces County authorities will be bolstered by state police and officers of the state Alcohol Beverage Commission, said Constable DeeWayne Mathews. ``Our problem is the alcohol and the long, long hours they spend on the beach,'' Matthews said. ``You sit there and drink for 24 hours, you have a tendency to get drunk.''

DOC.HEAD: General Killed Trying to Arrest Coup Suspect Buried
LaserPhoto MLA2
DOC.TEXT: A lone trumpeter played taps and a helicopter dropped flower petals from above Saturday as 1,000 mourners buried a popular army officer who was killed while trying to arrest a rebellious governor. The coffin bearing Brig. Gen. Oscar Florendo's body was lowered into a concrete tomb after a three-gun salute. Relatives, close friends and even some reporters cried openly as the trumpeter played and the flowers rained down. Florendo, chief of the military's civil relations office and a popular former armed forces spokesman, was slain March 4 in the northern Philippines. He died during a clash between government troops and supporters of a suspended governor accused of taking part in December's coup attempt. The troops were called in after supporters of the governor, Rodolfo Aguinaldo, resisted attempts to arrest him and took Florendo hostage. Aguinaldo escaped during the confusion and remained at large Saturday. On Thursday, he said from hiding that he took responsibility for Florendo's death, and he called it a ``terrible mistake.'' At least 150 vehicles formed a convoy that brought Florendo's coffin from Camp Aguinaldo, the armed forces headquarters in suburban Manila, to Heroes Cemetery nine miles to the south. Many people living along the route lighted candles and offered prayers as the hearse passed. Eight brigadier generals, all Florendo's classmates at the elite Philippine Military Academy, acted as pallbearers and carried his coffin to a jeep-drawn cart that carried it the final 200 yards to the burial site. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos, a former armed forces chief of staff who had worked closely with Florendo, said after the funeral that the general was ``a special person whose sincerity and compassion is unmatched among our own personnel in the armed forces as well as in government.'' Sen. Ernesto Maceda, who also attended the funeral, said he hoped Florendo's death ``will shock us into reality and do some soul searching in order to gain the determination to unite for peace.'' ``When will this syndrome of violence that we are seeing every day end?'' said Maceda, chairman of the Senate Defense Committee. Florendo had been trying to serve an arrest warrant on Aguinaldo, the suspended governor of northern Cagayan province in connection with the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. At least 113 people died and more than 600 were wounded in the coup try. Aguinaldo made a broadcast the first day of the coup declaring his support for the rebel soldiers and offering to send ``artillery and armor'' to Manila. After four days of trying to persuade Aguinaldo to surrender, the governor and his supporters seized a hotel in Cagayan's capital, Tuguegarao, took Florendo hostage and trapped several other military and government officials. Florendo and 11 other people died during fighting when government troops recaptured the hotel.

DOC.HEAD: Too Poor To Rob
DOC.TEXT: A robber who broke into a home and held the owner at knifepoint apparently decided his victim was worse off than he was and gave back the $8 he was going to steal. ``I think he was disgusted,'' said the 32-year-old victim. The thief came into the house through an unlocked carport door early Friday and jumped on the victim, who was in bed. There was a brief struggle in which the victim was hit several times on the head with the butt of the knife. The victim said the robber ransacked his room, scooping up a watch, rings, $3 in change and $5 from his wallet. ``This house is not worth robbing,'' the thief suddenly said, giving back the money. But he kept the six rings and a watch valued at $61, according to a police report. ``He couldn't believe that was all the money I had,'' the victim said. ``He just dumped it in my hands and left.''

DOC.HEAD: Prisoner Escapes Day Before Completing His Sentence
DOC.TEXT: An inmate escaped from prison one day before he was to be released, and now faces up to 20 years in prison if recaptured. Donald M. Thomas, 34, of Newport, began serving a 90-day term for disorderly conduct Dec. 8 at the Adult Correctional Institution and his release papers were to have been handed to him Friday. Thomas was reported missing at 2:55 p.m. Thursday, shortly after he and 14 other prisoners returned to the minimum-security unit from an off-grounds work detail, said prison spokesman Joseph DiNitto. Thomas apparently got out of the van and hid behind it as several other work crews arrived and went into the prison, then he fled. A few minutes later, guards conducted a head count and realized someone was missing. ``For the life of me I don't know what possessed him to leave with only one day of his sentence left to serve,'' said DiNitto. Thomas was still missing Saturday. DiNitto said once Thomas is captured he will be arraigned on a charge of escaping, which carries a sentence of one to 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Two Sentenced for Drowning Woman
DOC.TEXT: Two women convicted in the 1985 drowning of a teen-ager linked romantically with their boyfriends were sentenced to 15 years to life in prison. Karen Severson and Laura Doyle, both 22 and of Arleta, were sentenced in Superior Court Friday after jurors found them guilty of second-degree murder. They were convicted of killing Michele ``Missy'' Avila, 17, by holding her head under ankle-deep water in a stream in Big Tujuna Canyon in Angeles National Forest. Judge Jack B. Tso dismissed defense pleas for leniency, saying the brutality of the crime justified a maximum penalty. Defense lawyers argued that the women had troubled childhoods and drug problems. The prosecution's key witness was a woman who testified that she saw the two defendants push Miss Avila down a path toward the creek, accusing her of having had sex with their boyfriends. Hikers found the girl's body three days later.

DOC.HEAD: Seattle Archbishop Stops Training Deacons in Protest
DOC.TEXT: Seattle Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen has canceled plans to train more deacons until the role of women in the Roman Catholic Church is addressed more thoroughly. Women are not allowed to be deacons. ``Many women and men told us that the church didn't seem to respect the personhood of women, that the church was patriarchal and unappreciative of women's gifts,'' said Hunthausen, who with Coadjutor Archbishop Thomas Murphy is helping the U.S. Catholic bishops to write a pastoral letter, ``Women in Society and the Church.'' Some priests, deacons and lay Catholics praised the archbishop's decision in calling attention to women's role in the church, but others said they thought it would have no effect other than slowing the flow of deacons into parishes. Deacons perform considerable work in some parishes, such as administering the sacraments of baptism and marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Dismissal of Ethics Complaint Caps Gingrich's Political Ascent
DOC.TEXT: Former President Richard Nixon was making his first visit to the House since being driven from office by the Watergate scandal when Rep. Newt Gingrich learned that his own ethics cloud had evaporated. Gingrich, second-ranking Republican in the House, said it was during Nixon's hourlong meeting Thursday with GOP members of Congress that he was handed the letter ending 11 ``psychologically difficult'' months. The letter said the committee had dismissed ethics complaints brought by Rep. Bill Alexander, D-Ark., against the Georgia lawmaker after he had caused the investigation that led to the resignation of former Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas. The committee, however, criticized Gingrich for not reporting on his annual financial disclosure forms that he had co-signed the mortgage on his daughter's home. It also criticized Gingrich for his staff's use of official letterhead to promote a private company's senior citizens cruise. But on each of Alexander's major allegations of misconduct, the committee said it found that ``no adequate basis'' existed to launch a full-scale ethics investigation. Most of the allegations focused on a partnership Gingrich created in 1984 to promote a book he helped write, ``Window of Opportunity.'' Alexander contended Gingrich had violated House rules on gifts and outside income, as well as federal campaign finance laws, with the partnership and book deal. The committee's letter capped Gingrich's meteoric rise _ in less than two years _ from a back-bench Republican firebrand to the leading contender to replace 67-year-old Republican leader Bob Michel when he retires. Along the way, Gingrich's tactics made him the target of choice for House Democrats. Gingrich compiled lists of Democrats he claimed should be investigated, he traveled the country denouncing ``House Democratic corruption'' and he filed the complaint that led the ethics committee to charge Wright with 69 violations of House rules, including charges that he accepted $145,000 in gifts from a Fort Worth, Texas, business executive. As the ethics investigation grew more serious for Wright, House Republicans rewarded Gingrich by electing him whip last year when Dick Cheney left the job to become secretary of Defense. Democrats vowed revenge when Wright decided to resign last June. ``There's no question Democrats were mad as hell and wanted to pin him to the wall'' after Wright was forced from office, said Thomas Mann, a congressional scholar at the Brookings Institution. But Mann said Gingrich benefited both from the changed atmosphere in the House since Wright's resignation and from the apparent weakness of the charges. ``Politically motivated charges aren't going to go anywhere unless there's something really there to begin with and unless the overall atmosphere that made it possible remains the same,'' he said. When he resigned, Wright called for an end to ``mindless cannibalism,'' and the new Democratic leadership team moved to reduce the partisan tone in the House. But Gingrich said he's convinced the committee would have reached the same conclusion in his case anyway. ``On item after item after item, they said there is no grounds for these charges,'' Gingrich said. ``So my presumption is that even in a more intensely partisan environment, the truth beats passion in the end.'' With the ethics case resolved in Gingrich's favor, Mann predicted, Democrats likely will reorient their campaign but not abandon it. ``They still want to get him, but I think it will switch from ethics and legal wars to political wars,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Cautions Travel to Haiti
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Saturday advised U.S. citizens to avoid travel to Haiti because of political unrest there. ``In view of continuing civil disturbances in various parts of Haiti, the Department of State recommends that American citizens defer all non-essential travel to Haiti at this time,'' a department statement said. The department said that although there did not appear to be any threat to Americans in Haiti, U.S. citizens should exercise caution and avoid crowds and areas affected by current unrest. The department said U.S. citizens who do travel to Haiti should register upon arrival with the consular section of the American Embassy.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor, who sued Delta Air Lines for $10 million after she was ejected from a flight for letting her dogs roam free, has had her lawsuit tossed out of court for the moment, a federal judge said Saturday. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler said Miss Gabor's attorneys can refile the complaint once they fix its flaws. Miss Gabor sued alleging negligence, defamation and assault and battery after she was removed from Flight 462 while stopping in Atlanta en route from Los Angeles to West Palm Beach on Jan. 6, 1989. A flight attendant and the pilot asked their first-class passenger to put her dogs Genghis Kahn and Macho Man in her carry-on kennel, but she refused. ``You know Zsa Zsa. She'll speak her mind,'' said her lawyer, Donald Norton. ``She told the stewardess what she thought of her.'' Norton said only one dog was loose and that the argument was over Miss Gabor's refusal to put a jewel-filled Gucci bag in an overhead compartment. In Atlanta, a Delta vice president boarded the Boeing 767 to ask again, but the airline said she rejected the requests with ``considerable vulgarity'' and was escorted off the flight by a police officer. The incident occurred before Miss Gabor's celebrated run-in with a Beverly Hills motorcycle officer on June 14. She is appealing a three-day jail sentence; and the officer is suing her for $10 million, charging slander, emotional distress and assault and battery.

Teen-age actor Corey Feldman was arrested for alleged heroin possession after several balloons containing the drug were found in his car, police said. Feldman, 18, was booked for investigation of possessing narcotics late Friday, said police Sgt. Thomas Jones, adding the quantity of heroin was described as ``numerous balloons'' _ the street packaging for the drug. Feldman, who has appeared in such films as ``The Goonies,'' ``Dream A Little Dream'' and ``The Bad News Bears'' TV series, was released on bail early Saturday. Details of the arrest following a traffic stop were not disclosed, although Jones said Feldman was the only person in the car.

A weapons charge has been dropped against New York Mets outfielder Darryl Strawberry, who finished a 27-day stay in an alcohol rehabilitation clinic earlier this month, prosecutors said. The charge, which stemmed from a domestic dispute in January, will not be prosecuted because of insufficient evidence. A further charge of spousal battery will not be filed, City Attorney James K. Hahn said. Strawberry, 27, was booked for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon on Jan. 26 after a dispute with his wife at their Encino home. Police said Lisa Strawberry, 25, accused her husband of threatening her with a gun that was registered to her. However, she later told the city attorney's office she did not want her husband to be prosecuted. Strawberry, who is participating in the Mets Assistance Program, has agreed to provide prosecutors with biweekly written progress reports for three months, while continuing alcohol counseling and beginning family counseling, Hahn said. The decision not to prosecute was reached after hearings involving Strawberry's wife and her mother, Virginia Andrews, and an ``especially frank'' discussion with Strawberry, the city attorney's office said.

Actor Ralph Waite, who played the Blue Ridge Mountains patriarch on the long-running television series ``The Waltons,'' wants a seat in Congress. Waite, 61, of Rancho Mirage filed papers Thursday to enter the 37th Congressional District race. The self-described moderate Democrat hopes to unseat Republican Rep. Al McCandless of La Quinta. Waite said he hoped to capitalize on his role as John Walton in the family series that ran from 1972 to 1980, to sway a heavily Republican district. ``I'm glad for that background and image,'' Waite said. He said he will probably need $900,000 to beat McCandless, a four-term congressman who has handily defeated all opponents since his election in 1982. There are two other Democratic candidates in the race, Johnny Pearson of the Lake Elsinore area and Jeffrey Jacobs of Moreno Valley. The district covers most of Riverside County.

DOC.HEAD: Weighty Issues Not Only Thing on Congressional Minds
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 15-17 pvs, bgng: Dante Fascell, to CORRECT references to `this week' and further identify Duran. Picks up 18th graf pvs, `Sen. John
DOC.TEXT: Liz Taylor, Roberto Duran and a pack of marauding mussels all came to Congress this past week, in one form or another. If you thought your representatives spent all week on such weighty matters as aid for Eastern Europe and the Clean Air bill, think again. Most members of Congress devote only a small portion of their days to such pursuits. Just as many hours, and usually many more, are spent on keeping constituents happy, getting one's picture or name mentioned in the hometown or national press, attending receptions, and lavishing praise on colleagues and witnesses. A typical two-hour congressional hearing, for example, will devote 20 minutes or so to rituals of accolade. The Democratic chairman of the committee praises a colleague for helping prepare the session; the ranking Republican praises the chairman for holding the hearing; the members praise the witness _ an administration official or specialist of some sort _ for his or her work on the subject, and so on. With some 250 committees and subcommittees in Congress, the 100 Senate members and their 435 colleagues in the House are busy people. Most sit on three or four committees, which is where most congressional action is taken. Except during floor votes, the main chambers of the House and Senate are virtually empty, with only a speaker on the podium and a stray clerk or usher in the aisles. More often than not, lawmakers will stay away from a plenary session to make time for a meeting with constituents visiting Washington. After all, these are the people who will get them re-elected. On a recent day, Rep. Dave McCurdy's schedule had 15 constituent visits. Aides to the Oklahoma Democrat say this is an unusally heavy load, although not rare. McCurdy and his colleagues also have to travel to their home districts periodically to meet with voters and tend to local business. Last year, McCurdy flew home 11 times. No wonder, then, that much of the work on Capitol Hill gets accomplished by staff members rather than by the lawmakers themselves. Most members have a staff of about 20, although some _ especially if they chair influential committees _ have double that. In all, Congress employs about 20,000 people _ including security police, cleaners and clerks. While visits by foreign visitors _ presidents, prime ministers and the like _ usually get bigger headlines, American celebrities are often a much bigger draw at the Capitol itself. Elizabeth Taylor came to Capitol Hill to lobby for a bill that would give $600 million to AIDS sufferers. Although Congress has been discussing the proposed bill for weeks, Miss Taylor's appearance at a hearing and a news conference drew dozens of lawmakers eager to shake her hand or stare into her famous violet eyes. ``It took Elizabeth Taylor to get you to one of my hearings,'' the panel's chairman, California Rep. Barbara Boxer, admonished her Democratic colleague from Illinois, Richard Durbin. Dante Fascell, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, made time last week for boxer Roberto Duran. The former welterweight champion came to Congress to seek aid for his native Panama, food for hungry children and housing for Panamanians left homeless by the U.S. invasion last December. And then there were the marauding mollusks. Reporters on Capitol Hill, sifting through their mail boxes, pulled out a plastic bag stuffed with mussel shells appended to a press release. ``Sen. John Glenn and Rep. Henry Nowak today proposed a $40 million plan to control the zebra mussel, the small shellfish attacking water intake pipes and creating environmental problems in the Great Lakes,'' the release said. Glenn was joined at a news conference by seven lawmakers battling the spread of the mollusks, which reached the Great Lakes by stowing away on freighters from Europe. ``I can tell you it's no joke,'' Glenn said.

DOC.HEAD: Recall Election Highlights Growth, Leadership Issues
DOC.TEXT: A recall election on Tuesday, the second time in a month residents will cast ballots, is shaping up as a battle between old-timers who favor slow growth and newcomers who say development is vital to the economy. Voters must decide whether to recall four-term Mayor Bill Stirling and three other city councilmen _ Steve Crockett, Frank Peters and Michael Gassman. Their critics say the four run a confrontational and unprofessional government and have done little to solve pressing housing and traffic problems. Also, they have been accused of being rude to constituents and promoting favorite causes _ as in Stirling's widely publicized campaign to ban fur sales, which failed in an election Feb. 13. The four members of the five-member council drew the ire of many when they opposed a large-scale Ritz-Carlton Hotel at the base of Aspen mountain. Residents voted 60 percent to 40 percent in February to let developer Mohamed Hadid build a 292-room, 66-foot-tall, $70 million luxury hotel. Stirling and his supporters on the council wanted to scale back the hotel's size by 25 percent and down to 44 feet high. The slow-growth advocates who have dominated city and county politics for decades fear they are becoming suddenly unfashionable. Voter approval of the hotel ``was a real big departure _ an aberration,'' said Michael Kinsley, a Pitkin County commissioner from 1975 to 1985. ``For the last several years, nobody has been elected to office who explicitly favored growth. And this election approved a major hotel.'' Kinsley, who had favored the scaled-back hotel plan, attributed the vote to intensive lobbying and campaign spending by Hadid. The strongest supporters of the hotel came from more recent arrivals to Aspen, from the wealthy, and from people who call themselves moderates or conservatives, according to an Aspen Times Daily exit poll Feb. 13. About 70 percent of the town's 3,700 registered voters turned out for that election. Supporters of the larger hotel plan say voters simply recognized the reality that Aspen has become a world-class resort. ``This town's 15 years behind the times as far as accommodations,'' said Don Kopf, 61, a contractor who passes out recall buttons. He believes the City Council has failed to direct growth and has let the housing problem reach crisis dimensions. ``Government should be run like a business, not like a fraternity,'' he said. Kopf accuses those in power of trying to close the door on future development. ``It's an attitude that, `I've got mine, you can't have yours.''' Carol Craig, an Aspenite for 34 years and a volunteer at the Thrift Shop, opposed both the larger hotel and a measure approved by voters to widen and straighten Highway 82 into town. She says the roads should be closed to cars entirely. ``That would preserve the essence of Aspen,'' she says. ``People come here for the beauty and the security of the place.'' In the recall election, voters will vote first on whether to recall each councilman, then may vote on a candidate to replace him. Stirling's post is being sought by Wainwright Dawson, 54, a management consultant and former Stirling aide; and Terry Butler, who lost to Stirling in last year's mayoral race. Rick Head, Margot Pendleton, Augie Reno and Ward Hauenstein seek to serve the remaining three years of Crockett's and Peters' terms. Marcia Goshorn is running to replace Gassman, whose term is up this fall. Of the four subjected to a recall, Crockett is considered the most vulnerable. Critics say he made fun of a speaker at a city council meeting. He also was accused of calling tourists ``parasites'' on national television, but provided videotape disproving that charge. His accusers, however, refuse to apologize. Stirling, who departed from his usual laid-back style and began taking out newspaper ads a month before this election, said there's a new rancor in Aspen than goes beyond the spirited debate that always has characterized the town. Pitkin County Sheriff Bob Braudis agrees. ``Several issues have driven a wedge between 30-year friends here. There's a mean-spiritedness that's descended on this little valley here that's new to us.'' Judy Gerbaz, who manages the Thrift Shop, says she's weary of the infighting: ``Even the school board meetings in this town are wild.'' Still, she takes pride in Aspen's argumentative and progressive spirit. ``Some say we're a laughingstock, but I think we're educating the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem Mayor Blames Bush for Tensions in City
LaserPhotos JRL1, JRL2
DOC.TEXT: Jerusalem's mayor Saturday blamed recent statements by President Bush for raising tensions in the city, which over the weekend experienced some of its worst violence in the Palestinian uprising. Israeli police shot and killed two Palestinians in a refugee camp of Arab east Jerusalem on Friday night, sparking riots Saturday. Israeli leaders recently restated their claim to the Arab sector of Jerusalem, despite recent U.S. statements that the status of the land is in dispute and should be resolved by negotiation. Israel captured east Jerusalem and the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. It has since annexed east Jerusalem, home to 140,000 Palestinians, and has been building Jewish neighborhoods around the Arab enclave to strengthen its hold on the land. Both Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III said in the past 10 days that Israel's policy of settling Jews in the occupied lands, including east Jerusalem, was an impediment to peace. ``We do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or east Jerusalem,'' Bush said at a news conference March 3. Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem called Bush's remarks untimely and unjustified. ``I feel offended by lack of knowledge about what is going on here on part of very important people who are our friends who have no idea what's happening,'' the mayor said on Israel radio. He said that on one hand Bush supported the unity of the city and the right of Jews to live there, but on the other he referred to Jewish neighborhoods in east Jerusalem as settlements. This, he said, ``is inconsistent with the facts.'' Kollek also said Palestinian frustration over the lack of progress in peace efforts was mounting in advance of a debate Sunday in the inner Cabinet. The left-leaning Labor Party and the right-wing Likud bloc will once again attempt to reach a decision on whether to accept U.S. proposals for holding peace talks in Cairo. Violence erupted Friday night in the Shufat refugee camp in Arab east Jerusalem, the only camp within Jerusalem's city limits. Residents said police opened fire that night and again Saturday morning to quell stone-throwing demonstrations. Camp residents and U.N. officials identified the victims as Mahmud Fawzi Abu Khalife, 21, and Sufian Mohammed Abdullah Khalil, 25. They said at least two other Palestinians were wounded, one critically. Police spokesman Uzi Sandori confirmed one dead and two wounded. He said the man was killed when 40 masked youths charged police with iron bars Saturday morning. About a dozen camp residents were detained for questioning, he said. It was some of the worst violence in the city since the uprising against Israeli rule began in December 1987. The deaths raised to 662 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli troops or civilians in the uprising. Forthy-three Israelis also have been killed. Word of the deaths sparked rioting in east Jerusalem. Police dispersed students who had overturned a vehicle and hurled stones at passing cars, Sandori said. Later, about 400 Israeli and Palestinian women held a peaceful rally along the border where east and west Jerusalem meet. They called on Israel to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization and halt Jewish settlements in occupied lands. In the Gaza Strip, Arab reports said masked assailants killed a Palestinian man, Ibrahim el-Batnaje, with axes and daggers for allegedly collaborating with Israeli authorities. His death brought to 195 the number of Palestinians slain by their fellow Arabs on suspicion of collaborating with Israel.

DOC.SECOND: Government Increases Casualty Toll From Failed Coup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KAB1
DOC.TEXT: The government acknowledged Saturday that civilian casualties in last week's coup attempt were almost four times higher than originally reported. Government spokesman Naqib Sameer said 70 more bodies of civilians were pulled from the rubble of destroyed buildings, bringing the death toll to 95. President Najib orignally said 25 civilians died during the fighting Tuesday and Wednesday. No figures were released Saturday for military casualties. A Western military expert estimated hundreds of officers and elite commandos died when Afghan warplanes bombed the capital, causing extensive damage to the city of 2 million. The military also appeared have suffered heavy material losses. At least 10 jet fighters and 15 tanks were believed destroyed, government and diplomatic sources said. The government has said it shot down three rebel planes. Meanwhile, Eastern European diplomatic sources and one Afghan government official provided some insight into the failure of the coup, which was launched Tuesday by Defense Minister Shah Nawaz Tanai, a hard-line Communist. According to their statements, forces from the Afghan intelligence agency surrounded two renegade tank corps late Monday amid indications a coup might be attempted. This prevented critical ground suport for Tanai when the assault began Tuesday. One corps was bottled up near Pulcharki prison on the outskirts of Kabul and another tank unit was surrounded behind the Defense Ministry. Only two tanks from the unit near Pulcharki broke free Tuesday. They attacked the military university near the prison but were soon destroyed, the Eastern European source said. The renegades were limited to air strikes on the capital. Although the strikes were bloody and destructive, they were not enough to unseat Najib. The trapped tanks, coupled with the army's use of destructive Scud missiles against mutineers, appeared to have been central in quelling the coup. A Western diplomat in Islamabad said the prompt smashing of Tanai's communications network also hurt the defense minister's plot. By Wednesday, most of the fighting was over, although rebels and diplomats in Islamabad claimed fighting went on until Friday. On Saturday, Kabul was calm except for two rockets, apparently fired by Moslem rebels who have been fighting the Soviet-backed Kabul government for 12 years. Six people were injured, Sameer said. Government figrures released Saturday showed four bazaars, nine restaurants, 230 shops, 18 buildings and 282 apartments were destroyed during the coup attempt. ``Hundreds of residential houses and public facilities were also damaged,'' Sameer said. A purge of forces loyal to Tanai continued Saturday. Government sources reported arrests among officials in the state television station and among lower-ranking officers in the military and the security forces. Five members of the ruling Politburo, five members of the National Defense Council and two members of the Central Committee of the ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan have been purged, Bakhtar News Agency reported. One Eastern European source, quoting Afghan government officials, said more than 2,000 people were jailed Wednesday and Thursday. The reports could not be independently confirmed. Of the arrests, Sameer would say only, ``We have arrested a number of people involved in the coup plot and will continue to arrest others.'' The losses of men and equipment appeared likely to weaken the fighting strength of the Afghan army, which remains locked in civil war with the U.S.-backed rebels, the Western military expert said. The Afghan air force, which was the center of the coup attempt, has been credited in large part with helping Najib survive since the Kremlin ended nine years of military intervention in February 1989. But it also seemed unlikely guerrilla forces would be able to capitalize on the chaos. They remained in relative disunity, diplomats based in Kabul said. Afghan government radio and television continued to link Tanai's plot to fundamentalist rebel leader Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, but diplomats in Kabul said they believed the rebel leader had nothing to do with the operation. Hekmatyar has said, however, he supports the coup and is reportedly involved in negotiations with Tanai supporters. Tanai fled to Pakistan on Wednesday and then allied himself with Hekmatyar.

DOC.HEAD: High Spending, Low Blows Mark Texas Gubernatorial Primary
DOC.TEXT: Barraged by drug questions, death penalty claims and million-dollar television advertising, Texas voters go to the polls Tuesday to cast their primary election ballots for governor. The Democratic primary _ pitting Treasurer Ann Richards, Attorney General Jim Mattox and former Gov. Mark White _ is especially bitter. Republican hopefuls are scrambling to hold oilman Clayton Williams under the 50 percent mark he needs to avoid an April runoff election. The races appeared headed toward an all-time state spending record for a gubernatorial primary. Together, the top three Democrats and top four Republicans spent $25 million through March 5. A Dallas Morning News-Houston Chronicle poll conducted last week showed the Democrats in a dead heat and Williams widening his already substantial lead over the Republican pack. The poll, to be published in the newspapers' Sunday editions, showed 28 percent of those surveyed backed Ms. Richards, while Mattox had 25 percent and White garnered 24 percent. But the poll's margin of error of 4.5 percentage points meant it was too close to call. The Democratic race was so contentious that Mattox, whose own slogan was ``Texas Tough,'' decried what he called the ``cannibalism'' of his party's infighting. Ms. Richards, a rising Democratic star after her keynote speech at the party's 1988 national convention, found herself under siege from opponents and the news media after repeatedly refusing to say whether she ever used illegal drugs. ``This question was never raised in the eight years that I was managing a portfolio of $4 billion a day. It was only when I got in the way of these two boys who want to be governor that it came up,'' she said. A recovering alcoholic, Ms. Richards said she hadn't used a ``mood-altering chemical'' in 10 years, and she accused both White and Mattox of profiteering from public service. ``They've got the best resumes money can buy,'' Ms. Richards said, suggesting that besides a drug test, the candidates should take lie-detector tests as well. Mattox called on her to ``stop running the down-in-the-gutter type of campaign you're running.'' White and Mattox sparred with each other over the death penalty. Mattox aired television commercials claiming he was responsible for the executions of 32 felons. White, governor from 1983 to 1987, responded with an ad that showed him walking past giant photos of criminals put to death during his tenure, saying, ``Only a governor can make executions happen. I did. And I will.'' The Republicans dueled more politely, with pundits predicting that the colorful and popular ``Claytie'' will coast to victory. ``The question is not, `Will Williams fall under 50 (percent),' but `Will he get over 60?''' said Richard Murray, director of the poll for the newspapers by the Public Policy Center at the University of Houston. Williams' nearest rival, Railroad Commissioner Kent Hance, nonetheless predicted a runoff. A former Democrat and congressman, Hance said he would quit politics if he didn't win the GOP nomination. Williams, a Midland businessman so popular that his campaign appearances drew autograph seekers, said he hoped to avoid a runoff so he could turn his guns on the Democrats. ``As a Republican, it would be much better for our party if I were able to make it without a runoff,'' he said. He has spent $8 million on the campaign _ $6 million out of his own pocket _a record for one candidate in a Texas gubernatorial primary. The Williams campaign dominated the television airwaves with lavishly produced commercials. His final ad showed him wearing a cowboy hat and standing in front of a chuck wagon, talking about the spirit of Texas. ``I'm a fourth-generation Texan and I'm very proud of it,'' he tells the camera. ``We sure as heck haven't lost that spirit.'' Besides Hance, two other GOP hopefuls aimed at a runoff. Dallas lawyer Tom Luce, an associate of billionaire H. Ross Perot, won endorsements from most of the state's largest newspapers for offering detailed programs on such issues as education and the environment. But confronted with Williams' slick TV performances, Luce said perhaps he could have used a ``charisma transplant'' to compete. Former Secretary of State Jack Rains was counting on a big vote in his hometown of Houston to carry him after winning praise as a skillful orator in three debates televised statewide. While the governor's race monopolized the public's attention, Tuesday's primary ballots also will include dozens of other races _ from the U.S. Senate to the state Legislature. In the Senate race, Republican Phil Gramm is uncontested. On the Democratic side, state Sen. Hugh Parmer of Fort Worth faces a Lyndon LaRouche supporter, Harley Schlanger of Houston. Secretary of State George Bayoud and the two party chairmen have predicted that about 25 percent of the state's 8.3 million registered voters will cast ballots. GOP turnout is forecast at 750,000 to 1 million, while Democratic turnout is estimated at 1.4 million to 1.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Government Increases Death Toll in Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0532.

DOC.HEAD: Bight and Brief
DOC.TEXT: A state lawmaker flying south for a Florida vacation this month will hold ``office hours'' in two cocktail lounges there for constituents who are spending the winter in that state. ``Just because these folks spend the winter away from the North Country does not mean that they do not need to be represented,'' said Rep. Jeff Woodburn, a 24-year-old Democrat from Whitefield in northern New Hampshire. A news release Friday said the first-term lawmaker will hold a series of informal ``office hours'' March 26th at 2 p.m. at Perry's Ocean Edge Lounge in Daytona Beach and March 31 at 4 p.m. in the Elbow Room in Fort Lauderdale. ``It was sort of a nice Friday afternoon joke,'' Woodburn said Saturday. ``I don't expect anybody will show up, but ... you never know.'' Woodburn, who was planning to vacation in Florida that week, said he often holds office hours in local bars or restaurants in his district, and at least 300 of his 6,000 or 7,000 constituents spend the winter in Florida. Woodburn said he would not collect mileage or expenses from the state for his trip.

Louie the Llama doesn't have to be a follower any more. The 5-month-old, 72-pound South American ruminant had cataracts removed from his right eye in an operation that lets him to see for the first time. Dr. James Clinton, the Medford veterinarian who performed the 50-minute surgery Thursday, said Louie's history suggests the llama could not see because he never started any activities with fellow animals. ``This one always followed,'' Clinton said. ``It never led.'' Louie is recovering at Popcorn Park Zoo, home to about 300 injured or abandoned animals ranging from chickens to deer, said zoo director John Bergmann. With cataracts, the crystalline lens of the eye becomes opaque, blocking light rays instead of refracting them. The surgeon removes the lens, leaving the cornea, the transparent tissue over the front of the eyeball. Clinton compared the crystalline lens to a fine-tuning instrument. He said its removal results in about 90 percent vision. Clinton, an eye specialist whose prior patients have included owls and a leopard, said Louie was his first llama. Clinton operated on just one eye because the surgery prompts a release of a protein that causes inflammation. Most animals can see well enough with one eye but Louie could get surgery in his left eye after 16 weeks, Clinton said. Bergmann is checking on how Louie is faring with eyesight for the first time. ``Last night, it moved away from us for the first time when we brought it food,'' Bergmann said Friday.

The U.S. District Court that serves Georgia's Southern District has become the first in the nation to get its own flag. The red, white and blue flag, designed by Clerk Henry R.
