Crumley Jr. and given official recognition in a Dec. 8 court order by Chief Judge Anthony A. Alaimo, will be displayed in each federal courtroom in the 43-county district. David Sellers, spokesman for the Washington administrative office of all U.S. courts, said Friday that he knows of no other court district in the nation that has its own flag. Crumley said he and Alaimo felt the judiciary, as the third branch of government, should have its own flag. Most federal agencies already have flags. His court flag has a white stripe through the middle, separating its red top and blue bottom. In the center is the Great Seal of the United States. Curved above the seal are the words, ``United States Courts,'' and below are the words ``Southern District of Georgia.'' Crumley said the red symbolizes the blood that has been shed to preserve the judicial system, the white, the purity of the system and the blue, the commitment of the courts to upholding the law. ``People who have seen it think it's beautiful,'' said Crumley.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Northwest Crew Loses Licenses
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials have revoked the licenses of three Northwest Airlines flight crew members accused of flying under the influence of alcohol. ``Safety and alcohol do not mix,'' said Federal Aviation Administration Administrator James B. Busey, in a swift action that he said Friday should serve as a lesson to other crews. Capt. Norman Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga., first officer Robert J. Kirchner, 35, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and second officer Joseph W. Balzer, 34, of Antioch, Tenn., were arrested Thursday when Northwest Flight 650, a Boeing 727 with 91 passengers aboard, arrived without incident in Minneapolis from Fargo, N.D., airport police said. FAA officials had received an anonymous call indicating that the three had been drinking in the Fargo area Wednesday night, said Alan Muncaster, a Northwest spokesman. Minnesota law prohibits flying with a blood-alcohol level above 0.04 percent. The case will be referred to the city attorney's office by Tuesday, said Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport police chief Jim Welna. Busey said the crew had violated the Minnesota law and federal rules against flying within eight hours of drinking alcohol. ``We will take equally forceful action against any other airman who violates the agency's regulations against alcohol,'' Busey said. Violation of the agency's alcohol rules ``is not common at all,'' said FAA spokesman Bob Buckhorn. Buckhorn said Busey acted after the three crew members were reported by an FAA inspector to have been flying within eight hours of drinking, being under the influence of alcohol and having blood-alcohol concentrations greater than 0.04 percent. The three crew members have the right to appeal their emergency license revocations within 10 days to the National Transportation Safety Board. Kirchner and Balzer have not returned phone calls and Prouse has an unlisted number. The Air Line Pilots Association issued a statement expressing its support for a ``100 percent alcohol- and drug-free cockpit on every flight'' and called any deviation from that standard as an ``extremely rare anomaly.'' Bob Gibbons, another spokesman for Eagan-based Northwest, said that the airline was conducting its own investigation to see whether the crew had violated the company's rule against drinking within 12 hours before a flight. The three men were removed from flight duty, he said. ``Upon the completion of our investigation they could be subjected to discipline which could be as severe as discharge from the company,'' he said. Northwest spokesmen were silent on specifics of the case pending the outcome of the investigation, but promised to make public the outcome and suggested that the matter may be settled next week. FAA records show that since 1984, the industry has recorded 237 incidents of drug and alcohol abuse by crew members, including 126 in which licenses were revoked. The rest were suspensions of 30 days to a year. At least six involved major carriers, but none appeared to involve Northwest. Friday also marked the last day for comments to the U.S. Transportation Department as it debates whether to formally introduce a new rule allowing random testing of essential transportation-system workers for alcohol abuse. Drug testing in the airline industry, including pilots and mechanics at Northwest, began Jan. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Ten Killed in Factional Fighting
LaserPhoto JHB1
DOC.TEXT: At least 10 people were killed overnight in clashes related to black factional fighting, police said Saturday. Authorities arrested about 140 people for protesting or looting as the government clamped down on unrest. Nine people were killed in black factional fighting in various areas and a police officer was killed by gunmen, a police report said. The worst unrest was in the black township of Kathlehong outside Johannesburg, where three new deaths brought the toll in a week of factional violence to at least 22. Scores of people have been injured. South Africa has been hit by a wave of violent unrest that has claimed about 200 lives during the past month. The unrest is regarded as the worst to hit the country since the mid-1980s. The government threatened to use emergency measures to end it. Police arrested about 80 people in Cape Town on Saturday for taking part in a protest to demand the release of political prisoners. Police declared the march illegal and moved in after about 300 protesters attempted to march with signs saying: ``Release Political Prisoners.'' Authorities in Bophuthatswana, a black homeland north of Johannesburg, said they arrested about 60 people Saturday for looting and taking part in protests Feb. 5 and 6. South African police also reported a number of minor clashes with protesters in various areas. Officers fired shotguns, tear gas and rubber bullets, but no serious injuries were reported. The Star newspaper reported Saturday that the government is considering further measures to halt the unrest, and more arrests are expected. The violence has stemmed from various causes, including black factional fighting and unrest in the tribal homelands. In Kathlehong, a fight between rival taxi companies in the township exploded into a major factional fight last week. Hundreds of residents have fled the area. The South African Police sent extra units into the area to protect residents, police said. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told Parliament Friday the government was prepared to use its extensive powers under the 3{-year-old state of emergency to quell the violence. The emergency regulations allow police to detain suspects for up to six months without charge, ban protests, and bar journalists and the general public from protests and areas of unrest. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party charged the government is responsible for the violence. Opposition leaders said President F.W. de Klerk's decision to legalize the African National Congress and other opposition groups encouraged radicals to attempt to seize power. Walter Sisulu, an ANC leader, said Friday the government was reverting ``to the old approach of looking for scapegoats and hidden `instigators.''' ``The primary reason for the unrest, conflict and confrontation has always been the poverty and violence caused by apartheid,'' he said. Under apartheid, the black majority has no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Weapon Detonated in Nevada Underground Test
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. nuclear weapon test of 1990 rocked the Nevada desert Saturday, the same day a published report said the Soviet Union is phasing out testing on its mainland because of citizens' safety concerns. The Washington Post reported that the Soviet Union would move its nuclear testing site from south-central Asia to an island inside the Arctic Circle. It cited sources it did not name in the Soviet Union and the United States. The tested weapon, code-named Metropolis, was detonated at the bottom of a 1,500-foot shaft at Yucca Flat at the remote Nevada Test Site. The device was listed as having an explosive force of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT, but was believed to be near the upper limits because of warnings issued in advance by the Energy Department. The test registered 5.1 on the Richter scale at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., according to spokesman John Minsch. Seismic equipment atop Fitzgerald's Hotel and Casino in downtown Las Vegas, 85 miles away, registered slight motion from the blast. ``There's definitely ground motion,'' DOE spokesman Chris West said by telephone from a control point 12 miles from ground zero, where the test was monitored by video camera. ``It's a little like sitting in a rowboat in the water; there's a mild rocking motion,'' West said. He said 11 anti-nuclear weapons protesters turned out at a gate about 30 miles from ground zero shortly before the 8 a.m. detonation. Two protesters were arrested on trespassing charges. The Washington Post said the Soviets had decided to phase out nuclear testing at their main testing grounds at Seimipalatinsk, in south-central Asia, and halt testing there by 1993. The Soviets plan to shift their testing program to Novaya Zemlya, a large island in the Barents Sea within the Arctic Circle, the sources told the paper. A Russian anti-nuclear group named Nevada has been campaigning to halt testing at Semipalatinsk, complaining of radiation leaks from the underground tests. ``The Soviets have had a second major test site for many years, and have done a lot of testing there,'' West said Saturday. ``The Soviets are not stopping testing but are just moving to another location. The U.S. doesn't have the luxury of a backup site.'' Metropolis was the 700th announced test conducted in Nevada since testing began at the desert site in 1951. The last test was Dec. 20.

DOC.HEAD: Former Publisher of ``Who's Who'' Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Jackson Martindell, a management consultant and former publisher of Who's Who in America, has died of cancer. He was 89. Martindell, who died Wednesday, was born in Amarillo, Texas, and was a graduate of the University of Colorado and Columbia University. He served in the Army's American Expeditionary Force during World War I. By 1932, Martindell was in New York City and had founded Fiduciary Counsel Inc., which advised prominent business families. He also was treasurer of the Marshall Field Foundation. Over the next two decades, Martindell made a reputation as a banker, financier, consultant and economic adviser. After World War II, he worked as a U.S. government volunteer to help the Yugoslavian government re-establish that nation's economy. In 1948 he married Anne Clark, who later became a New Jersey state senator and U.S. ambassador to New Zealand. In 1949, Martindell founded the New American Institute of Management, which developed the ``management audit'' technique to assess business leadership. For many years, he ran the company from his Fort Lauderdale home. In 1956, he became publisher of Marquis' Who's Who of Chicago, which published the annual Who's Who in America. He sold the publication to ITT in 1969 for a sum he described as ``fantastic'' and retired. He is survived by three sons and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some significant dates in Haiti's modern history: Oct. 22, 1957 - Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier becomes president in disputed election. April 1, 1964 _ Duvalier proclaims himself president for life. April 21, 1971 _ Duvalier dies and 19-year-old Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier becomes president. Feb. 7, 1986 _ Duvalier flees to exile in France after a month of anti-government unrest that leaves more than 50 people dead. A three-man junta led by Duvalier's army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, takes power. Oct. 19, 1986 _ Low participation in first national election in 30 years for a 41-member Constituent Assembly to write a new constitution. March 29, 1987 _ Voters overwhelmingly approve a new constitution putting elections for president and National Assembly in the hands of a civilian election commission. June 1987 _ Namphy's junta tries to take over elections. Haitians take to the streets and soldiers kill at least 30 armed demonstrators. Anti-government unrest and diplomatic pressure force junta to back down. Nov. 29, 1987 _ Election Day. Assassins protected by the army kill at least 34 voters and confiscate ballots. The election is called off three hours after it begins. Namphy and junta dissolve election commission. The United States suspends $78 million in aid in protest. Jan. 17, 1988 _ Leslie Manigat, a 57-year-old university professor, is elected president in newly scheduled elections. Few Haitians vote and most opposition leaders refuse to participate. June 19 _ Troops storm the National Palace, deposing Manigat and replacing him with Namphy. Namphy abolishes the National Assembly a day later. Sept. 17 _ Namphy is ousted in a coup led by noncommissioned officers and exiled in the neighboring Dominican Republic. Sept. 18 _ Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, chief of the Presidential Guard and a former Duvalier adviser, declares himself president. March 13, 1989 _ Avril partially restores the suspended 1987 constitution. March 28 _ Four high-ranking army officers are reportedly accused of drug trafficking and discharged. The action comes one day after a U.S. official links resumption of U.S. aid to progress in stopping the drug trade. April 2 _ Gunfire breaks out at the presidential palace. The government later says it has foiled a coup attempt by rebel officers. The U.S. Embassy says loyal Presidential Guards rescued Avril as he was being driven away to be deported. April 3 _ Avril goes on national television to announce the coup was unsuccessfull and says power-hungry soldiers were behind it. April 4 _ Government placates rebel soldiers by releasing and deporting three army officers who led the coup attempt against Avril. Jan. 20, 1990 _ Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril declares a 30-day state of siege after the mysterious killing of an army colonel. Fifty opposition leaders are arrested, jailed and reportedly beaten and tortured. Seven political leaders are exiled. Jan. 29 _ The government lifts the state of siege after the United States, France, Canada, Haiti's Roman Catholic Bishops and the 12-member European Community condemn the crackdown. Feb. 7 _ The military declares a general amnesty for all political prisoners on the fourth anniversary of the fall of Jean Claude Duvalier. Opposition leaders say they will boycott scheduled elections unless Avril first steps down. March 5 _ Rosaline Vaval, an 11-year-old schoolgirl studying on her porch, is killed by stray bullets fired by soldiers during an anti-government demonstration in the provincial town of Petit Goave. The killing sparks nationwide protests against Avril. March 10 _ Avril steps down as Haiti's leader, handing power to the army chief of staff, Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham. Abraham promises a provisional government led by a civilian will be named to organize elections.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Readies for Independence Vote
With AM-Gorbachev-Five Years, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's first freely elected parliament in 50 years convened Saturday night to prepare for a historic vote on independence from the Soviet Union. ``Tomorrow, the festival begins,'' said Longinas Vasiliauskas, a spokesman for the pro-independence Sajudis movement, which won a two-thirds majority of the deputies in the new parliament. The parliament, which votes Sunday on whether to secede, is the country's first legislature not dominated by Communists. Its deputies represent a variety of political parties, with no single party dominant. In municipal elections earlier this month, Sajudis backed candidates based on their views on democracy and independence, regardless of party. At the modern building housing the parliament, citizens and legislators sang the Lithuanian anthem as the session opened Saturday night. Outside, about 100 demonstrators waved the red-yellow-and-green flags of independent Lithuania and joked about the day when they would need passports to travel to Moscow. Inside, Lithuanian leaders stood in front of a huge banner depicting the Soviet star and the Communist Party's famous hammer-and-sickle emblem. Asked if the banner would be removed when Lithuania declares independence, activist Eduardas Potashinskas replied, ``That's easy. If only that were all that we had to change.'' Lithuania was an independent country between the two world wars. In 1940, Lithuania and the other Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, were forcibly annexed to the Soviet Union while under Red Army occupation. The bold move to declare Lithuania independent could present President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with his greatest crisis in five years in power. Gorbachev and other Soviet officials have indicated the Kremlin may grudgingly accept Lithuanian secession, but at a steep price. Specifically, Gorbachev has suggested a bill of $34 billion in compensation for factories and other infrastructures built during a half-century of Soviet rule. Lithuanians replied that their bill to the Soviet Union for decades of repression would be higher. The independence proposal is widely expected to pass Sunday, due to the commanding majority of seats won by Sajudis candidates who favor independence. Sajudis has already won 95 of 130 seats filled so far, said spokesman Haroldas Subachius. The last 11 races were being decided in run-offs Saturday and Sunday, but the new parliament chose to rush into session with a minimal quorum so it can vote on independence before Gorbachev is given broad new powers by the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies on Monday. Gorbachev is seeking the authority to declare a state of emergency on his own, which would include the power to suspend republic parliaments and take over administration of a republic. Progressives consider the proposed powers potentially dictatorial. Also high on the parliament's agenda is election of the Ireland-sized republic's two top leaders: the premier and the chairman of the Supreme Soviet legislature. The second slot is sometimes called the presidency, and Sajudis wants its own man in the job instead of the current Communist Party leader, Algirdas Brazauskas. A Sajudis council decided that because Communists are a minority in the new Lithuanian parliament, it would be unfitting to re-elect Brazauskas, activist Subachius said. Brazauskas enjoys widespread personal popularity because he led the Lithuanian Communists when they split from the Soviet party in December and joined the drive for independence. Sajudis probably will back one of its three leading figures for the post of president, activists said. Gorbachev's reforms have provoked strong pro-independence sentiments in many of the country's 15 republics. On Friday, the Georgian parliament passed a resolution condemning the republic's annexation to the Soviet Union, mirroring moves already made in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. The parliament will be asked to reaffirm an act first passed on Feb. 16, 1918 declaring the state independent. Lawmakers already have declared illegal Lithuania's incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940 under a secret Nazi-Soviet pact. Lawmakers also will be asked to restore the 1938 constitution that was swept away by Josef Stalin's Kremlin in favor of Soviet-style law. In remarks reported by the official Tass news agency, Lithuanian economist Bronislovas Zaikauskas said his homeland, poor in natural resources, could exploit its location on the Soviet Union's western fringe to become a ``trampoline'' for Western firms seeking entry to the Soviet market. However, Brazauskas has indicated the Kremlin might demand to retain control of the city of Klaipeda if Lithuania secedes. Klaipeda is the republic's main port.

DOC.HEAD: Troop Withdrawal Agreement Signed, Hungary Wants End of Mutual Aid Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and Hungary signed an agreement Saturday calling for all Red Army troops to be withdrawn from Hungary by the middle of next year, and Budapest proposed an end to the mutual assistance pact between the nations. The pact was the Soviet pretext for invading Hungary in 1956. Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn hinted it is time for the Soviets to apologize for that invasion. ``We must give a clear picture of the events of 1956 and the Soviet interference,'' he said. In December, the Soviets apologized for the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia. ``This is a new page in Hungarian history,'' Horn told a news conference after he and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze signed the troop withdrawal agreement. He credited Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new foreign policy for the agreement. It calls for all 49,700 Red Army soldiers and 27,146 military vehicles to start heading home Monday and to be out of Hungary entirely by June 30, 1991. The Soviets have already agreed to remove their 73,500 soldiers from Czechoslovakia by the same date. That means Moscow is committed to withdrawing 123,200 troops from countries on the East bloc's front line within 14 months. Horn said it is time to drop the ``obsolete'' mutual assistance pact, which the Soviets cited when their troops poured into Hungary in 1956 to crush its drive for democratic reforms. On March 25, Hungary will hold its first free national elections since the Communists consolidated power in 1948. ``The treaty of friendship and cooperation is obsolete,'' Horn said. ``We must now replace it with a joint statement reflecting changes in our bilateral relations and in the international sphere.'' ``We should get rid of the ideological elements still remaining in our relationship,'' he said, a clear reference to the Soviet Union's decades of forcing Communism on resisting Hungarians. The foreign minister said the Soviets have agreed to discuss the issue. In an interview with Hungarian radio, Horn also said he could see the possibility of NATO and the Warsaw Pact converging someday, if the East bloc continues to democratize. Asked if he preferred a united Germany to be neutral or a member of the Western alliance, Horn said bluntly: ``If the future Germany wants to remain a member of NATO, we should respond to that wish.'' He also said the wishes of all of Europe should be taken into account. Hungarian radio reported that the two governments are still negotiating on the property being left behind by the Soviet troops. The Soviets were reported to have preferred a final pullout date from Hungary of Aug. 31, 1991, giving them more time for dismantling military stockpiles. Hungarian military officials say the equipment includes 860 tanks and 1,500 armored personnel carriers. According to Hungarian radio, two-thirds of the withdrawal of Soviet troops and equipment is to be completed by the end of this year. Horn said the Hungarian side first brought up the troop issue two years ago and it was initialed Friday, in time for Horn's planned arrival Saturday for the signing ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Under House Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Gbagbo's phone no longer in service; pickup 4th graf pvs, `Gbagbo has...'
DOC.TEXT: An opposition leader was placed under house arrest Saturday after demanding multiparty democracy and expressing support for demonstrators protesting austerity measures. Soldiers surrounded Laurent Gbagbo's house and prevented reporters from entering. Gbagbo at first was allowed to make telephone calls. He said he was ordered to remain at the house after he returned from the French Embassy, where he was refused a visa to travel to France to participate in a television debate on African economies. But several hours after police arrived at his home, telephone callers received an announcement saying Gbago's number was no longer in service. Gbagbo has been under house arrest twice in the ast two years. He is a history professor who founded the unauthorized Ivorian Popular Front eight years ago and has been calling for multiparty elections. He also has said his party supports recent anti-government protests. The protests turned violent and produced the worst unrest in years in this normally peaceful country. Demonstrators, mainly university students, said the poor were being burdened with an unfair load of austerity measures. They demanded the ouster of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, accusing him of siphoning money from state coffers. Soldiers and police broke up protests with harsh beatings, tear gas and stun grenades. Many protesters were peaceful, but others stoned and burned cars and ransacked several stores. It is not known how many people were injured in the violence. Troops still patrol Abidjan, the capital, though there have been no demonstrations for a week. The government defused the unrest by promising to review planned austerity measures. Those measures would cut salaries of civil servants by up to 40 percent and charge a 10 percent austerity tax for some people. Authorities also have promised to cut prices of staple foods and rents on government housing. But World Bank and International Monetary Fund officials say wage cuts are necessary if Ivory Coast is to control an economic crisis rooted in slumping prices of cocoa and coffee, its main exports. Gbagbo has blamed the crisis on the ruling Democratic Party and Houphouet-Boigny, who has ruled the nation as a one-party state since its independence from France in 1960. Several of Gbagbo's supporters have been detained recently for distributing a newsletter calling for the peaceful creation of a multiparty democracy. The newsletter cost the equivalent of $2, but photocopies now are being sold for $7.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Sign Peace Pact, Then Hit Campaign Trail
DOC.TEXT: Former leaders of a leftist guerrilla group campaigned in mayoral and congressional races Saturday, just hours after signing a treaty with the government that ended their 16-year insurgency. President Virgilio Barco initialed the agreement with Carlos Pizarro, the commander of the April 19 Movement, or M19 rebel group, in a historic ceremony late Friday at the government palace. On Thursday, the estimated 1,800 members of M19 laid down their weapons in two towns in Colombia's southern mountains. The weapons, including automatic rifles, pistols and shotguns, were melted down to forge a monument to peace. The government agreed to create a fund to help develop rural areas, incorporate former guerrillas into civilian life, and create a commission to study the effects of cocaine trafficking on Colombia and other countries. Barco told reporters after signing the agreement that it had ``bolstered the hope of finding civilized paths for resolving conflicts and differences.'' But the president added that other leftist guerrilla groups were ``persisting in their terrorist actions against the Colombian people.'' He reiterated his willingness to negotiate with the organizations. Two other rebel groups, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the People's Liberation Army, have continued attacking police and military targets. Another leftist guerrilla group, the National Liberation Army, has said it will never enter peace talks. It has carried out a campaign of kidnappings and other terrorism to disrupt Sunday's balloting. Colombians in all regions will elect all 313 members of the nation's bicameral legislature, 9,042 city councilmen, 1,009 mayors, and 421 state assembly members. The governing Liberal Party also will nominate the candidate it will back in the May presidential election. The government has said that only a few southern and northeastern towns are threatened by the National Liberation Army offensive and that elections will not be suspended in any of country's 1,009 municipalities. Pizarro is running as the M19's candidate in Bogota's mayoral race and many and his former comrades in arms are seeking congressional seats. Political analysts give them little chance of winning, but government sources say that Pizarro may act as an official mediator between the government and other leftist guerrilla groups in any future peace talks.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Parties Ask for Delayed Elections
DOC.TEXT: Major opposition parties Saturday demanded a delay in May elections to allow more time to challenge the post-revolutionary leadership, which has been attacked for its ties to the old regime. The demand represents the first time the fractious opposition has openly pooled its forces to stop the National Salvation Front's bid for long-term power. The National Peasants' Party and the National Liberal Party, the two largest opposition groups, joined forces with smaller parties in seeking the election postponement in a letter to interim President Ion Iliescu. They did not say when the letter would be sent. However, the government has reacted with scorn to previous demands for a delay in elections. ``They are idiots,'' government spokesman Cristian Unteanu said recently. The vote is set for May 20, but the opposition wants more time to build up electoral momentum against the dominant National Salvation Front. Many of its members have been assailed for having held posts in the government of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was toppled in a bloody revolution in December. A draft of the opposition's letter to Iliescu said Romanians are not ready for democratic elections because they don't know the true state of the nation's devastated economy. The country's rulers gained some economic maneuvering room Saturday, though, as four strikes were reportedly settled. The actions involved Bucharest subway workers, 15 Carpathian coal mines, pilots and sailors in the Black Sea port of Constanta and public transport workers in the Danube port city of Galati, according to Bucharest Radio. The opposition also argued in its letter that May elections would hurt the nation's agricultural sector by distracting workers from the vital spring planting. However, the primary reason for seeking postponement clearly is opposition fears that the National Salvation Front would have an unassailable lead in elections as early as May. The Front has dominated Romanian politics and government since the December revolution. The 150-member Front took power during the revolt. It relinquished only part of its power to a multiparty Council of National Unity in February after the Front announced it would run candidates in the elections, reversing an earlier pledge. The reversal touched off an outcry from the opposition, because the Front was also organizing the elections. The Front has since styled itself as a political movement rather than a ruling body, but its members dominate both the government and the Council, which is serving as a parliament until the elections. In his earlier interview with The Associated Press, Unteanu said: ``If they decide to postpone the elections, it will be a signal for political instability.'' ``The government needs to have the legitimacy of elections,'' he said. The government is struggling to restructure the economy from the centralized, state-run Communist model to a free-enterprise, market economy.

DOC.HEAD: Freedom Marchers Complete Re-enactment of Selma-Montgomery March
LaserPhotos MY1,2
DOC.TEXT: The re-enactment of the historic, 50-mile march from Selma to Montgomery ended Saturday with 3,000 people gathered in the shadow of Alabama's Capitol to rekindle the spirit of the civil rights movement. The turnout paled in comparison to the 1965 march, when 25,000 people gathered in ``the Cradle of the Confederacy'' to demand voting rights, but organizers hoped the 1990 trek would herald a new age of activism. ``It would be a shameful waste if we marched all the way from Selma to Montgomery to go home and sit on our seats of apathy,'' said Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christan Leadership Conference, who led the week-long, commemorative march. At the Capitol, where the Confederate battle flag still flies over the white dome despite blacks' protests, Jesse Jackson told the chanting crowd their message must be taken to the nation's capital. ``On to Washington for jobs,'' Jackson exhorted the gathering. ``On to Washington for peace dividends. Keep hope alive.'' Coretta Scott King encouraged the mostly black crowd to keep fighting for racial equality. ``These are the faithful few, and God always uses those who are willing to be used,'' said the widow of slain civil rights leader Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., whose first church is a block down the street from the Capitol steps. Mrs. King, Jackson and others said blacks had made progress but much remained to be done. Lowery called for corporations ``to engage in equitable reinvestment in our communities.'' Jackson later went to meet with former Gov. George C. Wallace at his home. Wallace, who opposed the 1965 march, later won widespread black support that helped win his fourth and final term as governor in 1982. ``If the governor can come from where he was 20 years ago and speak of a moral society where there is economic justice, there is hope for blacks and whites alike,'' Jackson told reporters after the meeting. The rally capped a week in which about 150 marchers crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma and headed east along a rural highway to Montgomery, covering the same path activists took in 1965. The march 25 years ago came two weeks after ``Bloody Sunday,'' where white authorities routed black marchers with clubs and tear gas as they tried to cross the bridge over the Alabama River. The violence at Selma was recorded by television cameras and helped spur Congress to pass the 1965 Voting Rights Act, which guaranteed ballot box rights for blacks. James P. Turner, an acting assistant attorney general in the civil rights division of the Justice Department, said the law's effect was almost immediate. In Alabama alone, he said, black voter registration increased from about 92,000 in 1964 to nearly 250,000 in 1967. ``Nationwide, the number of black elected officials has leaped from 103 in 1964 to 7,226 today,'' Turner told the rally. The final, two-mile leg of the commemoration began about two hours before the Capitol ceremony, with Lowery and Mrs. King leading about 1,000 blacks and a few whites through some of Montgomery's black neighborhoods. Blue skies and warm temperatures greeted the sign-carrying marchers, who chanted ``Fired up!'' and ``We ain't gonna take it no more'' on their way downtown. Lowery said blacks must reclaim values of the civil rights era that some have lost en route to 1990. ``We crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge but now we've got to cross the rivers of apathy and loss of self-esteem,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Group Battles Billboards With Whitewash
Laserphoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Harlem residents fed up with billboards enticing them to buy alcohol and cigarettes splashed paint over more than a dozen of the signs Saturday and cheered a company that followed suit. Singing ``Yield Not to Temptation,'' about 50 members of the Abyssinian Baptist Church marched with buckets and paint rollers down a street in Harlem, a section of New York where a recent study found men have shorter lifespans than in Bangladesh. ``Alcohol kills more people than heroin, marijuana, crack and cocaine together,'' said the Rev. Calvin O. Butts, the protest organizer and church pastor. It was the group's second swing through Harlem in two weeks. Butts said billboards advertising such products as whiskey and cigarettes ``proliferate in the African-American community more than any other community,'' often degrade women and are designed to entice youths. ``The board says `Alive with pleasure,' but tell that to someone dying of lung cancer,'' Butts said. The group passed graffiti-covered tenements and a dozen or so men drinking out of brown paper bags at 10 a.m. The protesters whitewashed more than a dozen 6-foot-by-12-foot billboards. Four police cars and a police van tailed the crowd, which included several children. ``We are using discretion,'' said police Capt. Terry Tunnock. ``We haven't had complaints from anyone. If any of the companies do complain there could be arrests, but none have come forward.'' Butts and others painted over several billboards a week earlier, prompting one outdoor advertising company, Scheiffelin & Somerset Co., to announce Johnny Walker Scotch and Hennessey Cognac would be banned from its billboards in low-income communities. Protesters gathered at the church Saturday before hitting the streets with their whitewash and rollers. They got a surprise announcement from a visitor, John Brown, who is vice president of another sign company, Metropolitan Outdoor Advertising. Brown announced that his company, one of the largest in the city and one of the biggest distributors of small billboards in the United States, would remove liquor and cigarette billboards within five blocks of places of worship, schools and play areas in New York. He said the company would consider doing the same elsewhere in the country. Brown noted similar whitewashing campaigns under way in Chicago, Detroit and Oakland, Calif. ``If we are to survive as advertisers in the '90s, we need to take positive action,'' he said. The billboard-blotting campaigns come at a time of heightened criticism of manufacturers that target advertising for cigarettes and alcohol at minority consumers. In January, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. canceled plans to market a new cigarette, Uptown, with ads tailored to win over blacks, after Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan joined Philadelphia community groups in criticizing the campaign. Officials in Richmond, Calif., are considering a ban on alcohol and tobacco billboard advertising near schools. ``We have to get at the basic, underlying motivations of people and we believe that these alcohol and cigarette billboards send a mixed message to kids who are being taught in a school to shun drugs,'' said Jim Rogers, chairman of an anti-drug task force in Richmond. A Metropolitan Outdoor Advertising worker perched on a ladder got cheers and applause from paint-slinging protesters as he papered over a billboard advertising beer with a new message: ``God makes house calls.'' A few bystanders, some sipping from cans or bottles hidden inside brown paper bags, seemed unimpressed with the effort. ``It ain't going to work,'' said an elderly man watching the group. He nudged a young man standing next to him who held up his brown paper bag and said, ``This is a personal thing.'' The protesters worked at one point in a vacant lot littered with garbage and ankle deep in spots with empty cans. Across the street, 21-year-old Larry Rodgers said he didn't think the billboard campaign would change much. ``On every corner there's a liquor store and a bar,'' said Rodgers, who described himself as a recovering alcoholic. ``It's a good idea, but it's not going to help.''

DOC.HEAD: Subway Crash Raises Questions
DOC.TEXT: The subway train had just left Philadelphia's big, bustling 30th Street Station when morning commuters noticed something was wrong. ``It kind of hit a bump or something and then it rocked really hard,'' said Rose McGurl, 35. ``And then it hit the posts that separate the two lanes of trains and then it came off the tracks.'' Three people were killed and 94 injured when the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority's six-car Train 61, filled with hundreds of people heading to work, derailed at 8:21 a.m. Wednesday. The last three cars abruptly were jerked onto adjacent tracks; one car was ripped open by steel pillars in the 83-year-old tunnel. Then, after President Bush and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner had unveiled a national transportation policy urging further cuts in federal support for mass transit, investigators' findings came in: _ One of four motors on the train's third car had lost its primary and backup supports, come loose and gouged 1,555 feet of ties before hitting a crossover switch, the National Transportation Safety Board said. _ On Friday, the NTSB said 27 of 76 motors it inspected on 19 cars were improperly secured, including one other motor on the same car on which the motor had dislodged. _ The motorman driving the train had tested positive for cocaine use, but the NTSB said it hadn't been determined whether the drug was a factor in the accident. The motorman, whose name was withheld, will be suspended without pay Monday, SEPTA spokesman Dave Murdock said. _ Still unexplained by SEPTA or city officials was a 17-minute delay, in which a SEPTA dispatcher didn't issue an alarm for nine minutes after the derailment and paramedics weren't summoned for eight minutes more. The safety board recommended none of the Budd Co.-built cars be used until inspected and repaired, and commuters had to take shuttle buses the rest of the week for a 37-block stretch of the 12.8-mile subway and elevated line. SEPTA general manager Louis Gambaccini pledged to complete the inspections by Monday, when full service was scheduled to resume. He insisted the rail system was safe. The accident was the first fatal derailment since 1961 on the line, which typically carries 100,000 passengers twice a day and which SEPTA has operated since 1969. Operator error, equipment failure and vandalism have caused several major accidents in the past decade on SEPTA's suburban train and trolley systems, including one fatality and 246 injuries in three accidents during a 22-month stretch from 1984 to 1986. NTSB members John K. Lauber and Susan M. Coughlin returned to Washington on Saturday, but 10 employees were expected to stay in Philadelphia through the middle of this week, said Russell Gober, investigator in charge. Investigators were still interviewing survivors, looking at track and signals and going over earlier findings, he said. ``Mostly we're just getting the information that we've already developed in perspective,'' he said. The NTSB's report on the accident isn't expected for nine months to a year. Gov. Robert P. Casey toured the crash site Thursday and was questioned about SEPTA's complaints of inadequate financing by local, state and federal governments. ``President Bush cut $27 million from SEPTA this year,'' Casey said. ``I've never cut five cents from SEPTA. I've done nothing but increase money for SEPTA.'' Gambaccini agreed the state's recent increases have been crucial to SEPTA's survival, but he said more was needed, especially in light of the federal government's proposed end of mass transit subsidies. Gambaccini later said SEPTA's financial problems sometimes force maintenance workers to take ``shortcuts,'' but dismissed them as a possible factor in the subway crash. When the cocaine results were revealed, Gambaccini said he hoped the findings wouldn't taint other SEPTA workers, whom he characterized as ``a workforce of dedicated and responsible human beings.'' Of nearly 1,000 SEPTA employees tested since the Transport Workers Union agreed to random tests a year ago, 2.32 percent tested positive for illegal drug use, Gambaccini said. ``In every case, immediate and appropriate action was taken,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Evangelist Warns Germans Against ``Hedonism'' as Communism Wanes
LaserPhoto BER5
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Billy Graham took his crusade to the open Berlin Wall on Saturday and appealed to East Germans he sees as spiritually adrift following the demise of Communist ideology. In a one-hour sermon at the wall, the U.S. evangelist warned of materialism and the lure of ``hedonism and self-gratification'' at ``this time of rejoicing.'' He was referring to democratic changes sweeping the Communist world. ``The people I've met in Germany are living in both hope and fear,'' Graham told a rain-soaked rally of about 10,000 people on a vast, grassy square in front of the imposing Reichstag, the parliament of Germany prior to World War II. He noted that while many Germans hope for renewed national unity and prosperity, worries about the future abound. ``Many people feel insecure. The old roots are shaking everywhere,'' Graham said. Hartmut Stepp, a West German Evangelical Church leader from Stuttgart, said Graham's ministry was sought since ``a spiritual, ideological vacuum exists because of this social upheaval.'' At least half of the crowd was East German, judging from a show of hands sought by one speaker at the rally. Horst Arold, 50, said he had traveled 175 miles from Weimar, East Germany, for an event that would have been inaccessible only five months ago. East Germany's old Communist regime flung open the Berlin Wall in November, under pressure from mass protests for democratic reform. ``This is fantastic,'' Arold said. ``It's the first time in years that we can take part in something like this.'' Rally organizers set up a giant video screen and public address loudspeakers on the Reichstag steps, where Graham spoke under a portico inscription that reads ``To the German people.'' However, turnout was only a fraction of what organizers had expected. Graham spoke a week before East Germany's first free parliamentary elections on March 18, but said he had no political message. The East German Christian Democratic Union, which is backed by its West German counterpart led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, has emphasized its religious roots in the campaign. Graham last held rallies in Berlin in 1960, the year before the wall went up. He has conducted eight previous evangelical crusades in Germany, the first in 1954 when much of the nation still lay in ruins from World War II. Graham, who was ordained a minister in the Southern Baptists' Church in 1939, has also preached in the Soviet Union and other East European countries in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers for Church Bus Crash Driver File Notice of Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for a man sentenced to 16 years imprisonment in the nation's worst drunken-driving accident have filed notice they will appeal his conviction. Larry Mahoney, 36, was convicted Dec. 23 on 81 charges in the May 14, 1988, crash that killed 24 teen-agers and three adults traveling in a school bus. Mahoney's pickup truck, going the wrong way on Interstate 71 near Carrollton, slammed head on into the bus, which was quickly engulfed in flames. The victims were on a church outing. Twelve others on the bus were seriously hurt. Mahoney was convicted on 27 counts of second-degree manslaughter, 12 counts of first-degree assault, 27 counts of first-degree wanton endangerment, 14 counts of second-degree wanton endangerment and one count of driving under the influence. Mahoney was sentenced to 16 years in prison and must serve half the sentence before being eligible for parole. Attorneys filed a notice of appeal Friday in Carroll Circuit Court.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Gets Bronze Star 21 Years After Heroic Rescue
LaserPhoto ST1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First name Denver is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Jim Lahr sat ramrod straight in his wheelchair, tears welling in his eyes as his field commander in Vietnam added a long-delayed Bronze Star Saturday to the rows of medals pinned to his Marine uniform. ``The good guys finally won one,'' said Col. Donald Meyers, who retired from the Corps less than two years ago. ``It doesn't happen very often.'' While on patrol in Vietnam on March 21, 1969, 16 days before the end of his 13-month tour of duty, Lahr and several other Marines descended the steep banks of a stream to fill canteens. It turned out they had stumbled on a huge North Vietnamese supply cache, said Denver Lawson Freeman, who probably would have died there if it weren't for Lahr. As they stooped in the 2-foot-deep water, they were suddenly ambushed with machine-gun fire and rocket-propelled grenades. ``The whole hill basically just exploded,'' Freeman said. A grenade fell nearby, wounding Freeman and several others. ``Corporal Lahr, with complete disregard for his own safety ... assisted several Marines to safety,'' the award citation says. ``Despite the heavy fire, he made several trips ... until he himself was wounded and unable to continue.'' Lahr said he took one round from a rifle. The bullet went into his shoulder, grazed his lung, hit three ribs and finally lodged in his spine, paralyzing him from the waist down. For 20 years, neither Freeman nor Lahr knew that the other had survived. But through a contact he made at a Marine Corps reunion last summer, Freeman learned that Lahr was living in Lincoln, Ill. He set out to see that his friend received the honor he deserved. If he hadn't pulled me out of the river that day I wouldn't be here today,'' Freeman said after the awards ceremony Saturday at the Marine Reserve base in St. Louis. ``There's just no doubt in my mind about that.'' Freeman ``started the ball rolling,'' said Marine Sgt. Major Wallace Poyner, writing letters and petitions to the awards section of the Marine Corps. Lahr downplayed his heroism, saying he did it all on impulse and didn't even know immediately that he was shot. ``It all happened so fast,'' he said as he fingered the citation for heroism. ``I fell down in the water and grabbed a big rock. I didn't know I was hit until I looked down and saw the blood running away from me in the water.'' He remembers nothing more until he awoke on a hospital ship some days later. Freeman suffered a crushed bone in his right thigh in the battle and was hospitalized for 10 months after the attack. He now sells insurance in South Charleston, W.Va. Lahr is active in veterans' groups, said Nancy, his wife of 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian President Says Aid Delay Hurts Panama
DOC.TEXT: Democracy will fail in Panama unless promised U.S. economic help arrives soon, President Guillermo Endara said Saturday as he entered the 10th day of a hunger strike to press for the aid. ``People cannot eat democracy,'' Endara told The Associated Press in an interview in the nave of Metropolitan Cathedral, where he is fasting in ``solidarity with the suffering of the people of Panama.'' Endara, whose electoral victory in May 1989 was annulled by former dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, was sworn in secretly on Dec. 19 only hours before U.S. forces invaded Panama and ousted Noriega. But Endara's government is faced with severe economic problems. The United States has turned over only $160 million of $400 million it withheld in back pay during the last two years of Noriega's rule. Meanwhile, President Bush's promises of economic assistance are being discussed in Congress. The invasion and ensuing looting destroyed most of Panama City's business districts, costing nearly $700 million in losses and thousands of jobs. Unemployment, estimated at 20 percent before the invasion, is now more than 30 percent, the government says. ``It is painful to see that for ridiculous and foolish reasons they are holding back money that belongs to Panama,'' Endara said. The 52-year-old president added that he understands bureaucracy. ``I am sure President Bush is doing the best he can. There are legal requirements that have to do with the releasing of the funds, but still I do not see why the people of Panama have to wait,'' he said. One of hundreds of people who visit the cathedral daily to draw Endara's attention to the president's problems was Raul Kennedy, who belonged to a military unit dismissed by Noriega because of its participation in a failed coup last October. Kennedy was called back to serve in the new police force and said he has been working since January. ``But I have not gotten paid yet because my appointment is not official yet,'' he said. ``They tell me everything is being delayed or suspended for lack of money. I understand the country is in bad shape, but I have a wife and two children to support.'' Said Endara: ``In order to survive, democracy must show that it is effective, that it can provide people food and justice. If it does not do that, it fails.'' ``I am still optimistic. I think our experiment will be successful, but I see signs of concern. There could be popular unrest, unless there are some quick solutions. The congressional delay of approval endangers our democracy,'' he said. Endara, a portly man who normally weighs around 240 pounds, has lost more than 10 pounds since he started his fast. He is under medical care and drinks only water. He sleeps on a canvass cot cooled by a fan. There is a phone by his side and he attends government meetings. Not everyone agrees with how Endara is conducting Panama's affairs. The daily newspaper La Prensa ran a cartoon showing the president and his fiance, 22-year-old Ana Diaz, holding hands in the cathedral, ignoring the rise in crime and other social upheavals. On Friday police arrested more than 700 suspects while searching for drugs and guns. The rise in crime is alarming, and police officials blame some of it on unemployment and the amount of weapons believed to be in the hands paramilitary bands set up by Noriega. ``We used to have an average of four murders per month,'' said Capt. Leslie Loaiza, director of the technical police. ``We now have 30.''

DOC.HEAD: Tough Choices Ahead for Veterans Department
DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS spelling of Derwinski in graf 5, ``And VA xxx; graf 13, ``that assessement xxx; and graf 22, ``Derwinski ran
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It's starting to sprinkle on the election-year parade that last March brought the nation's 27 million veterans more access to the White House. Not that the marching and music will stop anytime soon. The Bush administration's 1991 budget proposal asks for a record $31 billion for the Veterans Affairs Department, including an unheard of $12.3 billion for health programs. The proposal is ``the best VA medical care budget request by a president in more than a decade,'' says Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., chairman of the Senate Veterans' Affairs Committee. And VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski has raised the hopes of the 3.1 million Vietnam War veterans by promising he will personally settle the Agent Orange question this spring. Derwinski, more than any VA official in the recent past, has opened his doors to that group of veterans, says Paul S. Egan of the Vietnam Veterans of America. But the same members of Congress who praised the budget have already begun tinkering with it and refused to go along with a review of the VA medical system that could mean closing hospitals or clinics. Veterans groups demanded $1.1 billion more and are attacking VA's effort to review the benefits system. Derwinski is the first VA secretary of the United States. Until March 15, 1989, VA stood for the Veterans Administration _ just another government agency, albeit a massive one. Now it is a department, giving Derwinski full Cabinet status. VA helps educate, house, treat and bury the people who served the country in war or peace. It operates the largest health-care system in the free world and is the fifth-largest life insurance provider in the country. Second in size only to the nation's veterans-producing machine, the Pentagon, the VA employs about a quarter of a million people. VA's 172 medical centers and its other facilities are choice cuts of meat in the federal pork barrel. Since they make up well over a tenth of the U.S. population and are all of voting age, veterans are a political force, especially when politicians wrap themselves in the flag as they did in 1988. That is why it was easy for President Reagan to sign the Department of Veterans Affairs Act in October of that year even though, as an avowed enemy of big government, he had tried to strip the Education and Energy departments of Cabinet status. ``Given the broad political support which already exists for the VA and its programs, the gain from elevation to a Cabinet department would be at the margin,'' the independent National Academy of Public Administration told Congress in 1988. That assessment is also why Derwinski, a wily former congressman from Chicago, knows that hard times lie ahead. Derwinski must decide what to do about the 9 million or so World War II veterans who are getting older _ and many of them sicker and poorer. Large numbers have moved South and West away from existing facilities in the East and Midwest. He must also decide how much special attention to give to the nearly half-million Vietnam-era veterans who have continuing post-combat trauma or to countless others who say they have cancer or other ailments caused by exposure to Agent Orange. He must deal with an overstrained bureaucracy that forces young veterans to wait months for their claims to be handled or just can't get through to VA on the telephone. He must deal with chronically underpaid doctors and nurses. Finally, Derwinski must develop and maintain good working relationships with Congress, where he served 12 terms before joining the Reagan State Department, and with the veterans' lobby. Congress and the veterans groups ``tend to be better second-guessers than blocking backs,'' Derwinski said recently in a rare show of pique. ``They tend to be less cooperative about proposals to innovate than they do critiquing our past performance,'' he said. ``That's the headache part of the job.'' When Derwinski made those remarks, the Disabled American Veterans had just questioned ``the department's commitment to its role as veterans' advocate.'' The group had discovered VA was quietly studying ``benefit reforms.'' That in-house study includes a look at the sacred cow known as disability payments. VA says it is looking at ways to restore fairness to the system, including equal death benefits for survivors of privates or generals. Derwinski ran up against a brick wall in Congress last July when he asked for legislation to create a study commission that would examine the VA's network of hospitals and clinics. He said no such review had been done for a quarter of a century. ``We got caught in the debate about military base closings, so our timing wasn't good,'' said Derwinski, who decided this year to appoint his own review commission. It will make its proposals to Congress in two years. Derwinski has also eliminated 27 medical districts ``that everyone told me were layers of bureaucracy.'' Although Congress cheered the new budget request, the House Veterans Affairs Committee wasted no time tacking another $729 million on to it. Veterans groups asked for $1.1 billion more. Derwinski's considerable reserve of goodwill could rise or drop depending on what he does about Agent Orange this spring. ``The advice is so terribly conflicting,'' Derwinski said. ``There's no consensus out there.'' He gave strong hints starting last May he would give veterans the benefit of the doubt and award them compensation payments on Agent Orange claims _ adding perhaps $36 million to the VA's cost of doing business. Derwinski backed off from a chance to decide last November. But this year he's promising action, depending on the outcome of a Centers for Disease Control study on cancer in Vietnam veterans.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Robert Greene covers Veterans Affairs for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Radioactive Pellet Found in Cross-Country Shipment, NRC Investigates
DOC.TEXT: Officials spent Saturday laboriously trying to track down truck drivers, warehouse workers and others who may have been exposed to an intensely radioactive pellet buried within a transcontinental cargo shipment. The radioactive pellet _ the size of a pencil eraser _ was discovered Thursday lying loose in a shipment of what were supposed to have been empty containers trucked to Massachusetts. The pellet, called a source, is used for making X-ray-type pictures of welds, structural steel and other industrial objects. Technicians at the shipment's last stop, Amersham Inc. of Burlington, discovered the pellet when they detected radioactivity coming from the shipment of containers used to carry sources. The container that the source was found in lacked a shielding device that would have prevented the radiation from leaking out. ``It's safe to say that this is extraordinarily rare,'' said Karl Abraham, a Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokesman. ``There should be concern but certainly not panic until we have a chance to contact all the individuals who have had exposure.'' Abraham said it would take several days to determine how many people may have received radiation during the shipment's transit from South Korea to Los Angeles, where it was stored for a month before being trucked cross-country to Amersham, which manufactures equipment used to test industrial structures. ``It appears to be an old source, a decayed source,'' Abraham said of the pellet. New pellets radiate at a level of 60 to 75 curies; radiation from the one that was found was at levels from 3 to 7 curies, he said. Initial measurements taken 4 to 6 inches away form the pellet found the level of radiation to be 150 rems per hour _ millions of times higher than that people normally are exposed to from the environment and X-rays. A rem is a measure of the estimated damage done to living tissue by radiation. People generally receive about one-tenth of a rem, or 100 millirem, of radiation annually from natural sources; the average American is exposed to an annual dose of 77 millirem from medical X-rays. Abraham said investigators would better be able to determine the radiation field after reconstructing the way in which the cargo was stored. ``Then we have to determine the relation of that to where the driver was sitting, where the people in the warehouse were and how long these people were near the source,'' he said. ``It's going to be a laborious process that will take many days.'' The NRC has enlisted the help of state officials in Massachusetts, California, Pennsylvania and Maryland in their efforts to reconstruct the radioactive shipment's path. The Sate Department has also contacted the South Korean government, he said. Abraham said it wasn't immediately clear how or at what point the radioactive pellet slipped into the cargo, but ``the shipment supposedly came in sealed up under bond like most things do when they go from one continent to another.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Propose $200,000 Fine In ``Blue Ice'' Engine Loss
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials proposing a $200,000 fine against Northwest Airlines say improper maintenance was involved when an engine fell off a Northwest plane over Florida in January. Northwest said Friday it would seek to have the fine reduced. A three-engine Boeing 727 en route from Miami to Minneapolis on Jan. 4 landed safely in Tampa, Fla., after losing the right rear engine, which fell onto ranch land north of Tampa. There were no injuries. The National Transportation Safety Board said in January that preliminary findings showed blue fluid that apparently leaked from the plane's forward lavatory solidified into chunks of ice as the plane cruised at 35,000 feet. The ``blue ice'' then flew into the engine, damaging it until it broke loose and fell off, as the engines are designed to do to prevent damage to the fuselage, the official said. Northwest has maintained that various problems with the lavatory had been repaired several times in the weeks before the incident, but the Federal Aviation Administration said late Friday that a leaking valve reported to the airline on several occasions between Dec. 23 and Jan. 4, wasn't repaired. ``As a result, during that period the aircraft was operated in an unairworthy condition on 53 flights,'' the FAA said. Northwest spokesman Alan Muncaster said Friday he expects the airline will negotiate with federal officials in an attempt to get the fine reduced.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Had Mixed Feelings About Avril
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with 3 grafs: INSERTS 2 grafs after pvs 3rd graf ``However, $41.4 million ...'' to add State Department comments
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Haiti Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Saturday welcomed a promise by Haiti's new leader to set the stage for national elections by turning over power within 72 hours. A U.S. statement called on the country's armed forces to join with political and business leaders in a spirit of reconciliation. Stressing the longtime U.S. call for human rights in Haiti, the statement said, ``We obviously hope the latest developments contribute to a realization of this objective.'' The administration has had mixed feelings about the regime of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril in Haiti, finding it responsive to U.S. human rights demands but unconvincing about its commitment to free elections. There is no U.S. economic or military aid to Haiti except for a small program to combat narcotics. A $10 million emergency food program for what is one of the poorest and most densely populated countries in the Western Hemisphere was not continued this year. However, $41.4 million for agricultural development and other humanitarian assistance is being distributed through voluntary agencies. Shortly after Avril yielded power to Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham the State Department responded by saying it welcomed the intermim leader's promise to give way to a panel led by the Supreme Court president in order to arrange elections. This step by Arabahm ``is in conformity with the spirit of the constitution,'' said Adam Shub, State Department spokesman. The department, in its human rights report last month, linked the Haitian army to human rights abuses in rural areas and said armed bands, some possibly traced to remnants of the feared Tonton Macoute militia of the Duvalier years, had committed a number of murders. And yet, the report said: ``Human rights abuses perpetrated or directed by government leaders were the hallmark of previous Haitian regimes. The Avril government avoided the egregious violations _ massacres and politically motivated killings _ characteristic of its predecessors.'' This slightly favorable report to Congress on Haiti's record in 1989 took a nosedive at the start of this year. In January, the Avril government imposed a state of siege, suspending basic civil liberties. Prominent opposition politicians were beaten and deported. The Bush administration registered its outrage. Within 10 days, the ban and censorship of the press was lifted, constitutional guarantees were revived. And on Feb. 7, political prisoners arrested since November were released in an amnesty. But the State Department said the actions were insufficient evidence of the Avril government's commitment to human rights and free elections. Ambassador Alvin Adams was recalled to Washington. It was amid this re-evaluation of U.S. relations with Haiti, and a strategy designed to wrench a positive response from Port-Au-Prince, that the latest crisis developed. Reports that Mrs. Avril had taken refuge in Washington were not confirmed. The State Department on Saturday watched unfolding developments in Port-Au-Prince without a word of comment. The Avril government is the fifth in Haiti since Jean-Claude Duvalier fled for France in February 1986 aboard a U.S. Air Force transport. His family's 29-year rule was replaced by a national governing council. ``Baby Doc'' left Haiti with a strong shove from the Reagan administration, though Duvalier left a taped message behind suggesting he had made the decision himself ``so a bloodbath (would) be avoided for my people.'' ``We don't want to take too much credit,'' a U.S. official told an Associated Press reporter at the time. ``But, yes, we did (force him out). And he knows it. He knew that sooner or later we would make sure that he did (leave). But we wanted it done in a way that would bring about democracy and help prevent another Iran or Nicaragua.'' As it turned out, Haiti became neither democratic nor as instable as Iran after the departure of the shah. Haitians gained freedom of expression, of the press and of association that did not exist under the Duvaliers. But arbitrary arrests continued.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 6 Die of Complications Tied to Experimental AIDS Drug
DOC.TEXT: Six AIDS patients taking the experimental drug DDI have died of pancreatitis, a toxic side effect attributed to the drug, according to a published report. The Los Angeles Times reported Saturday that the deaths have occurred in the five months since the federal government made DDI _ dideoxyinosine _ available on a limited basis. Five of the dead were among the 8,000 patients receiving DDI as part of an expanded access program through the Food and Drug Administration, according to the drug's manufacturer, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. The sixth was one of 700 patients taking part in government-sponsored trials of the drug, the Times said. In a news release Saturday, the FDA said officials were aware of adverse reactions to the drug, including deaths, but didn't provide further detail. The FDA said it asked Bristol-Myers to provide detailed information as soon as possible so the agency could determine if changes are needed ``to make the ongoing protocols as safe as possible.'' The FDA also asked the drug company to write doctors caring for patients receiving DDI ``providing them and their patients with the best available information about this situation and urging them to monitor their patients closely for signs of pancreatitis.'' Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of AIDS activities for the National Institutes of Health, told the paper ``toxic side-effects, some of which will be serious,'' were expected. Pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, a digestive organ. Severe inflammation can lead to kidney failure, respiratory failure and death. Kathryn R. Bloom, a spokeswoman for Bristol-Myers, told the Times the it hadn't been proven the deaths were caused by DDI. Bloom said there have been 44 reports of pancreatitis, including the six fatalities. ``We are taking this very seriously,'' Bloom told the newspaper. In addition to the letter being prepared for doctors, the company is studying the affects of dose levels and the length of therapy. The expanded access program is to make DDI available to patients with advanced infections by HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, who are unqualified to take part in formal research studies. This includes patients who are medically unable to take AZT _ another drug for AIDS treatment. When the expanded access to DDI was approved last year, eight non-fatal cases of pancreatitis had already been reported among about 100 AIDS patients who had received the drug, the Times said, citing government statistics. Many of those patients, however, were receiving far higher does of DDI than those approved for widespread experimental use by the FDA.

DOC.HEAD: Party Leader Gives Impassioned Call for Unity, Members Vote on New Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with vote beginning, results to be announced Sunday, SUB grafs 3-4; pickup 5th graf pvs, `We want...'
DOC.TEXT: Italian Communists applauded and sang Saturday after party leader Achille Occhetto, moved to tears by the embrace of his chief opponents, made an impassioned call for unity in creating a new party. Occhetto has emerged victorious at the party congress in his effort to relaunch the Italian Communist Party, a move that eventually is expected to lead to a new party name and the elimination of the hammer-and-sickle symbol. Delegates representing the West's largest Communist Party began voting at about 11:20 p.m. on the proposal. But the result was assured and delegates passed resolutions during the evening to regulate how they will plan for the new party. The party said the voting booths would be open for three hours and the result would be announced later Sunday. The final vote had been expected earlier but was backed up behind a series of resolutions and speeches. ``We want to change many things, but we do not intend to leave the historic path from which we came _ we want to widen it,'' said Occhetto. ``Together we will construct our future, we will struggle together for democracy, for Italy and for Europe and socialism.'' Occhetto's proposal was spurred by the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe and the party's steady decline in membership and electoral strength in Italy. Occetto was interrupted by applause 24 times during the hour-long speech. He urged unity and outlined how the new party would seek to create a ``democratic alternative'' in Italy to represent the workers, the poor, the weak and the disenfranchised. The party leader came to the congress with the support of almost 67 percent of the delegates. That was more than enough to ensure the success of his bid to create a new party. However, his proposal risks splitting the party, which claims 1.4 million members. Old Guard Communists waged an impassioned battle against revisions, which were expected to include the name change and elimination of the party's revered symbols. But fears of a party split seemed to vanish when the party's old lion, Pietro Ingrao, and former party secretary Alessandro Natta, two of the leading opponents of change, embraced Occhetto at the end of his speech. The 1,092 delegates gave Occhetto a standing ovation, applauding and singing ``Bandiera Rosa'' (Red Flag), the party anthem. Occhetto wiped tears from his eyes as he took his seat on the high red multi-tiered platform. The sports arena was awash in red banners and Communist symbols. The Communists nearly came to power in 1976 when they won 34 percent of the vote, but they dropped to about 27 percent in the last parliamentary elections in 1987. The Italian party has long proclaimed itself independent of Moscow. It has espoused Western parliamentary democracy, supported Italy's membership in NATO and condemned the Soviet intervention in Czechoslovakia in 1968 and Afghanistan in 1979. But while the party has portrayed itself as a critic of international communism, Occhetto has argued it cannot ignore the march of history and the collapse of Communist governments in Eastern Europe. He has maintained that a revamped Italian party can move closer to the mainstream of European socialism and perhaps unite Italy's fractured political left to offer an alternative to the Christian Democrats, who have dominated Italian politics more than four decades.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Court Sentences Journalist to Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs with comment by Amensty International, newspaper editorial; pickup 17th graf pvs, `In November...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON5
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi court sentenced a journalist with a British newspaper to death on espionage charges Saturday and ordered a British nurse jailed for 15 years for allegedly helping him, the Foreign Office said. Under Iraqi law, no appeal is allowed. The journalist, Iranian-born Farzad Bazoft of London's weekly Observer newspaper, was arrested in September while investigating reports of an explosion at an Iraqi military complex. The nurse, Daphne Parish, was accused of helping Bazoft by driving him to the plant. Bazoft, 31, and Mrs. Parish, 52, were tried by a revolutionary court on charges of committing hostile acts against Iraq. The proceedings, which were not open to the public, began Thursday then were adjourned after five hours. They resumed for 35 minutes Saturday, the Foreign Office said. The defendents were assigned Iraqi lawyers, but a British diplomat was allowed to attend the trial. There was no indication when the execution of Bazoft might be carried out. The 31-year-old stateless Iranian has lived in Britain since 1975 and travels on British documents. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was ``horrified by the severity of the sentence'' against Bazoft, a Foreign Office spokesman said. He said she will appeal to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for clemency on humanitarian grounds. Junior Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave said the government was concentrating on ``the immediate next few hours,'' to get the death sentence lifted. He said the government was considering sending a top-level emissary to Baghdad. ``We rule out nothing,'' he said. The sentences, if carried out, ``are bound to have a far-reaching effect on relations between the two countries,'' Waldegrave added. Amnesty International appealed for clemency. The London-based human rights organization said in a statement that it ``opposes the death penalty in all cases'' and supports the ``right not to be subjected to cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment.'' Iraq's ambassador to Britain, Dr. Azmi Al-Salihi, told Independent Television News he passed Mrs. Thatcher's plea for clemency to Baghdad. Asked whether Hussein would consider the request, he said: ``Let us see. We have good relations with the British government. We want all the aspects of our good relations continued.'' Bazoft, an Iranian exile, has lived in Britain since 1975 and travels on British documents. Mrs. Parish lives in Baghdad, where she is a senior nursing administrator for the Irish-run Ibn al-Bitar hospital. Her daughter, Michelle de Vries, who lives in London, said she was ``extremely shocked and distressed'' by her mother's sentence. An Iraqi who was in contact with Bazoft in Baghdad was also tried and received a 10-year sentence for communicating government secrets to a foreigner, the Foreign Office said. The Iraqi was identified only as Rahim. ``We utterly deplore these harsh and excessive sentences,'' a Foreign Office statement said. ``No evidence was produced at the trial which would justify sentences of this severity. They come ill from a regime which is trying to show a more liberal face to the world.'' In a front-page editorial on Sunday, The Observer called the Iraqi court's action ``a monstrous piece of injustice that will damage the country's reputation around the world.'' ``It is an outrage demanding the same firmness which the prime minister showed when she broke diplomatic relations with the regimes of Libya and Syria for their official association with terrorism. ``Terrorism is not the issue here, but cruelty barbarity and injustice, which can be demonstrated many times over in Iraq.'' In November, Bazoft appeared on Iraqi state television and said he had been spying for Israel. Mrs. Parish did not appear in the broadcast. The editor of the Sunday Observer, Donald Trelford, said the paper was certain Bazoft was not spying for anyone. He said the statement must have been made under duress and noted that Bazoft appeared to be in poor physical shape. Trelford said Bazoft had sought official permission to visit the Al-Iskandaria military complex south of Baghdad, had told the paper of his movements, and had talked openly about the visit to colleagues on his return to Baghdad. ``None of this conduct is consistent with espionage. It is entirely consistent with journalism,'' he said. As Bazoft is an Iranian, the Foreign Office said it was not in the same position to argue on his behalf as it was for Mrs. Parish, who is British-born. But it said it was appealing on Bazoft's behalf for humanitarian reasons and because he lived in Britain for years. The explosion at the military complex was reported in London to have killed up to 700 people, but the Iraqis later said 19 people were killed in a fuel depot blast.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Paper Says Washington Plans Hostage Rescue
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian newspaper said Saturday the United States and Israel are planning a military rescue mission to free Western hostages in Lebanon. The newspaper, the English-language Kayhan International, said the eight captive Americans would be killed if such an attempt were made to free them and the 10 other Westerners. The paper did not cite sources, and its unconfirmed report gave no further details. There was no immediate comment from Washington. The newspaper, quoted by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, said any joint U.S.-Israeli rescue mission would ``end the so-called hostage crisis with the death of at least the American hostages.''
