Meanwhile, a key Moslem leader in Beirut, Lebanon, Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, said of the hostages: ``We believe there are encouraging elements regarding readiness to deal with this issue.'' He is spiritual leader of Hezbollah, or Party of God, an Iranian-linked group believed to be an umbrella for organizations holding most of the Western hostages. On Feb. 23, after returning from a trip to Iran, Fadlallah called in a sermon for ``realistic and humanitarian means to free the hostages.'' There have been several Iranian reports since then that some hostages might be freed. President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran recently said the hostages were being used by the West as a propaganda weapon and should be freed. There have also been reports that U.S. officials were talking indirectly to Iranian officials in an effort to win the release of captives. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Kayhan International said Saturday a recent ``media blitz'' on the U.S. hostages in Lebanon was designed in part to prepare the American public for the planned military operation. The Revolutionary Justice Organization said last week it had ``acquired accurate information that an American military operation is imminent against areas where the Americans believe hostages are held.'' The pro-Iranian group, which holds two U.S. hostages, said in a statement it had ``no intention'' of freeing hostages it was holding. Kayhan International's positions are often at variance with those of Rafsanjani, who favors good ties with the West to attract investment and technology for Iran's sluggish economy. Former President Carter authorized an attempt to rescue 52 American hostages held in Iran in 1980. However, the operation ended in disaster on April 25 of that year when a helicopter collided with a tanker aircraft over an Iranian desert, killing eight servicemen. The hostages were finally freed in January 1981 after 444 days in captivity.

DOC.BYLINE: Rain in South and Pacific Northwest; Fog closes Midwest Airports. ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Rain and snow fell in the Pacific Northwest Saturday, and fog slowed air traffic in Milwaukee and Chicago. Showers also fell across the South. Snow advisories were posted over the Cascade range in Washington and northern Oregon, where heavy snow fell late in the week. Snowfall overnight Friday amounted to 3 inches at Timberline, Ore., and the day before, eight inches fell at Stampede Pass, Wash., bringing the season's total to 8{ feet. Wisconsin was almost completely blanketed with fog, and air traffic at Mitchell Field International Airport in Milwaukee was disrupted for much of the day. With visibility at 600 feet, all incoming flights and many departures were halted from 8 a.m. to 2:30 p.m., said Ron LaMarche, supervisor for the Federal Aviation Administration at the Mitchell Field tower. At Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, fog caused delays of up to 90 minutes, and air traffic was running an hour late at the city's other airport, Midway. For an hour in the morning, United Airlines, O'Hare's largest tenant, ordered a ``ground stop,'' which directed controllers at airports in cities to halt United flights to Chicago, said to Chicago Aviation Department spokeswoman Lisa Howard. The dense fog, caused by a warm weather front moving through the region, stretched from Chicago to Dubuque, Iowa, according to the National Weather Service. It was rainy Saturday in much of the South and parts of the Midwest. Showers fell from Virginia and the Carolinas across to northern Georgia. Rain also fell in eastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania and New York state and southeast Minnesota. The low temperature for the nation Saturday was 4 degrees Saranac Lake, in New York's Adirondack Mountains. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 33 degrees in both Duluth, Minn., and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 86 degrees at Harlingen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Fine Proposal Generates Little Opposition in College Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to move up explanation that ban would go into effect only if Supreme Court overturned Roe vs. Wade. Picks up 5th graf, ``In the...' ^By JUDY DAUBENMIER
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to declare Ann Arbor a ``zone for reproductive freedom'' by limiting punishment for abortions to a $5 fine has generated little visible opposition from residents. The fines, similar to parking tickets, would go into effect only if the U.S. Supreme Court reversed its 1973 decision permitting abortions and Michigan decided to restrict abortions. ``There seems to be more discussion nationally than in Ann Arbor about this,'' City Attorney R. Bruce Laidlaw said this week. Ann Arbor resident Sabra Briere said she led the effort to get the referendum on the April 2 city ballot because abortion bans don't stop women from having abortions. ``In the event the Dark Ages return, Ann Arbor will have a core group of committed pro-choice people anyway,'' Briere said. Briere predicted the measure would pass easily in Ann Arbor, a city of about 112,000 that is home to the University of Michigan. The effect of the proposed revision in the city charter would be limited, because Ann Arbor can't prevent state police from enforcing state laws, Laidlaw said. The measure wouldn't protect doctors from losing their licenses or facing other penalties for performing illegal abortions, he said. Briere said anti-abortion laws don't work. She said they didn't stop her grandmother from having two abortions in the early 1900s. ``I think abortions will be performed all over, including in Ann Arbor, just as they always have been,'' Briere said. Briere headed the effort to gather 4,127 signatures to get the proposal on the ballot to declare Ann Arbor a ``zone of reproductive freedom.'' She needed 3,720 signatures. The measure was approved last month for the April election. Ann Arbor residents voted overwhelmingly against a 1988 proposal to ban state-funded abortions for poor women. The measure passed statewide by a wide margin. Barbara Listing, president of the anti-abortion group Right to Life of Michigan, views the $5 fine proposal as a publicity stunt by those who believe a woman have a right to have abortions. ``I doubt very much if any city could pass a local ordinance excluding a state penalty, especially for a felony,'' she said. RaeAnn Houbeck, who chairs Washtenaw County Right to Life in Ann Arbor, urged its members to vote against the proposal. ``I think it sends out a message to the rest of the state sort of naming Ann Arbor as an abortion capital of the state, which I think is appalling,'' she said. The measure is patterened on an Ann Arbor charter provision that limits the fine for marijuana possession in the city to $5, despite stiffer penalties at the state level. ``I can tell you we do have more than a legal leg to stand on,'' said Briere, a secretary at the University of Michigan who is the chairwoman of Citizens for Reproductive Freedom. A hefty majority in favor of the measure would be a signal to lawmakers to avoid restrictions on abortion, said Carol King, executive director of the Michigan Abortion Rights Action League. ``I think it's a statement on the part of Ann Arbor people that they think abortion should be legal and available. I don't think it's an empty gesture at all,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: No Talks Planned as Strike Enters Second Weekend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to CORRECT that walkout is in second week, edit to tighten. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Some Greyhound...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CD1
DOC.TEXT: Federal mediators called the striking Greyhound employees' union to Washington and may ask the company to a separate meeting in an attempt to revive contract negotiations in the second week of the walkout. Strikers continued picketing Saturday and Greyhound reported some violence in a nationwide series of memorials Friday for a driver killed on a California picket line. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers, went on strike March 2 against the only nationwide bus company. The two sides had failed to agree on a new, three-year contract. ``Our goal is to put 9,300 people back to work and we will participate in anything that will lead to that,'' said union spokesman Jeffery Nelson. ``We called for federal mediation in January but the company refused. ``Hopefully, they are now predisposed to accept an independent third party's involvement in the issues.'' A Greyhound negotiator said the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service is going to meet with the union Monday ``on a fact-finding mission.'' ``After that happens, they might contact us. But there's been no formal date for a meeting,'' said the negotiator, George Gravely. He said there were no meetings scheduled between the company and union. Pickets at the Greyhound terminal in Dallas Saturday carried copies of a letter from the Rev. Jesse Jackson urging U.S. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole to intervene in the strike, said Don Hardin of Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1313 in Dallas. Some Greyhound travel was disrupted Friday by bullets, a bomb threat and a beating. In Phoenix, Greyhound officials said a passing vehicle shot through the passenger door window of a bus en route Saturday to Los Angeles, but there were no injuries. Police had a suspect in the shooting, a Greyhound spokesman said. Strikers held memorial services Friday at terminals nationwide for Bob Waterhouse, killed one week ago when a bus crushed him against a wall while he was picketing in Redding, Calif. ``We are pleased by the wide support demonstrated by the general public and supporting groups during yesterday's events,'' said Nelson. ``The report from Washington's rally was great and Cleveland and New York were gigantic. They marched at the Port Authority'' bus terminal. Cleveland Mayor Michael White marched with strikers on Friday evening, and ministers in Cleveland, Chicago, St. Louis and Detroit led prayers and had moments of silence in Waterhouse's memory, he said. Tracy Nichols, a 16-year-old girl struck by a bus while walking in a picket line in Orlando, Fla., remained in serious but improving condition Saturday. In Indianapolis, about 150 strikers were joined by their families in picketing outside a Greyhound bus terminal. Carrying handmade signs with the messages `Go Scabhound' and `Let my Grandpa work.'' In central Ohio, authorities were investigating three shots fired from a passing car that hit a Greyhound bus carrying 29 passengers. No one was injured in the shooting on Interstate 71 about 25 miles southwest of Columbus. Bullets struck a window near the driver, a window at the back of the bus, and above the baggage bin, said Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale. Nelson said the union does not condone violence. ``We are fully prepared to cooperate with local authorities should they seek our assistance,'' he said. At a Seattle terminal, a Cascade Trailways bus bound for Portland, Ore., was delayed about 30 minutes by a crowd of striking Greyhound workers and other supporters. Police said about 20 officers helped keep order and one man was cited for misdemeanor ``pedestrian interference.'' In Pittsburgh, union members said police beat a striking driver as officers struggled Thursday night with pickets who were attempting to block a bus bound for Columbus, Ohio. Authorities said a bomb threat prompted the evacuation of passengers from a Greyhound bus en route from Las Vegas to Los Angeles, but a search with bomb-sniffing dogs on Interstate 15 near Baker, Calif., found no bomb.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmen Encouraged by Sheriff's Armory Seizure
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff Michael Ashe's unique solution to chronic jail overcrowding _ commandeering a National Guard armory _ may have unlocked new approaches to the problem, lawmen said. ``In these extraordinary times you can't just sit back and conduct your operations as business as usual,'' said Robert C. Rufo, president of the Massachusetts Sheriff's Association. ``Sheriff Ashe took a real public sector entrepreneurial approach and was highly creative,'' he said. Ashe got extra space for jail inmates Thursday, when a judge approved a compromise offer from the state for the Hampden County sheriff to move inmates from the Springfield armory to a vacant one in Holyoke, about 10 miles to the north. Holyoke officials promptly launched a legal challenge, but Hampden County Superior Court Judge George Keady refused to immediately block the compromise. He scheduled a hearing on the matter for next week. The saga began Feb. 16, when Ashe shocked state officials by marching into the armory and ordering officials to make room for prisoners under a 17th-century statute that orders citizens to give ``suitable aid'' to law enforcement efforts. The 102-year-old Hampden County jail, built to hold 279 prisoners, had reached its federal limit of 500 inmates and the only alternative to seizing the armory was putting criminals back on the streets, Ashe said. The sheriff's action, which initially met with strong resistance from the state government, drew the support of sheriffs around the country, Ashe said. ``It resurrected all of these unresolved issues, which is not just here but all over the nation,'' he said. ``You have to commend the guy,'' said Dick Ford, executive director of the American Jail Association in Hagerstown, Md. ``He took the initiative to do something about which no one else had acted.'' Other sheriffs struggling with crowded jails have taken direct action, such as self-imposed caps on jail populations, Ford said. In Massachusetts, sheriffs quickly called a meeting after the armory takeover and presented a letter to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis expressing their interest in more than two dozen National Guard armories recently closed because of a fiscal crisis in the state. Rufo said the sheriffs received an encouraging response and will meet with state officials next week to talk about the possibility of using the empty armories to house overflow inmates.

DOC.HEAD: State Republicans Endorse Gubernatorial Candidate
DOC.TEXT: More than half the delegates to the Republican State Convention endorsed Steven Pierce for governor Saturday, but one of his chief opponents in the GOP primary vowed to stay in the race. Pierce, minority leader in the Massachusetts House, received a so-called ``supermajority'' _ a margin wide enough to allow the GOP to endorse him before the Sept. 18 primary. His chief rival, William Weld, said he would remain in the race, upsetting state GOP chairman Raymond Shamie's plan to get the party to unite behind one candidate. A third GOP gubernatorial contender, Paul Cronin, failed to get enough votes to stay in the race and won't be on the primary ballot. Massachusetts hasn't had a Republican governor since 1970, but the party's fortunes rose after Democratic Gov. Michael S. Dukakis lost his 1988 presidential bid. Dukakis returned home to find the Massachusetts economic miracle he made a centerpiece of his campaign had collapsed. ``I am very gratified and very excited about my victory today,'' Pierce said. ``We're going to win the primary. I don't know what the margin will be.'' The convention vote was 2,672 for Pierce, or 52.6 percent. Weld received 1,845 votes, or 36.3 percent. Cronin garnered 563 votes, or 11.1 percent. Under convention rules, candidates needed at least 15 percent of the votes to go to the primary. The rules also provided that a candidate who beat his closest rival by 15 percent or more got the supermajority, freeing the GOP from neutrality. Weld, a former federal prosecutor, made it clear he planned to continue his campaign, though he didn't question the results of the convention vote. ``I think my strength is in the primary,'' said Weld, who has positioned himself as more moderate than Pierce. ``I think it will be a real service to the party and the voters.'' Shamie stopped short of saying he would ask Weld to drop out. At first, Shamie said, ``I have no plans to ask Bill Weld to withdraw.'' But later Saturday, he said, ``I might, I might'' when asked the same question. The state that bragged of having a budget surplus and one of the nation's lowest unemployment rates before 1988 now has a budget deficit of more than $500 million and a jobless rate of 5.3 percent, which equals the national average. The fiscal crisis is the top issue in the gubernatorial race. On the Democratic side, none of four top candidates for governor have emerged to lead the pack. They are state Rep. John Flood, former state Attorney General Francis Bellotti, on-leave Boston University President John Silber and Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy. Republican U.S. Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia told delegates to the GOP convention that the Democratic Party in the state is the Democratic candidates' biggest problem. ``If you are running as a Democrat, if you are part of the Democratic machine, you are the problem and electing you can't solve it,'' Gingrich said.

DOC.HEAD: Avril Promised Democracy, But Didn't Deliver
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to ADD family background, CORRECT Avril's age to 52 sted 51; pickup 11th graf pvs, `Despite his...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ When Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril came to power in in 1988, he talked of free elections and leading the country toward democracy. Saturday, it was Avril himself who was on the move. He was forced from power in a popular uprising by opponents who feared he would not make good on his promises. Like many Haitian rulers, Avril came to power in violence and left in violence. A week before the September 1988 coup that brought him to power, thugs armed with machetes, guns and spears stormed the Roman Catholic church of the Rev. Bertrand Aristide, a popular government critic. They massacred a dozen people there. The bloodbath split the military, and lower-ranking soldiers revolted against Lt. Henri Namphy. He was the army chief of staff who took charge of the government after dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to France in February 1986 during another mass uprising. The 1988 soldiers' rebellion was apparently not orchestrated by Avril, then army chief of staff. But it was Avril who finally came out on top, declaring himself president. He quickly went on national television and promised the impoverished Caribbean nation democratic reform and free presidential elections. Haitians, accustomed to lies and brutality from their leaders, were skeptical. Avril, a 52-year-old with a quiet demeanor, never seemed comfortable in the public eye. His wife, Marie-Ange, is a captain in the army and a nurse. The couple has four children. Avril had been in the background as a financial adviser to Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, Jean-Claude's father who founded the 29-year Duvalier family regime. Avril later advised Duvalier's son when he replaced his father. Because of that close relationship, critics called Avril a ``bagman'' who reputedly became a millionaire and negotiated military weapons and equipment sales abroad. Meanwhile, the Duvaliers created an authoritarian regime using the dreaded forces known as Tonton Macoutes to keep opponents in check. Despite his earlier association with the Duvaliers, Avril won some public support a few months into his rule. He held public meetings with civilian political leaders, talked with union leaders and restored most of the 1987 constitution that Namphy suspended. He also approved the formation of an independent electoral council to organize and oversee this year's general elections. Although there was skepticism, many thought it was better to work with Avril than against him. ``You're not going to get power if there's not a reasonable understanding with those guys,'' Marc Bazin, a presidential hopeful and former World Bank economist, said at the time. The U.S. government has had mixed feelings about Avril's regime. In its human rights report, it said the Haitian army was linked to human rights abuses in rural areas but that it ``avoided the egregious violations, massacres and politically motivated killings _ characteristic of his predecessors.'' Nevertheless, in March 1989, it said the resumption of $60 million in aid must be tied to democratic reform and cooperation in fighting drug trafficking. Immediately afterward, Avril's government accused four high-ranking army officers of drug trafficking and discharged them. The next month, Avril showed he had the loyalty of his 1,100-member Presidential Guard when they put down a rebellion by two army units. But Avril started looking more like a dictator. After the unsolved killing of an army colonel, his government imposed a state of siege on Jan. 20, jailed 50 opposition activists and sent seven political leaders into exile abroad. Many detainees were reportedly beaten or tortured. Nearly all political parties decided to boycott elections unless Avril stepped down. Speculation began to swirl Monday that Avril was on his way out after the army killed an 11-year-old girl, apparently by accident. Mass demonstrations followed, and at least three people were killed. President Bush, in a speech, mentioned Haiti in the same breath with Cuba. This time, Avril's government was characterized as a black mark on democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Widow of Protagonist in Movie `Missing' Returns to Chile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with more quotes, details; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Chile, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The widow of an American whose arrest and slaying in a 1973 military coup inspired the movie ``Missing'' returned to Chile on Saturday to witness the end of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's 16{-year rule. ``It's not the Chile of my nightmares,'' said Joyce Horman, who was invited by the elected government that takes power Sunday. Mrs. Horman told The Associated Press in an interview that she no longer expects any new information on her husband's death. ``I think it would be a very special circumstance for anyone with direct knowledge to step forward at this time,'' she said. But she added: ``I haven't ruled it out.'' ``But the most important thing is that democracy is established for Chileans, that there is respect for human rights.'' Her husband, Charles Horman, then 29, was among thousands of people arrested when Pinochet seized power in a bloody coup on Sept. 11, 1973. It toppled the elected government of President Salvador Allende, a Marxist. Horman, a free-lance journalist, and his wife were living in Chile at the time. According to the family and testimony collected by human rights groups, Horman was among many suspected dissidents held and executed at Santiago's National Stadium. The military government has denied the allegations. Horman's father, Ed Horman, pressed for years for details on his son's death and wrote a book about his efforts. The book provided the story for the movie ``Missing,'' starring Sissy Spacek as Horman's wife and Jack Lemmon as the father. The movie is officially banned in Chile. ``Maybe now they'll show it,'' Mrs. Horman said. In the AP interview, she said she found the country much more open and friendly than it was when she and her father-in-law were ushered out by U.S. diplomats and military authorities on Oct. 18, 1973. ``The air feels lighter. It's a different place,'' she said. ``It's not the place I remember.'' Both Mrs. Horman, a 45-year-old computer specialist, and Horman's father live in New York City. Horman's father is not attending the inauguration. On Monday, the National Stadium will be the site of a massive celebration to mark the end of Pinochet's rule. Patricio Aylwin, a 71-year-old Christian Democrat, was the candidate of a center-left coalition that defeated Pinochet in Dec. 14 national elections, winning 55 percent of the vote. Mrs. Horman was one of about 400 people invited by Aylwin to witness the change of government.

DOC.HEAD: Lead Musher Gets Hot, Six-Course Meal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT start of race to March 3, sted Feb. 3; ADDS two grafs at end with disqualification of Wyoming musher.
DOC.TEXT: Musher Susan Butcher gobbled a hot, six-course meal early Saturday as a reward for leading racers into this Yukon River settlement in the 18th annual Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race. The gourmet meal is traditional for the first musher to reach Ruby, which is more than halfway in the 1,160-mile endurance run across mountains, rivers, ice and tundra. In addition to the meal of veal lafitte with a Thai shrimp appetizer, chocolate cheescake and other delights, she collected $2,500 in cash for being first into Ruby. Seventy teams left Anchorage March 3 in the annual race to Nome. Leaders reached the official halfway point Friday at Cripple. Butcher grabbed the lead from Lavon Barve, who had headed the pack for several days. ``There's a definite top five now and they're the same top five from last year,'' Butcher said. Leaders kept up with Butcher Saturday afternoon as they raced for the next checkpoint at Galena, 52 miles up the Yukon River. Barve was second into Ruby, followed by Dee Dee Jonrowe, defending champion Joe Runyan and Tim Osmar. Butcher said the hot food was welcome after living on dried rations. ``I just threw in some emergency food, a pretty bad selection,'' Butcher said. The Iditarod, which commemorates a 1925 dogsled run to bring life-saving diphtheria serum to Nome, is named for a ghost town on the route. A Wyoming musher, Frank Teasley, was disqualified Saturday, when a race judge declared that his dogs were too sick to continue because of a virus that has hit other teams as well. The judge found there wasn't any negligence by Teasley's. Teasley's disqualification came just days after he killed a moose that he said was terrorizing another team along the trail.

DOC.HEAD: Citizens in Three Cities Demonstrate for Change
DOC.TEXT: Reformers who occupied a museum in the Georgian city of Tbilisi on Saturday were among protesters in at least four cities who demanded change, according to activists and news reports. In the Ukrainian city of Kiev, an activist said a crowd estimated at 50,000 gathered for a pro-democracy election rally. In Nazran, thousands of Ingushi residents held their fifth day of protests, calling for restoration of their autonomous republic in their southern homeland, Tass reported. Hundreds of thousands of Ingushi residents were deported from their homes in the Caucasus in 1944 after dictator Josef Stalin accused them of collaboration with the Nazis. Ingushi protesters insisted their demand for restoration of their homeland did not mean they intended to oust the Ossetians now living in the area, Tass said. There is a Checheno-Ingushi republic, but much of the Ingushi land was allocated to what is now Northern Ossetia when the natives were deported. In Tbilisi, a crowd gathered at the Museum of Marxism-Leninism and then occupied it to demand office space for non-Communist political groups. Authorities agreed, and the incident ended peacefully. The crowd was estimated by police at 1,200 and by activists at 3,000. In Kiev, speakers said election rigging was rampant in the Ukraine. But democratic candidates for the Ukrainian parliament have still won 33 races and advanced to runoffs in 120 others, said Yaroslav Tropimov of the Rukh people's front. Activists claim 10 percent of the ballots cast in the town of Ivankov were falsified to benefit Ukrainian Communist Party second secretary Stanislav Gurenko, Tropimov said. Both the Tbilisi and the Kiev activists spoke against Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's request for vastly expanded powers, activists said. Gorbachev's proposal to create a Soviet presidency is scheduled for adoption on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Return of Space Shuttle Atlantis to Florida Delayed by Weather
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather over Texas on Saturday forced officials to postpone the return of the space shuttle Atlantis to Florida. A Boeing 747 jet, with the shuttle riding piggyback, was scheduled instead to take off on Sunday, said Nancy Lovato, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Dryden Flight Research Facility here. Atlantis blasted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Feb. 28 and landed on Rogers Dry Lake on March 4, concluding a secret military mission. Sources told The Associated Press that the shuttle's five astronaut's deployed a $500 million spy satellite capable of taking high-resolution photographs and listening to electronic communications all over the world.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Protesters Take Control of Consulate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with higher estimate of protesters involved, further details. Pick up 6th graf, `Avril, who ...'
DOC.TEXT: About 100 demonstrators entered the Haitian consulate in Miami on Saturday, demanding a say in naming a new consul following the resignation of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril as the nation's military ruler. The protesters, most of them Haitian exiles, climbed the walls outside the downtown consulate and entered the empty building. The group occupied the offices for several hours until an armed FBI unit, State Department officials and a police SWAT team arrived and talked them into surrendering, said FBI spokesman Paul Miller. Miller said the FBI decided against making arrests immediately ``because of the emotions involved.'' No one was injured, he said. Miller initially estimated the number of protesters at 40 or 50, but later revised the number upward. Some of the demonstrators carried papers apparently taken from the consulate, but no material was confiscated from them, Miller said. Avril, who came to power in September 1988 in a coup, stepped down Saturday and Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham promised to transfer power to a panel led by the Supreme Court president by Monday. Moments after word reached Miami's Little Haiti section, spontaneous celebrations erupted. But Haitian exile leader Gerard Jean-Juste sounded a note of caution. He noted it was the fifth transition of power in Haiti since February 1986, when dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile. ``We are more mature now. We have seen this before and the country fell into repression,'' said Jean-Juste, director of Miami's Haitian Refugee Center. Jean-Juste said Miami's Haitian community would push for a new consulate staff and oppose the appointment of a consul linked to the Avril regime. ``We want someone from our own community. It's the one thing we hope to come out of this,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Travels to Inaugural in Chile After Caribbean Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 10 grafs new to update with arrival in Chile; picks up 5th prv, ``Chile became xxx; minor editing below, including deleting lower reference to Kennedy, now higher and to President Bush, also now higher
DOC.HEAD: Precede BRIDGETOWN, Barbados
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, arriving Saturday to celebrate Chile's return to democracy, said the United States expects outgoing President General Augusto Pinochet to honor ``a new era'' of civilian rule despite his continued control of the military. Under the constitution his regime wrote, Pinochet still heads Chile's 60,000-member military. But Quayle told reporters traveling with him that the ultimate authority is Patricio Aylwin, being inaugurated president Sunday. On another matter, Quayle raised the possibility of talking with outgoing Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega, also here for Aylwin's inauguration. He noted that the Feb. 25 elections in Nicaragua and Ortega's promise to abide by the results and turn over power to Violeta Chamorro makes it ``a different situation now'' and leaves ``no reason that I shouldn't talk'' to Ortega. He said no meeting with Ortega was scheduled, but added that ``I anticipate it could happen.'' During a brief airport arrival ceremony Saturday night, Quayle congratulated Chileans for bringing `the dawn of a new era of democracy'' through election. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a member of the U.S. party and sponsor of an arms ban against Chile, responded to Chilean reporters seeking a comment by proclaiming: ``It's extraordinary to breath the free air of Chile. Tomorrow is a day that I would not have missed in all the world.'' Quayle was to meet Sunday with Pinochet for what he called ``a short meeting in the line of protocol.'' He said he would carry messages from various individuals, including President Bush. During his stay in Chile, Quayle said he expected to raise the matter of the United States continued unsuccessful attempts to extradite two Chilean military officers wanted for trial in the 1976 killing in Washington of exiled former Chilean cabinet minister Orlando Letelier. Earlier in Bridgetown, Barbados, Quayle wrapped up talks with Caribbean leaders by pledging greater U.S. assistance to the region. Chile became the last country in South America to return to democracy. A potentially troubled future already looms, with Pinochet insisting on retaining control of the country's 60,000 strong military and victims of human rights abuses vowing to file thousands of criminal complaints against the military. Pinochet called the Dec. 14 election that Aylwin won after voters rejected a referendum in October 1988 that would have extended his rule to 1997. Quayle on Saturday met with six Caribbean heads of state in a session hosted by Barbados Prime Minister Lloyd Erskine Sandiford. Quayle told reporters the meeting focused on economic development issues of concern to Barbados, Dominica, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, St. Kitts, St. Lucia and Antigua. ``I had it pointed out to me very clearly ... the lack of adequate contribution this year,'' from the United States to the region, he said. ``I believe next year we will be able to do better,'' he added, but refused to give any dollar amounts. The talks covered educational opportunities and ``reforms in the way we approach agriculture,'' and other economic development, Quayle said. They touched only briefly on anti-drug cooperation, said Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith. The meeting came a day after the Pentagon announced it would increase aircraft and warship presence in the Caribbean to step up interdiction efforts. Quayle repeated what is becoming a refrain for his trip to Barbados and South America. He said people in the region should not believe the United States is overlooking them because of the intense interest in the Eastern Europe reforms. ``We are interested in the world, and we are particularly interested in the Western Hemisphere,'' he said. ``We are all Americans,'' he said, adding the Caribbean is ``a priority'' with Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested for Placing Fake Bomb at Synagogue
DOC.TEXT: Police have charged a 39-year-old man with placing a fake bomb at a synagogue featured in the movie ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' Gerald Bertolini of Forest Park was scheduled for arraignment on a misdemeanor charge Monday, said Atlanta Police Lt. LaSalle Smith. A package discovered on the front steps of The Temple March 3 caused the evacuation of 150 people attending a bat mitzvah. The package, wrapped in garbage bags and made to look like a bomb, also contained a videocassette tape and messages to Coretta Scott King and a local television anchorwoman. Smith alleged that Bertolini's name was found inside the package. Police said they don't believe Bertolini has a police record or a history of violence, or racist or anti-Semitic acts, but they haven't established a motive for the hoax. The Temple was bombed in 1958 in an attack that some said prompted religious leaders in the city to come together to fight anti-Semitism. Nobody was injured in the 1958 bombing, which blasted a 20-foot hole in a wall of the synagogue. That bombing figures in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' about an elderly Jewish woman's friendship with her black chauffeur.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Bars Doctors' Group From Collective Bargaining
DOC.TEXT: An organization of Colorado physicians may no longer negotiate prices with hospitals and insurance companies on behalf of its members, a federal judge has ruled in a lawsuit brought by the state. The ruling Friday concluded a state attorney general's price-fixing investigation into the Colorado Union of Physicians and Surgeons, which has more than 100 members. State Attorney General Duane Woodard said U.S. District Judge Sherman G. Finesilver barred the organization from acting as a collective bargaining unit on behalf of the physicians it represents, many of whom are in direct competition. The group's telephone number is unlisted. A state complaint contended the organization violated federal and state antitrust laws by engaging in a pattern of price-fixing. Woodard said the organization, with members in Denver and Pueblo, ``is not a bona fide labor union and its physician members are not employees.'' ``Therefore, the collective bargaining done by CUPS with various hospitals and health insurance plans is an illegal restraint of trade and amounts to price-fixing,'' he said. The organization agreed in a settlement of the complaint to pay the state $8,000 for investigative costs and attorney's fees. The complaint said the doctors' group and its members agreed on reimbursement for providing medical services to patients, then would negotiate for increased compensation with insurance companies, hospitals and health maintenance organizations. The complaint alleged that the group and its members threatened termination of existing contracts with insurance companies, hospitals and health maintenance organizations and threatened patients with billing on a ``fee for service basis'' if the companies refused to cooperate. Garth Lucero, first assistant attorney general, said a ``fee for service basis'' meant a patient would have been unable to get reimbursed for medical treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Legislature Passes Amnesty Law
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly on Saturday pardoned both the Contra rebels and Sandinista government workers accused of wrongdoing in a sweeping amnesty law of ``national reconciliation.'' ``We must avoid political vengeance and block any moves by hotheads in the National Opposition Union,'' said Carlos Nunez, president of the legislature. He was apparently referring to possible reprisals against Sandinista government workers after the opposition takes over April 25. The amnesty was proposed by leftist President Daniel Ortega after he lost the Feb. 25 presidential elections to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who headed the National Opposition Union's ticket. The leftist Sandinistas control the National Assembly, and lawmakers passed the law on a vote of 72 in favor with six abstentions. Only 78 of the 96 members were present. The law absolves Nicaraguans, ``residents or not in the country, who commit crimes against public order and against internal security of the state.'' The U.S.-backed Contras, who have fought to overthrow the Sandinistas, have resisted calls from the outgoing and incoming governments to lay down their weapons. About 11,000 Contras are based in border camps in Honduras. The ``Law of General Amnesty and Reconciliation'' was introduced Thursday, replacing an earlier version that prompted significant opposition. The wording of the new version was changed to make the amnesty more sweeping. The amnesty covers public employees who ``presumably committed crimes of failing in their duties, fraud or theft and have not been prosecuted'' between July 1979, when the Sandinistas came to power, and the day the law takes effect. Legislators said it will take effect between March 20-23 when it is published in the official government gazette. Edwin Illescas of the Democratic Conservative Party said he supported the law because he recognized that by holding elections, the Sandinistas were working for peace. He said similar laws had been passed in Argentina, Uruguay and Chile and hastened the return of democracy. The law says it is designed ``to contribute to the national reconciliation of all the sectors of society with the goal of peace and tranquillity to Nicaraguan families.'' ``The union of Nicaraguan families needs the pardon and to forget those deeds that brought anxiety and restlessness in the nation.'' ``The law is not to protect criminals'' but benefits ``people who have worked more than 10 years protecting the revolution,'' Nunez said. The Sandinistas hold 61 seats in the present legislature to 35 for the opposition. The 14-party National Opposition Union will hold a majority in the new legislature, with the Sandinistas remaining the largest single party.

DOC.HEAD: Former Foreign Secretary, Lord Stewart Dies
DOC.TEXT: Former British Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart died Saturday at Charing Cross Hospital after a brief illness, a hospital spokesman said. He was 83. The nature of Stewart's illness was not disclosed. During 1964-70 Stewart served as foreign secretary twice in the Labor government of former Prime Minister Harold Wilson. He also held the position of secretary of state for economic affairs. Stewart was a Labor member of Parliament for 34 years before receiving a life peerage in 1979. He became Lord Stewart of Fulham and moved into the House of Lords, where he remained active until his illness. As foreign secretary during the Vietnam war, Stewart came under pressure from the opposition Conservative Party for the government's policy, which refused to commit troops to aid the United States. He also faced criticism from left-wing Labor Party members who believed that the government was too sympathetic to the United States. The London-born former school teacher graduated from Oxford University and served in the Army Intelligence Corps during World War II. Lady Stewart, the former Mary Birkinshaw, died in 1985. The Stewarts had no children.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Calls for Unity As He Yields Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-15 bgng, `Vice President...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Quayle arrival and remarks; pickup graf 16 pvs, `Pinochet left...'
DOC.TEXT: To supporters' cheers and opponents' cries of ``murderer,'' right-wing Gen. Augusto Pinochet ended his last full day in power Saturday with a call for national unity behind his elected successor. Pinochet was snubbed by 10 foreign leaders, who delayed their arrivals for Sunday's inaugural ceremonies until he hands over power to Patricio Aylwin. Only three heads of state arrived during the day Saturday. In a taped good-bye speech broadcast nationally on television and radio Saturday night, Pinochet called on his countrymen ``to unite their forces to those of the new authorities.'' ``The president who is assuming power has the right to expect, from each of us, a responsible attitude,'' he said, standing erect in a white dress army uniform with the presidential sash. ``I want the best for my country, and I always will be ready to serve her,'' Pinochet said. The 74-year-old general plans to stay on as commander of the 60,000-man army, despite requests by Aylwin that he fully retire. In 1988, a proposal to extend Pinochet's rule to 1997 was defeated in a referendum, and the loss forced him to call elections last December. Aylwin, a 71-year-old Christian Democrat backed by a coalition of 17 centrist and leftist parties, won 55 percent of the vote. His closest challenger, a former Pinochet finance minister, won 29 percent. Pinochet feted visiting dignitaries in the presidential palace Saturday afternoon. Those who arrived Saturday included presidents Alberto LaCalle of Uruguay, Carlos Menem of Argentina and Jose Sarney of Brazil. Their visits ended years of international political isolation for the general. Among those delaying their arrivals were presidents Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, Alan Garcia of Peru, Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua, and prime ministers Giulio Andreotti of Italy and Felipe Gonzalez of Spain. Chilean Foreign Minister Hernan Errazuriz criticized their decisions, saying they displayed ``a lack of education.'' Vice President Dan Quayle arrived late Saturday from Venezuela and planned to meet with Pinochet at his residence in a Santiago neighborhood Sunday morning. Speaking at the airport, Quayle said the United States expects Pinochet to honor ``a new era'' of civilian rule. Traveling with Quayle was Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., despised by Pinochet and his supporters for his outspoken criticism of human rights abuses under the military government. Kennedy sponsored a 1976 ban, still in effect, on U.S. arms sales to Chile. Except for a papal tour in 1987, the last visit by a head of state to Chile was that of Brazilian military President Joao Figueiredo in 1982. Pinochet's last attempt to go abroad, in 1980, had to be aborted when then-Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos withdrew an invitiation even though Pinochet already was in mid-flight. Pinochet left the three-story presidential palace late Saturday afternoon for the last time by the front door, to both cheers and boos. ``Viva Pinochet!'' shouted supporters. Others cried ``Murderer!'' and yelled obscenities as he climbed into his armored Mercedes Benz and drove off with his customary, heavily armed military escort. As he took his leave after ruling for 16{ years, some palace functionaires wept. But he gently chided them: ``No one has died here.'' He called on everyone ``to keep working.'' Workmen in Valparaiso, a resort town near Santiago, prepared a new, half-finished congressional palace for Sunday's inaugural ceremony. Others in Santiago swept up debris from a series of small terrorist bomb blasts Friday that left one person injured. About 40 relatives and sympathizers of leftists jailed on terrorism charges staged a protest inside Santiago's downtown cathedral on Saturday, occupying the pews. But the protest was peaceful and they vacated the building without incident after about seven hours. A spokesman for the protesters, Mirnas Rivas, told reporters: ``There can be no transition to democracy in Chile if political prisoners aren't freed.'' Aylwin has said he favors freeing prisoners of conscience but not those convicted of guerrilla or terrorist actions. The military government says all of those now jailed are charged or convicted in connection with guerrilla activity. Pinochet took power in September 1973 in a bloody coup that toppled the elected government of President Salvador Allende, an avowed Marxist, during a period of political and economic disorder. He suspended congress and launched a harsh crackdown on leftists and dissidents that earned his government a worldwide reputation for systematic human rights abuses. Also attending Aylwin's inauguration will be Joyce Horman, widow of Charles Horman, an American free-lance journalist whose arrest and killing during the 1973 coup inspired the movie ``Missing.'' According to the family and testimony collected by human rights groups, Horman was among many suspected dissidents held and executed at Santiago's National Stadium. The military government has denied the allegations. Mrs. Horman of New York was invited by the new government and was expected to attend several events surrounding the inauguration. She arrived Saturday. Police said at least 11 small bombs went off across Santiago during a 45-minute period late Friday night. No one claimed responsibility for the blasts. In one of the explosions, in an underground tool shed at a city park near the downtown U.S. Consulate, one worker was injured in the face and hands, police said. Other bombs went off at or near several government offices, a Mormon chapel, a courthouse, an army colonel's house and two businesses. Aylwin characterized the bombings as ``strange.'' He spoke to reporters in front of his home before leaving for Valparaiso, where he planned to spend the night. Small groups of leftist extremists are active in Chile, but there is widespread suspicion that at least in some cases the attacks attributed to them are the work of rightists who want to exaggerate the leftist threat.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. Archbishop Seeks Nuns, Priests to Test AIDS Vaccine
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Los Angeles has asked elderly nuns and priests to volunteer to be inoculated with an experimental AIDS vaccine. Archbishop Roger Mahony has sent a letter to the 3,500 priests and nuns in the Los Angeles archdiocese, seeking 10 volunteers age 65 or older. The prototype vaccine was developed by Dr. Jonas Salk, father of the commercial polio vaccine. The appeal was first reported by the Chicago Tribune, which said some scientists are concerned about the proposed experiment and the safety of Salk's vaccine. That is because the prototype vaccine is the only one among several being developed that is made from the whole AIDS virus. Critics say that if live strains of the virus contaminate the vacine, the volunteers could be accidentally infected, the paper said in its Sunday editions. The main reason for seeking volunteers from the ranks of the church was that they presumably would be most unlikely to have been infected with AIDS through the two most common means _ sexual intercourse or intravenous drug use, the paper said. The Rev. Kevin Kostelnik, who was working Saturday night at St. Vibiana's Church adjacent to Mahony's residence, said a letter requesting volunteers was sent out two months ago. ``The letter really didn't go into detail,'' Kostelnik said. ``I work in the office so I didn't see the need to respond to it.'' Kostelnik said he couldn't recall the details of the letter, but that it was sent to all the nuns and priests in Los Angeles and was seeking five to ten volunteers. Mahony is in Rome until March 19, Kostelnik said. Scores of Americans were infected with polio in the early 1950s when Salk used the same technique in developing the polio vaccine that eventually saved thousands of lives. A government investigation later determined the infections resulted when the virus contained in the vaccine hadn't been killed, as it was supposed to have been. Thus, if any of the volunteers were to test positive later for the AIDS virus, the infection could be traced directly to live virus that had contaminated the vaccine. The appeal by Mahony to the religious community was accompanied by a letter in which Dr. Brian Henderson of the University of Southern California said Salk would be the first volunteer. The 75-year-old Salk works at the La Jolla, Calif., institute that bears his name. Henderson, one of Salk's collaborators, added another reason for appealing to priests and nuns: the need for ``individuals who would find a role as such a volunteer a meaningful part of their life.'' Salk said he hasn't inoculated himself or any voluteers because the proposed experiment had yet to be approved by California authorities, the Tribune said. Salk developed the first polio vaccine, which was pronounced safe and effective on April 12, 1955. The dead-virus vaccine was administered by injection. In the 1960s, an oral polio vaccine was developed by Dr. Albert Sabin, and it has generally replaced the Salk vaccine, in part because of the ease of giving it. The vaccine developed by Sabin is also more potent and long-lasting, but because it uses tamed live virus, one of about every 3.2 million doses results in paralytic polio, according to the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Military Leader Resigns After Mass Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CLARIFY that opposition members were in disagreement prior to meeting with Abraham and that it was unknown whether they reached agreement later, SUB 5th graf pvs, `Members of...' Pickup 6th graf pvs, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Haitian ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, who rose to power 18 months ago in a revolt by pro-democracy soldiers, resigned Saturday during a popular uprising against his military regime. The embattled Haitian leader turned over power to Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army chief of staff, who said he would transfer rule to a civilian-led government within 72 hours. Abraham said the interim government would prepare for elections but did not give a date. Diplomat sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Avril would leave the country within two days. There was no word on where he would go and how he would get there. Immediately after Avril's resignation, members of a coalition of opposition parties disagreed over the provisions for Abraham's rule and there also was discord over who would lead the civilian government. The opposition members later met with Abraham and it was not immediately known whether they reached agreement. They scheduled a news conference for Sunday morning. It was Haiti's fifth change of government since February 1986, when dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled the impoverished Caribbean nation into exile in France. Avril's departure followed five days of mass protests. His opponents said they no longer trusted him to usher in fair elections that had been scheduled for October. Thousands of residents poured into the streets of the capital to celebrate. Youths erected flaming tire barricades at major intersections, and black smoke filled the sky over the capital. The television station Tele-Haiti said teen-agers shouted slogans outside the house of a special police agent in the slum suburb of Martissant, and that the agent and backers ``wildly'' opened fire, killing six. Radio Metropole said seven were killed. Sporadic gunfire was heard throughout the capital, Port-au-Prince, and there were power outages in some neighborhoods. Independent Radio Metropole said the houses of some Duvalier and Avril sympathizers had been ransacked and their cars burned. On radio talk shows, callers demanded that Avril be thrown out of the country. Abraham, in uniform, appeared on state television at 3:05 p.m. EST to announce Avril's resignation. ``In light of the resignation of the military government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, the armed forces of Haiti accept the heavy task,'' Abraham said in French. ``The mission is clear and the objective is precise: to re-establish peace and order within 72 hours so, in conformity with the constitution, a provisional government can organize elections.'' Abraham and the army want to give the interim presidency to Supreme Court President Gilbert Austin, who had been appointed by Avril as chief justice last year after serving as the general's justice minister. However, the opposition coalition _ called the Unity Assembly _ said he would be a puppet of the army and that it wanted him to resign as president of the high court. ``It is the president of the Supreme Court who, according to the constitution, should be president,'' Austin said Saturday night. There had been speculation that 51-year-old Avril wanted to return to his old job as army chief of staff. However, Tele-Haiti, an independent television station, said he was retiring from the army. Radio Metropole said Avril left the palace Saturday afternoon and was at his private residence in the wealthy suburb of Canape Vert, on the hills overlooking Port-au-Prince. Conservative leader Hubert De Ronceray, one of seven prominent politicians forced into exile in a government crackdown in January, said Avril's resignation was ``an encouraging first step.'' ``But Prosper Avril is still a public danger if he stays in Haiti,'' said De Ronceray, speaking by telephone from Miami. Another exile, Louis Roy, principal author of Haiti's 1987 constitution, said from the Caribbean island of Martinique that the Haitian people had ``risen and overthrown a regime which had tried to destroy its desire for a democratic form of government.'' But, he added: ``It remains to be seen whether the army deserves the confidence which has been placed in it.'' In Washington, the Bush administration welcomed the promise by Haiti's new leader to set the stage for national elections by turning over power within 72 hours. The statement said the United States long has called for improved human rights in Haiti and added: ``We obviously hope the latest developments contribute to a realization of this objective.'' Tele-Haiti said the interim president would be advised by an 11-member council representing civic groups, churches, the army and eight provincial districts. Earlier, the opposition coalition had said it wanted Supreme Court vice president Gabriel Volcy as the new provisional head. But Antoine Izmery, a prominent businessman who belongs to the Unity Assembly, said Volcy refused. He said ``it's an all-out war'' if Abraham remains in power for 72 hours. However, other political leaders were more conciliatory. Mark Bazin, an economist who leads a center-right party said he was ``reassured about Abraham's good faith to play according to the rules.'' He did not elaborate. Avril came to power in September 1988 in a coup by non-commissioned officers. He promised to hand over power to a civilian government after elections this fall. But critics said a brutal crackdown in January on government critics made clear that Avril intended to renege on that promise and make himself a dictator. Speculation Avril might be on his way out began growing Monday after a soldier killed an 11-year-old girl, apparently accidentally during a demonstration. The killing set off a spate of violent anti-government protests across the country that resulted in the deaths of at least three people. Haiti, the poorest country in the hemisphere, has been ruled by force of arms for most of its history since independence from France in 1804. After Jean-Claude Duvalier went into exile in 1986, he was replaced by Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, Duvalier's army chief of staff. He headed a three-man provisional junta that was to rule until elections for a new government. The first election attempt in November 1987 was called off hours into the vote after thugs killed at least 34 voters and confiscated ballots. In January 1988, Leslie Manigat, a university professor, was elected president. Few Haitians voted, and most opposition leaders refused to participate. Five months later, Namphy entered the picture again. His troops deposed Manigat, who had tried to fire Namphy. Avril replaced Namphy in the coup of September 1988.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Clean Air a0649
DOC.TEXT: The Senate agreed Friday to protect cities along the Southwest border from proposed clean air sanctions if their pollution comes from Mexico. The government, in assessing whether a city or region is in compliance with clean air standards, would have to consider whether the emissions originate across the border, according to the amendment to the clean air bill. ``Without this amendment, if the pollution in Juarez continues to get worse, it could technically shut down El Paso because of pollution someone else is causing,'' said sponsor Phil Gramm, R-Texas. ``It is imperative to not let cities along the border, in Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California, be penalized for pollution that they are victims of rather than generators of,'' Gramm said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Confirms Dunne for Civil Rights Post
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Friday unanimously confirmed John R. Dunne to be assistant attorney general for civil rights, filling a 15-month-old vacancy at the Justice Department. Dunne, a former New York state senator with little prior involvement in civil rights issues, was confirmed by voice vote. A day earlier, the Senate Judiciary Committee had recommended Dunne despite criticism over his former memberships in clubs that excluded women and stock holdings in a company that does business in South Africa Sen. Howard Metzenbaum D-Ohio, the only committee member to vote against Dunne on Thursday, complained that Dunne ``will probably be as good an appointee to head the division as we are going to get from this administration.'' Dunne, 60, of Garden City, N.Y., was nominated in January for the post, which had been vacant since December 1988 when William Bradford Reynolds resigned. President Bush's first choice for the job, William C. Lucas of Michigan, a former sheriff and county executive, was rejected by the Judiciary Committee by a 7-7 vote last August. Lucas had spent most of his career in law enforcement and had little litigation experience. He was opposed by many civil rights organizations. A virtual unknown in Washington, Dunne played a minor role in Bush's New York campaign. He had a powerful booster in Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, whom he has known since 1972 when they traveled to Japan among a group of young American political leaders. Dunne was a New York state senator for 24 years, resigning last year after losing a race for majority leader. Dunne is a partner in the Uniondale, N.Y., law firm of Rivkin, Radler, Dunne & Bayh. Civil rights groups criticized Dunne's almost non-existent civil rights record, but none opposed his nomination. Many had praise for the work he did helping to reform the New York prison system after the deadly 1971 riot at Attica state prison. But Dunne drew fire for having held longtime memberships in the Fort Orange Club in Albany, N.Y., and the Garden City Golf Club on Long Island, N.Y. The Fort Orange admitted women in 1988; the golf club is still sex-segregated. During his confirmation hearing, Dunne expressed regret at having joined the clubs. As for his nearly $20,000 worth of stock in a company doing business in South Africa, Dunne expressed willingness to divest it.

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Files Papers Opposing Injunction in Picture Exchange Suit
DOC.TEXT: Reuters filed court papers Friday opposing United Press International's request for a preliminary injunction barring Reuters from backing out of a picture exchange agreement. The memorandum was in response to a counterclaim made by UPI to a Reuters' lawsuit in U.S. District Court in Manhattan that seeks to void the contract between the two news services. Reuters denied allegations made by UPI that it had ``poached'' certain UPI clients, taken away employees and was trying to drive UPI out of business. ``It is a collection of inflammatory statements based on no authority whatever or on serious distortions of the documents at issue,'' Reuters said. Oral arguments on the request for a preliminary injunction will be heard Monday by Judge Peter K. Leisure. A temporary restraining order against Reuters is in effect until the judge decides whether to issue the injunction. Milt Capps, UPI's senior vice president for corporate affairs, was traveling and not available for comment, his office said. The agreement at issue was entered into in 1984 and called for UPI to supply Reuters with pictures from the United States, while Reuters would provide UPI with pictures from other countries. It was to run for 10 years. Last month Reuters said the agreement was not living up to its expectations and it was terminating it. UPI is opposing such a move.

DOC.HEAD: Paulsen to Run for President Again, After Mayoral Race
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Pat Paulsen, a perennial presidential candidate, has announced plans to enter the race for the last time in 1992. But first, he said, he will run for mayor of Longboat Key. Paulsen unveiled his plans at a beach resort Thursday. ``My good friend _ what's his name? _ Dr. Murf Klauber, asked me to come down and straighten the town out,'' Paulsen said. ``I'm down here to take the shackles off of Longboat, get some more involved people as commissioners.'' Paulsen announced tongue-in-cheek plans for local improvements. ``See that sand out there,'' he said pointing to the beach. ``It gets in your shoes. I think it should be paved over.'' That should squelch concerns about beach erosion, he said. What about the turtles? ``Who needs turtles?'' he said. Paulsen said he had $79 in his treasury before his Florida stop. In his 1972 run for president, Paulsen said he captured 2 percent of the vote in the New Hampshire primary and should have been elected. ``I can't run a tape recorder,'' he said. ``I would have been in no trouble.'' His slogan is ``Pat Who? in '92.'' The 62-year-old Paulsen said his chances look good this time _ his last to hit the trail _ if he runs as a Democrat. ``They don't know which way is up,'' he said. ``There will be lots of comedians in the race, especially the Democrats.''

DOC.HEAD: Garn Announces End of Electronic Battlefield
DOC.TEXT: Air Force plans to build a $2.5 billion electronic battlefield in Utah have been scrapped because of cuts in the military budget, Sen. Jake Garn said. Garn, R-Utah, met Thursday with Air Force Lt. Col. Neal Branford and an Air Force fiscal analyst. The senator had sought the meeting following rumors that the future of the battlefield proposed for Utah's western desert was in jeopardy. Garn said the Air Force officials told him that given the military budget cuts President Bush has proposed, and with Congress expected to make even deeper cuts in the Pentagon budget, the battlefield ``simply will not be built.'' The officials also said the costs of the battlefield had grown over what they had originally estimated, Garn said. The Air Force requested no money for the battlefield in the fiscal 1991 budget. The Air Force officials told Garn their projected five-year budget also includes no money for the battlefield. Garn said, however, that operational electronic warfare simulation ranges in other states, most likely Nevada and California, will be upgraded. Rumors in military and civilian circles have pointed to plans for augmenting electronic battle capability projects at Fallon Naval Station in Nevada and at the China Lake Naval Weapons Station in California. The electronic battlefield, known in the Air Force as Electronic Combat Test Capability, simulates enemy defense systems such as radio- and radar-jamming devices and radar signals from surface-to-air missiles. Opponents of the Utah battlefield, which would have sprinkled sophisticated electronic combat simulation devices throughout the state's west desert, were jubilant over the announcement. ``I feel real good about it,'' said Juab County Commissioner Richard Brough. ``It was just an excuse on the part of the Air Force to get more airspace. That's all it amounted to.'' Desert ranchers had been worried about the effect of low-level warplane flights on herds.

DOC.HEAD: 110 Pounds of Heroin Found in Fuel Tank of Truck from Turkey
DOC.TEXT: Customs officers found 110 pounds of heroin in the fuel tank of a truck from Turkey, and on Friday the driver was arrested, authorities said. It was one of Britain's largest heroin seizures. The heroin, with a street value of at least $7 million, was discovered late Thursday when the truck arrived at the southeastern port of Ramsgate on a cross-channel ferry, officials said. The driver had driven a cargo of rugs from Turkey to Dunkirk, France, where he boarded the ferry, they said. The heroin, concealed in a secret compartment, was discovered during a routine check. ``Turkey is a source-country for heroin and we carry out random checks,'' said a customs spokesman, who was not identified in accordance with British practice. ``This time we struck it lucky.'' The driver, Ihsan Uskupluoglu, 27, was charged with illegally importing heroin, Customs said.

DOC.HEAD: Simpson Blasts Gephardt as War of Words Escalates
DOC.TEXT: The war of words between the Bush administration and House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt spread to the Senate floor Friday as the No.2 Republican called Gephardt ``a frustrated font of trivia.'' ``Old Richard is just going bananas,'' Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., the assistant GOP leader, said in a five-minute floor speech devoted primarily to attacks on Gephardt. Gephardt this week criticized President Bush for failing to wield leadership in Eastern Europe and proposed to provide direct economic aid to the Soviet Union. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater fired back that Gephardt has become the ``Maxwell Smart'' of politics, likening the Missouri Democrat to the bumbling character of the 1960s ``Get Smart'' TV show. Simpson, while acknowledging that Gephardt is talented and articulate, complained he ``has taken some pretty personal potshots at the president ... He seems to delight in that. I think its time to take a swift look at the institutional life of this frustrated font of trivia about our fine president.'' Simpson said Gephardt's criticism was prompted by the failure of his race for the Democratic presidential nomination and the success of the Bush campaign for the White House. ``It doesn't take any brains to be a critic,'' Simpson said. ``Anyone can qualify. All you need is a shrill voice and usually a human target.'' Gephardt communications director David Dreyer said in a statement that it ``shows a low opinion of the American people when the Republicans launch a personal attack against Congressman Gephardt, who is urging greater American leadership to advance democracy in the Eastern Bloc.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Flag Burned at Congressional Hearing on Puerto Rican Status
DOC.TEXT: Puerto Rican nationalists burned and stomped on an American flag Friday to protest congressional hearings on the island's future ties with the United States. The protest by dozens of independence supporters coincided with the first of three days of hearings in San Juan by an eight-member congressional delegation. Eighty witnesses are scheduled to testify on a proposed referendum in June 1991 on the Caribbean island's future. About 100 protesters calling themselves the Socialist Front Against the Plebiscite carried signs saying ``No to Colonialism'' and ``Independence'' outside the hearings at the Fine Arts Performing Center. They also sang the Puerto Rican anthem. Some of the protesters then torched the U.S. flag and stomped on it before peacefully dispersing. Voters are to choose whether Puerto Rico will become the 51st state, gain independence or take on an ``enhanced'' form of commonwealth with more autonomy. The issue of political status is an emotional one on this U.S. commonwealth of 3.3 million people. It has virtually dominated politics since the island was ceded by Spain in 1898 after the Spanish-American War. The 1991 referendum would be the first vote in more than 20 years on the island's status. In a 1967 referendum, 60 percent voted to continue as a commonwealth, 39 percent favored statehood, and 1 percent backed independence. Under commonwealth status, Puerto Ricans are U.S. citizens eligible for military service, food stamps and other benefits. But they don't pay taxes or vote for president. The hearings by the House Insular and International Affairs Subcommittee are chaired by U.S. Virgin Islands congressional delegate, Ron de Lugo. The hearings are aimed at determining how much each option would cost the U.S. Treasury, whether the vote should be automatically binding, and whether a simple majority should be enough to adopt a given option.

DOC.HEAD: San Antonio Thrift Sold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 15th graf: ``Receiverships also,'' with Kan., Calif. actions
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators sold a failed Texas savings institution Friday to a holding company controlled by financier Ronald O. Perelman in a deal that will cost the government $890 million. The buyer is putting up $10 million. The Resolution Trust Corp., created in August to dispose of failed thrifts, sold San Antonio Savings Savings Association to First Gibraltar Holdings Inc. The holding company already owns First Gibraltar Bank, a Dallas-based S&L with assets of over $9 billion. It was formed in 1988 from five smaller insolvent S&Ls in a much criticized bailout deal that required $5.1 billion in federal assistance and favorable tax breaks. The name of the San Antonio S&L will be changed to First Gibraltar Bank, but it will be maintained as a separate financial institution. Earlier this week, the Resolution Trust Corp. board voted to allow thrifts created in earlier bailouts to bid for newly failed S&Ls. However, because Congress has ordered the corporation to review the old bailouts, the agency is requiring First Gibralatar Holdings to maintain the San Antonio institution as a separately capitalized entity. The corporation said First Gibraltar's proposal was the cheapest of seven received. The holding company is taking $1.1 billion of San Antonio's $2.3 billion in assets. It agreed to assume responsibility for deposits of $2 billion in 220,000 accounts and other liabilities of $750 million. It is putting up $10 million of its own money. In return, the corporation agreed to advance $1.6 billion to First Gibraltar. The agency is keeping about $1.1 billion in sour loans. After those are sold, the net expense to the government will total an estimated $890 million. An investor group, MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., controls First Gibralatar Holdings. Its investors include Perelman and Revlon Inc. Dallas newspapers reported earlier this week that Perelman's group had emerged as the winner of a bidding war. Others reportedly interested in the San Antonio S&L were NCNB Texas, Banc One Corp. of Columbus, Ohio, and Security Pacific Corp. of Los Angeles. Analysts say the deal is a good one for First Gibraltar, expanding its retail base from Dallas to both Houston and San Antonio. It is the second big S&L bailout in Texas this year. Last month, the RTC pledged $1.1 billion in the sale of Bright Banc Savings Association of Dallas to Banc One Corp. of Columbus Ohio. The Resolution Trust Corp. has taken over more than 390 S&Ls, disposing of 51 mostly small institutions. In another action Friday, the agency moved to protect itself against the claims of creditors of CenTrust Bank, Miami. CenTrust, with $8.9 billion in assets, was seized by the government on Feb. 2. It was placed into receivership on Friday. Receiverships also were established for Hiawatha Savings and Loan Association of Hiawatha, Kan., and Westport Savings Bank of Hanford, Calif. In other S&L developments Friday: _The Treasury Department-led RTC Oversight Board, which controls the policy and pursestrings of the bailout, approved a change designed to speed the sale of repossessed real estate. It authorized the corporation to accept down payments as low as 15 percent, a reduction from 25 percent. _The Federal Housing Finance Board announced it had allowed the first two commercial banks to join the Federal Home Loan Bank System. Membership in the system, created in 1934 to provide low-cost financing for home mortgages, had previously been restricted to savings institutions. The S&L law enacted last August allows banks and credit unions to join if they devote at least 10 percent of their assets to residential housing. The two new members are the National Bank of Bremerton, Bremerton, Wash., and North American Bank and Trust Co., Waterbury, Conn. _The Bush administration filled out its S&L bureaucracy. It appointed Frank G. Zarb, chairman of Smith Barney, a New York brokerage firm, as chairman of a national advisory board overseeing the RTC's real estate sales. Six five-member regional advisory boards were created with headquarters in New York, Atlanta, Kansas City, Dallas, Denver and Los Angeles. The national board will consist of the regional chairmen and Zarb.

DOC.HEAD: First Conference Opens To Unite Bulgarian Opposition
DOC.TEXT: Delegates from dozens of independent groups opened a three-day conference Friday to unite Bulgaria's non-Communist opposition prior to multiparty elections in June. As the meeting began in Plovdiv, the country's second largest city, about 150,000 people demonstrated in the capital, Sofia, for a free press, the state media reported. The Sofia rally was called by the Union of Democratic Forces, or UDF, the leading opposition alliance, and by editors of several recently formed independent publications. Speakers called for a larger distribution of newsprint to opposition publications and no limit on subscriptions, the state BTA news agency and state-run television reported. The Plovdiv gathering is the first such opposition conference. Its main purpose is to seek ways to mount a common front to challenge the Communists in the elections by uniting the UDF; a recently formed Political Opposition Bloc, and other independent parties. But the going will apparently not be easy. Some delegates suggested that the UDF leadership shun groups organized along ethnic or religious lines. Petko Simeonov, a senior leader in UDF, said his group now includes 15 parties and political groups and four other parties are about to join. ``The UDF has always been in favor of united actions of the opposition,'' Simeonov told delegates. ``We want to know who the other political parties are who in the future want to establish a common program with us and a common list of candidates.'' The UDF is the only opposition alliance involved in talks with the ruling Communists. The Communists began the talks and other reforms after Todor Zhivkov, the longtime, hard-line Communist leader, was ousted in November during mass demonstrations. Representatives of Bulgaria's more than 1.2 million Turks and other Moslems were not invited to the Plovdiv meeting, nor was an organization representing the country's 800,000 Gypsies. The local Christian Democratic Party, a member of the Political Opposition Bloc, was acting as host in Plovdiv, about 100 miles southeast of Sofia. A total of 23 political parties and groups made brief political statements outlining their programs. Their memberships were said to range from 600 to more than 200,000.

DOC.HEAD: Collor de Mello Names Farm Minister, Vows `Revolution'
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello on Friday named as his minister of agriculture Gov. Joaquim Roriz of the capital district, who immediately pledged more agrarian reform. The issue has often caused bloody clashes and divided this vast nation of 150 million people. Half the arable land is in the hands of 4 percent of the population, according to government figures. In another appointment, Brazil's top police officer, Romeu Tuma, was picked to monitor tax collecting and prices. The incoming president says he wants to wage war on the ``abuses of the elites.'' Economist-rancher Roriz, 53, was named as minister of agriculture and agrarian reform Friday at a news conference in the capital, Brasilia. Roriz, named governor of the federal district of Brasilia in 1988 by President Jose Sarney, had planned to run for re-election behind a swell of popular support. Collor de Mello, who takes office on Nov. 15 for a five-year term, said Roriz had been instructed to start ``an agricultural revolution in the country.'' He gave no details. The future minister said ``only a peaceful, social and fair agrarian reform'' would bring about such a revolution, but he also was not specific. Collor de Mello is a conservative who ran as a free-market advocate, but he also claimed to champion the causes of Brazil's masses. In 1985, Sarney promised to distribute 90 million acres of land among 1.4 million families before 1989. He said 5.7 million families would be relocated by the year 2000. But only about 20,000 families have received land, while government statistics show 12 million farmers live in poverty. The president-elect named Tuma to take over the Federal Income bureau _ Brazil's equivalent of the Internal Revenue Service _ and the Supply and Prices Superintendency. He also will continue as chief of federal police. Tuma, 58, immediately declared, ``From now on, corruption and tax evasion are problems for the police.'' He began his career in 1953 as an investigator for the ``political police.'' The secret service investigated leftists and political opponents of the right-wing military regime, which ruled from 1964 to 1985.
