As director of the Sao Paulo state political police, Tuma received world acclaim in 1985 for discovering and identifying the remains of Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele. Tuma is the only top-level member of Sarney's administration who will keep his post under Collor de Mello.

DOC.HEAD: Inspection Finds Improperly Installed Pins
DOC.TEXT: The motorman who operated a subway train during a fatal derailment this week tested positive for cocaine, and federal investigators Friday found problems with other cars that run the same underground line. John K. Lauber of the National Transportation Safety Board said urine tests uncovered traces of cocaine in the motorman's system. Louis Gambaccini, general manager of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, said the motorman would be suspended as of Monday. No other details about the employee, including his name, were released. Investigators believe a motor under a subway car became dislodged Wednesday, hitting a switch and sending half the six-car train onto a second set of tracks. The fourth car smashed into steel support beams, killing three passengers and trapping survivors. Of 94 injured, 10 were still hospitalized Friday, all in good or satisfactory condition, hospital officials said. A 37-block stretch of the subway and elevated train line remained closed Friday, with buses ferrying passengers through west Philadelphia. Service was expected to resume Monday. In another development, Lauber said inspectors examined 76 motors on 19 cars. They found 27 pins installed incorrectly in nuts that help hold the motors under the cars. SEPTA has agreed to thoroughly inspect all cars running the line, Lauber said. The motor that became partially dislodged and was dragged along the subway tracks shortly before Wednesday's crash should have been attached to the car by a long vertical bolt, held on by a nut with a cotter pin inserted through the bolt and nut. A horizontal bolt and safety bracket would have been a backup in case the vertical bolt came loose. But the safety bracket, two thick steel loops that normally hold a horizontal bolt, had worn through in two places. In addition, the nut and cotter pin holding the vertical bolt onto the car apparently were lost before the crash, Lauber said. The safety bracket tore loose and the motor fell, he said. The motor gouged a 1,500-foot section of railroad ties before hitting the crossover switch and jerking the last three cars to a second set of tracks, Lauber said. The fourth car was peeled open and nearly cut in half by steel support beams. Seven people were trapped, including the three who died. NTSB investigators had been told of at least three times _ once during the past six months, once from 1980 to 1982 and once in 1975 _ when motors broke loose, Lauber said. But investigators did not know whether those motors had fallen to the tracks, NTSB spokesman Alan Pollock said Friday. ``We're trying to get the exact details,'' he said. Erich Vogel, chief mechanical officer for SEPTA, confirmed that bolts had come loose previously, but he believed the motors always had been caught by the safety brackets. ``I've been here since 1985 and we haven't lost a motor that I know of,'' he said. The cars are inspected visually once a month and more thoroughly every 12,000 miles, or about four to five months, Vogel said. Each car also has an annual inspection, the most thorough of the three types, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lindsay, Distinguished Marxist, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Jack Lindsay, a prolific Australian man of letters and lifelong Marxist, died at his home in the English university city of Cambridge. He was 89. Lindsay, who had written, edited or translated more than 170 books, died Thursday, according to his family. ``He died peacefully of old age after a good, long life,'' his Dutch wife, Meta, told The Associated Press on Friday. Lindsay came to England in 1926 and never returned to his homeland. But his reputation during self-imposed exile flourished in Australia, where he was given the title of Officer of the Order of Australia in 1981. His book that year, ``The Crisis of Marxism,'' was an often agonized analysis of failures he perceived in contemporary Marxist philosophy. Lindsay's works included novels, plays and poetry, literary criticism, history and biographies of historical figures, writers and artists, as well as translations of classical writers. Mrs. Lindsay said her husband liked best his biography of the English painter, J.M.W. Turner. An obituary in The Times of London described Lindsay as ``an immensely learned man.'' It said his socialist beliefs deprived his work of ``the serious attention it deserves.'' Lindsay was born in Melbourne in 1900 into a literary and artistic family. He tried to start a literary movement in Sydney but then emigrated to London. There, he founded the Fanfrolico Press, which published classical translations. More than 1 million copies of his novels of British life were published in translation in the Soviet Union. He was given the Soviet Order of Merit in 1968. Lindsay was active in socialist politics in the 1930s and served in the Signal Corps and at the War Office during World War II. His four volumes of autobiography contain accounts of literary life in Australia, England and France. He married twice. He had a son and daughter with his second wife, Meta Waterdrinker, who he met at a peace conference in the Netherlands and married in 1958. Their children, Philip and Helen, survive. There will be a private family funeral in Cambridge on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Death Sentence in Murder Case Linked to Mail Bombings
DOC.TEXT: A man was sentenced to die Friday for the shotgun slaying of a woman whose death was cited in a letter claiming responsibility for a series of fatal mail bombings in the South. A state jury deliberated about 4{ hours before sentencing Emmanuel Hammond to die in the electric chair for the 1988 murder of Julie Love, a 27-year-old preschool fitness instructor. Hammond, 24, was convicted by the same jury Wednesday of murder, kidnapping and armed robbery. Superior Court Judge Ralph Hicks sentenced Hammond to life in prison on the armed robbery count and 20 years for kidnapping. Miss Love, 27, of Atlanta disappeared in July 1988 and was the subject of a much-publicized search until her body was found in a northeast Atlanta wooded dumping ground last August. She had been shot in the head with a shotgun. Hammond denied on the witness stand that he had killed Miss Love. The trial was held under heavy security, in part because of a letter claiming responsibility for four mail bombings in the South in December. Two of the bombs killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance and Savannah lawyer Robert Robinson. The letter, signed by ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System,'' expressed outrage over the killing of Miss Love and threatened violence if other white women were attacked by black men in Alabama, Florida or Georgia. Miss Love was white. Hammond is black. Hammond's co-defendant and cousin, W. Maurice Porter, has pleaded guilty to murder, armed robbery and rape in Miss Love's killing. He has yet to be sentenced.

Oliver North says he lied repeatedly to Congress after national security adviser John Poindexter told him to ``take care of'' inquiries into whether he was secretly assisting the Nicaraguan rebels. But ``nobody ever told me to lie to Congress,'' North testified Friday at Poindexter's trial, insisting that he decided on his own to make the false statements after his boss sent him to meet with House Intelligence Committee members on Aug. 6, 1986. Poindexter watched intently while North spent the day on the witness stand in U.S. District Court, reluctantly testifying against his former boss on the National Security Council staff. North, the government's first witness, returns Monday to face questioning about the Iran initiative. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb led North through his recollections of a conversation with Poindexter, in which North said he didn't think it would be a ``very good idea'' to meet with the congressmen.

Georgia has become the fourth Soviet republic condemning its annexation to the Soviet Union, calling the move ``an international crime'' and demanding talks to secure independence, a local news agency reported. The decision Friday by Georgia's lawmakers came on the eve of a Lithuanian parliamentary session expected to consider secession. Lithuania would be the first of the Soviet Union's 15 republics to declare independence and would confront President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in one of his gravest crises during his 5-year-old rule. The Soviet Parliament is to vote Monday on his proposal to increase presidential power over unruly republics. All three Baltic republics _ Latvia and Estonia as well as Lithuania _ have condemned Soviet annexation of their lands a half century ago and have strong pro-independence movements.

The state House approved a bill that would outlaw abortion as a method of birth control and provide the nation's strongest challenge to a 1973 Supreme Court ruling legalizing abortion. ``We're really excited,'' Nancy Myers, a spokeswoman for National Right to Life Committee in Washington, D.C., said after Friday's 47-36 vote. ``We consider it to be extremely significant.'' The measure was forwarded to the Senate after more than three hours of debate before a gallery packed with activists from both sides of the issue. The bill could come to a final Senate floor vote as early as Friday, and opponents said it stood a good chance of passing. The GOP controls both houses of the Legislature. The bill, like legislation rejected recently in Minnesota and Utah, would outlaw abortion as a method of birth control. It would allow abortions only in cases of rape, incest, ``profound and irremediable'' fetal disabilities, or to save the life or prevent ``severe and long-lasting physical health damage'' to the mother.

A presidential commission is trying to find out how many people changed travel plans when the U.S. Embassy in Moscow disseminated a terrorism warning before the 1988 bombing of Pan American Flight 103. Two embassy witnesses testified under oath Friday that a notice from the Federal Aviation Administration of bomb threats against Pan Am flights en route to the United States was posted in several places around the diplomatic compound and outside and also was sent to Soviet officials. The State Department previously acknowledged only that the notice was improperly posted in the embassy a week before Flight 103 blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people on Dec. 21, 1988. Officials said the posting violated a policy against notifying government personnel when others are not told of a threat.

The U.S. military is widening its role in the war on drugs, but critics say the Pentagon may be battling a foe it cannot defeat. ``American troops will be entering a quagmire more complex than Vietnam,'' said Kevin Zeese, vice president of the Drug Policy Foundation, a Washington think tank that emphasizes the economic and social issues behind the drug problem. Zeese commented after the Defense Department announced Friday that it was adding warships, aircraft, radar equipment, dog teams and other military resources in the Atlantic, Pacific, Caribbean and along the southern U.S. border. The plan greatly extends the military's involvement in efforts to stem the flow of drugs into the United States and to help Colombia, Bolivia and other Latin American countries combat their drug cartels on land, sea and in the air.

The United States risks losing its international partners in the manned space station project if Congress cuts back on the $2.6 billion requested for the project in 1991, NASA Administrator Richard H. Truly says. ``I think a major reduction would cause them to look very seriously at our commitment to the project,'' Truly told the Senate science, technology and space subcommittee Friday. The space station Freedom is part of the Bush administration's $15.1 billion request for space programs in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. The project, with European, Japanese and Canadian partners, has been called the largest international research and development enterprise ever undertaken. Relations with the project partners were strained by the United States' decision last year to delay completion of construction for one year without consulting them.

DOC.HEAD: A New Dimension to Pigging Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation
DOC.TEXT: Pigs may not need encouragement to belly up to the feed trough, but scientists are looking for ways to make swine more efficient eaters. Researchers are trying to determine if bacteria found in the digestive tracts of American buffalo can be implanted in pigs and help farmers save money fattening their hogs for market. ``We know what it does in the test tube. We don't know yet what happens in the animal,'' says Vincent Varel, a research microbiologist for the government's Agricultural Research Service. A lot could be riding on the outcome of the tests at the Department of Agriculture's U.S. Meat Animal Research Center at Clay Center, Neb. Feed represents about half a farmer's production costs. An efficient, low-cost method to improve the digestive process and increase the weight gain from each pound of feed would lower farm costs and increase the chance of operating profitably. The studies are of special interest in Iowa, which accounts for one out of every four hogs raised for market in the United States. The livestock feed industry also is interested, and Varel says four feed companies already have contacted him to find out how the studies are progressing. Varel says the research is preliminary and that even if successful, it would be at least five years before farmers could apply the results to their hogs. The studies are focusing on a bacterium known as clostridium longisporum, found in bison. When fed or implanted in pigs, the bacterium stimulates production of a new, yet-to-be-named microorganism, which previously has not been found in pigs. ``The new organism better degrades fiber in pigs fed corn and soybeans. Metabolic studies will be done to determine how much energy the pig derives from this organism. If the fiber-degrading activity in pigs is increased, producers may be able to switch to less expensive feeds, such as feed grains from ethanol production,'' the Agricultural Research Service says in a synopsis of its studies. Varel says researchers suspected such an organism existed in bison because those beasts do a better job digesting a poor quality diet than domestic cows do. In the test tube, researchers found the organism degrades cellulose fiber 15 percent better than other organisms and decided, ``let's try it in the pig and see what happens there,'' Varel said in a telephone interview. So far, no side effects have been found and none are suspected, he says. The initial round of tests has determined the microorganism can be established in pigs and a new test will see if it can be done consistently. The next step is to compare the metabolism of pigs that have the organism with pigs that do not. Metabolism is the process of breaking down food into energy and waste matter. To find out, researchers will analyze what goes into the pig's mouth and what comes out the other end. ``The object is to see if this organism is having an effect on growth,'' he says. ``Within the next year, we will have a good idea if we can consistently establish it and whether it has an effect on the animals or not.'' Eventually, scientists will want to determine if the organism helps pigs add lean tissue or fat. Varel also says researchers will want to know if the organism makes pigs eat less because they make better use of what they are fed. ``We just don't have all the answers yet,'' he says.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday PMs March 12

DOC.HEAD: Jane Pauley Anchors Her First post-`Today' Special
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT name of show to `NBC Nightly News'
DOC.TEXT: NBC's Jane Pauley, safely away from the woes and slipping ratings of the ``Today'' show she once co-hosted, starts life anew in prime time Tuesday with an appropriately entitled special: ``Changes.'' Her own changes include anchoring a prime-time news series that NBC once said might start this summer. However, it has no executive producer yet and may not arrive until fall or even January, she says. But she doesn't consider this the NBC News version of ``Waiting for Godot.'' ``I think it's very sensible,'' Pauley says of the delay. In her view, ``Corporations don't normally behave sensibly if there is some pressure to put something on the air. But this strikes me as a very rational way to approach a weekly series, and I'm very pleased with that.'' On Saturday, Pauley, who also has been filling in for Tom Brokaw on the ``NBC Nightly News,'' leaves for East Germany to start another documentary on sports there. A few more documentaries lie ahead after that. Tuesday's special is about three people and one couple whose lives are in transition. Work on the first story, about Frank Morgan, a 56-year-old acclaimed jazz saxophonist who spent much of his life in prison, began in December. That was the month that Pauley, her contract extended to 1992, bid adieu to 13 years of predawn wakeups for ``Today.'' She had told its audience in October she was leaving and got a hug then from her successor, Deborah Norville. But since January, ``Today'' hasn't exactly been hugged by viewers, even though Pauley took pains in October to assure them she wasn't at odds with Norville or co-host Bryant Gumbel, whom she called her friends. Although NBC executives say they have no research to indicate it, ``Today'' likely was hurt and ABC's ``Good Morning America'' helped by the turmoil preceding Pauley's decision to leave. Those off-camera troubles last year included the leak of Gumbel's caustic memo criticizing staffers, notably weatherman Willard Scott, and the decision of NBC executives, including ``Today'' vice president Dick Ebersol, to replace veteran ``Today'' news anchor John Palmer with Norville. Although NBC officials have said they expected a dip in ``Today'' ratings when Norville moved up from news anchor to succeed Pauley in January, the dip now is in its third month. ABC's ``Good Morning America'' easily won the important February ratings ``sweeps,'' the results used by TV stations to set their advertising rates. It averaged a 4.5 rating, which was good news for ABC affiliates. No so for NBC affiliates. ``Today,'' according to NBC's estimate, had a 3.65 average in the sweeps _ well below the 4.6 it had in February 1989 when it won the reveille ratings race. Each ratings point now represents 921,000 homes. Pauley, who last year kept a stiff upper lip and never publicly complained about the behind-camera woes at ``Today,'' is sympathetic to its current ratings problems. ``Well, I've been there before,'' she says, harking back to a time when she co-hosted ``Today'' with Brokaw and the Nielsen verdict was that ``Good Morning America,'' then hosted by David Hartman, had become No. 1. ``It was almost a relief when it finally happened,'' she says. ``Because from that moment on, we were able to scramble and get our act together and come back.'' She thinks the same thing will happen again, and that those in charge of ``Today,'' including new executive producer Tom Capra, will ``be able to put together something that comes on pretty strong.'' Pauley laughed uproariously when asked about an upcoming report in the National Enquirer confiding that NBC, on bended knee, had begged her to return to ``Today'' and that she has agreed to interview guests on two of five shows each week, starting in April. ``Totally bogus,'' she said. Her own thoughts about the ``Today'' turmoil and its effect on the show's ratings? ``Obviously, I can't personalize it,'' she said. ``And yet, I think that an explanation is that there were `dislocations,' shall we say, on the `Today' show. ... And I think that bothers people, especially early in the morning. ``It's not just that `Jane is gone.' It's just that there was too much disruption. In the morning, you want, er, regularity.''

Elsewhere in television ... ABC-NBC SUMMIT REPORT, PART TWO: Former ``Today'' co-host Barbara Walters will be taping a chat with Bryant Gumbel for Friday's ``20-20'' on ABC. But officials of that show decline to tell inquiring reporters _ who no doubt suspect amazing revelations may be afoot _ when or where the taping is to be held. Anchorfolk interviewing each other has become commonplace. Last month, NBC aired an interview of its late-night inquirer, Bob Costas, with ABC's late-night interviewer, Ted Koppel of ``Nightline.'' Then, last week, Dick Cavett of NBC's cable service, CBNC, interviewed Costas for ``The Dick Cavett Show.'' Costas, among other things, criticized former ABC sportcaster Howard Cosell.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday PMs, March 12

DOC.HEAD: India, Pakistan on Alert for War Neither Wants
DOC.TEXT: Both say they do not want war in Kashmir, but India and Pakistan are preparing their armies to turn the lush, rugged region into a battleground for the third time since 1947. An estimated 240,000 Indian soldiers, supported by armor and aircraft, are in Kashmir. A provocation or misunderstanding arising from the Moslem insurgency in India's part of the region could send them into action. India and Pakistan have fought over the mountains and valleys of Kashmir since Britain carved the subcontinent into two nations, along Hindu and Moslem religious lines, and granted them independence 43 years ago. On the Indian side of the 41-year-old truce line, nearly 200 people have been killed since late January in battles between Kashmiri Moslem secessionists and Indian troops. ``Militarily speaking, it is a near-war scenario; both sides are ready,'' a retired Indian infantry officer in Srinagar said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The irony of the situation is that both sides ... claim day after day that they do not want war.'' In Baramulla, a major Indian army base and the last town before the cease-fire line, convoys of army trucks and artillery roll toward the frontier 25 miles away. Soldiers in battle fatigues practice battle tactics, firing live rounds at mock targets. ``The military activity you see here is more or less normal,'' Chewang Phunsog, chief civilian administrator of the strategic border districts Baramulla and Kupwara, said in an interview. ``I do not know if a war is on the cards, but if we are drawn into it, the other side will not find us lacking,'' he said. In Islamabad, a spokesman for Pakistan's Defense Ministry said a buildup of Indian paramilitary forces had occurred along the frontier. ``We think it is primarily for internal security, but it can always be used once it's there,'' said the spokesman, whose name cannot be used under briefing rules. Indian military sources said the number of troops deployed in Jammu-Kashmir, the only Indian state with a Moslem majority, had grown from 150,000 a few months ago to about 240,000. At least three border incidents have occurred since an Indian crackdown on Kashmiri separatists began Jan. 20. The most serious was Feb. 5, when about 4,000 Pakistani civilians tried to cross the border to help their Moslem brethren. Troopers opened fire, killing as many as 10, according to Indian newspapers. ``Here was a classic case of provocation,'' said an Indian officer in Srinagar, summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, who also would not let his name be used. ``We could have killed a thousand of them, but we did not, because that could have escalated into a major confrontation,'' he said. ``Today, political consideration comes first, but if we are pushed and pushed, we may not have any option but to go flat out.'' India and Pakistan fought their first war in 1948. It officially ended with the declaration of a U.N.-sponsored truce in January 1949, and Kashmir has been divided since. In 1965, they fought a second war over Kashmir. It lasted 16 days and ended with no real gains for either side. Their third war, in 1971, did not concern the disputed region. India entered the civil war between East Pakistan and West Pakistan and helped transform East Pakistan into independent Bangladesh. On paper, India has a great military advantage. It has 1.36 million men in the armed forces and 240,000 in reserve, compared with 500,000 men under arms in Pakistan. India has 3,150 battle tanks to Pakistan's 1,600 and 714 warplanes to Pakistan's 338. The Indian aircraft include advanced Soviet MiG-29s and Pakistan has U.S. F-16s. The 35-member U.N. military observer group continues the task it began four decades ago. ``Our job is to report any abnormal increase in military activities on the border to our headquarters in New York,'' said Capt. Idesbald van Biesebroeck of Belgium. The radio at the observer office in Srinagar crackles all day. So far, the words heard most often are ``normal'' and ``peaceful.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs AMs, March 15

DOC.HEAD: St Patrick's a Protestant, and a Catholic Too
DOC.TEXT: St. Patrick is a Protestant, and a Catholic too, in the town where tradition says he is buried. ``Things that would separate us nowadays would not separate us from St. Patrick,'' said the Rev. T.J. Simpson, a Presbyterian who will be preaching in the church near the grave on St. Patrick's Day. ``Our common ground is St. Patrick's ground,'' said Simpson, general secretary of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland. Very little can be proved about Patrick's life and work, but tradition associates him strongly with the counties of Northern Ireland, where a cycle of sectarian violence began more than 20 years ago. Roman Catholics, Anglicans, Methodists and Presbyterians will pray together on St. Patrick's Day in this placid town 20 miles southeast of Belfast, close to the places where Patrick is believed to have begun his mission and won his first converts. ``This is what people find hard to understand,'' said the Rev. Brian Mayne, whose Anglican cathedral is host for the service. A big slab of granite marking Patrick's grave is south of the church tower. ``We take it for granted that people of all persuasions would be involved,'' Mayne said. ``It's a recognition that Downpatrick is Patrick.'' Their common ground is not the legendary figure who drove the snakes from Ireland and had more powerful magic than the Druids, but the 5th century missionary as he describes himself in his ``Confession.'' ``The modern Protestant evangelical would be surprised at how modern Patrick is,'' said Brian Turner, curator of the Down Museum a few hundred yards from the grave site. ``He is very biblically based. He is always quoting the Bible as justification for what he does.'' Turner, a Methodist, finds the Protestant in Patrick's description of his inner turmoil while he was a captive in Ireland and forced to herd flocks. ``The Lord there made me aware of my unbelief that I might at last advert to my sins and turn wholeheartedly to the Lord my God,'' Patrick writes in his ``Confession,'' one of the few pieces of writing to survive from that time in Ireland. ``He showed concern for my weakness, and pity for my youth and ignorance; he watched over me before I got to know him and before I was able to distinguish good from evil.'' In other words, Turner says, Patrick claimed he was saved by grace, a fundamental principle of the Reformation. Canon Joseph P. Maguire at the Roman Catholic cathedral also is attracted to this Patrick. ``St. Patrick was a humble man of great faith,'' Maguire said, pointing to the saint's declaration that, while a captive, he prayed a hundred times by day and as many by night. ``I would hope that the image of St. Patrick for this present day is as a healer and reconciler, and as a person of prayer,'' he said, but added: ``We have a sneaking regard _ a regard for the man of the snakes and shamrocks.'' A few years ago, Maguire became the first Roman Catholic to preach in the Anglican cathedral since the Reformation. Despite all the clerical talk of ecumenism, the visitor may get a strong feeling of division. Two miles away in Saul, the traditional site of Patrick's landing in 432, there are an Anglican church at an old monastic site and a large statue of St. Patrick atop a nearby hill appropriated by the Catholics. Both were erected in 1932 for the 1,500th anniversary of Patrick's arrival. ``People come to Downpatrick and they say, `When did St. Patrick become a Protestant?''' Maguire said, and related an old joke that ``St. Patrick became a Protestant in 1932.'' Mayne winced at hearing that gibe repeated, and insisted, ``The Church of Ireland has always celebrated St. Patrick.'' Simpson grew up in Ballymena, near Mount Slemish, where St. Patrick is said to have been a herdsman. ``I, as a child, was very close to all that,'' he said. Turner thinks Downpatrick is untypical in its regard for Patrick. In Armagh, the seat supposedly chosen by Patrick, there are no plans for ecumenical services on the 17th. There will be the usual parade in Dublin, which is cheerfully conceded to be a copy of the one in New York, and shamrocks will be distributed at many Catholic church services. The state primary school in Downpatrick usually closes on St. Patrick's Day, Turner said, although it is not an official holiday and the great majority of the school's pupils are Protestants.

DOC.HEAD: GOP's New `Big Tent' Welcomes Pro-Choice Women
DOC.TEXT: The pro-choice training film at a recent candidate workshop was most notable for its audience and its star. The candidates were Republicans getting a pro-choice message from one of their own, GOP Rep. Connie Morella of Maryland. She's still at odds with her president and her party's platform on abortion. But in the new GOP, a GOP that says it is scrapping litmus tests in favor of a ``big tent'' that takes in many views, Morella no longer is a dissident. She's a role model for like-minded Republicans. ``We're proof that there can be differences of opinion,'' Morella says. The GOP never was as single-minded as its platform suggests. Plenty of its members have long supported abortion rights, for example. But that diversity has been widely acknowledged only since last November, when anti-abortion Republicans lost the New Jersey and Virginia gubernatorial elections in races where abortion was a key issue. It was less than two years ago that GOP leaders turned off Rep. Nancy Johnson's microphone when she moved to delete some anti-abortion language from the Republican platform at a party meeting in New Orleans. Johnson, R-Conn., doesn't think that would happen now. ``We have moved from a climate in which the party was trying to avoid the issue to a climate in which not only is discussion seen as inevitable, but people are beginning to re-evaluate their positions,'' she said. Some Republican women in Congress attribute the party's new openness to reawakened consciences, but others are less charitable. ``There is a greater desire, clearly motivated by political expediency, to make the issue less black and white,'' says Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I., who is running for the Senate. Either way, the women say, the end results are the same: a greater sensitivity to women's concerns and a possible windfall of support for bills that are important to women voters. ``They don't want to get hung with being anti-woman or anti-progress,'' says Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., another candidate for the Senate. ``People are looking for areas that all sides can come together on. Legislators always like finding the middle.'' Some gestures are cosmetic, such as a recent stampede to honor women in sports. But there also could be new support for more substantive options, including bills to provide better child care benefits, job-protected family leave, easier adoptions and better nutrition and health care programs for pregnant women and children. Several anti-abortion lawmakers from both parties have said they'll back a new contraceptive research bill, a shift that is encouraging to House co-sponsors Olympia Snowe, R-Maine, and Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., sees a willingness among some legislators to look at family planning in a new light. ``They are saying, wait a minute, this is not an abortion issue. This is a preventive issue. It's about health, counseling and a support system,'' she said. Some GOP women say the true test of any attitude shift will be whether the mostly male Congress shows any urgency to pass bills that would expand the federal child care role and require most employers to offer unpaid leave to new parents. Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., sees improved prospects for the family leave bill in light of developments in her home state, where such a measure was approved by the legislature in a special session. The bill had been considered dead until anti-abortion Republican Jim Courter lost the gubernatorial election by a wide margin. ``There's no doubt about the political dynamics,'' Roukema said of the turnaround in New Jersey. ``A lot of people who were afraid they were on the wrong side of the choice question ... reassessed their positions and voted for the bill.'' Roukema said she's signed up more supporters for the national family-leave bill as a result of what happened in New Jersey, ``and a lot of people have told me they are keeping their options open.'' Some pro-choice GOP activists would like their allies in Congress to press for relaxed rules on abortion itself. Among other things, they want to restore federal funds for all Medicaid abortions and enact a ``freedom of choice'' act that would take the future of abortion rights out of the Supreme Court's hands. But many GOP women say such crusades are bound to fail. ``Those are the kinds of changes that legislators are leery of,'' Martin said. ``They are looking for a different package that could let people work together.'' But if most Republicans are not prepared to do an about-face on abortion, many may be ready to approach the issue in a less confrontational way, pro-choice women say. They hope that will improve chances for restoring federal Medicaid abortion funds for victims of rape and incest. President Bush condones abortion under those circumstances and might be persuaded to release federal Medicaid dollars if there were strict regulations, according to Snowe and others who have met with him on the subject. ``Hopefully we can soften the party's position and bring some political benefits,'' Snowe said. ``The Republican Party is going to be looking for ways to modify the whole issue.''

DOC.HEAD: Life After Drexel For Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: The junk bond kingpin is dead _ long live the junk bond market. That's the theme that has emerged in many Wall Street post mortems of Drexel Burnham Lambert, now that a month has passed since the dominant firm in underwriting and trading of lower-quality bonds collapsed into bankruptcy proceedings. On first reaction, Drexel's demise came as a severe blow to the junk market, by abruptly removing from the scene the chief advocate of high-yield finance. Participants in the market lost their primary sponsor, facilitator and cheerleader. Even greater, perhaps, was the symbolic impact on the faith and trust of junk bond investors. Nevertheless, some observers say, the junk bond market seems very likely to endure once the current storms have passed. Indeed, they add, the latest developments may actually prove a boon to fanciers of ``junk'' in its original sense _ the depressed bonds of companies in trouble. ``It's likely that what we've known as the junk market in recent years, with its emphasis on takeover bonds, is gone,'' say analysts at IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis. ``But high-yield securities are a legitimate investment, and the high-yield market will emerge from the current situation in some form. ``In fact, the shakeout now occurring should remove some of the excesses that have gone on in recent years and result in a market that is more fundamentally sound.'' Perhaps the greatest irony in the current picture, observers say, is that trouble in the new sectors of the junk bond game may well expand activity in the earliest form of junk securities. Before Drexel came along, the junk bond market was largely made up of once-respectable issues that had fallen on hard times. Though some of these offered high (and risky) yields, others held out the promise of no current return at all, since their issuers were in default and making no interest or dividend payments. Investors bought no-yield junk bonds just as they would depressed common stocks, speculating on the chances for a turnaround in the issuer's fortunes. In part because of Drexel's failure, ``we expect to see a steady flow of new distressed securities in the coming months,'' says George Putnam III in the current edition of the Boston-based advisory service The Turnaround Letter. ``There will probably be several highly leveraged companies that might have been able to squeak by with Drexel's help but now will not make it.'' This kind of fire-sale merchandise has always appealed to a hardy breed of speculators. Historically, all you needed in this game was one or two big scores to offset the losses from other investments that never come back. But analysts caution that junk bonds of that kind have always been, and will continue to be, a long-shot proposition suitable only for people who can afford to absorb losses and be patient. Concludes IDS: ``1990 is a watershed year for the high-yield market. A number of the sources of the market's problems will resolve themselves this year. If investors begin to feel that deals are being made for sound reasons and in a prudent manner, they will return.''

DOC.HEAD: Recession Worries Easing
DOC.TEXT: Recession fears have been fading on Wall Street lately, helping the stock market to rally. But not all investors are happy to see those worries go. As spring approaches in the financial world, the U.S. economy apparently is gathering momentum again, resuming the expansion that has been running for nearly 7{ years. Analysts still have some major reservations about the state of business activity. Interest rates are higher than many people might wish, and corporate profits remain in a slump. Nevertheless, the view seems to be spreading that those misgivings will be alleviated as the year progresses by an increasingly healthy combination of growth and slackening inflation. That would presumably allow stock prices to climb substantially even before any marked improvement in corporate finances worked its way through to the bottom line. ``At this stage the United States is the only developed country with a declining inflation rate,'' said John Connolly, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``While the U.S. economy is troughing, others are peaking. ``Right now our fundamentals are excellent _ perhaps the best that can be found in the world.'' For others who look at the same picture from a less optimistic viewpoint, the prospect of a pickup in business conjures up memories of difficult periods for investors in recent years. Conceivably, they say, it could usher in a new bout of concerns before long about possible credit-tightening by the Federal Reserve, which has been waging a long-term campaign against inflation whenever the economy was strong enough to permit it. ``I expect to see more takers for the idea that the U.S. economy is indeed growing _ not growing rapidly enough to generate strong profits, but growing too rapidly to effect any improvement in inflation or interest rates,'' said Greg Smith at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``I suspect the triumph of this view will create another decline in the market, and may perhaps create a buying opportunity sometime in the second quarter. I anticipate a relatively difficult period marked by a paucity of brave and exciting new ideas.'' Undaunted by such warnings, buyers took stock prices to their highest levels since early January in the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 22.97 to 2,683.33, on top of a 96.17-point gain the week before. The New York Stock Exchange index of all listed common stocks rose 1.21 to 186.18; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 5.74 to 436.76, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 5.03 at 361.15. Volume on the Big Board averaged 157.73 million shares a day, against 161.60 million in the previous week. If corporate profits were the gauge rather than overall economic output, the U.S. economy already would have lapsed into a certified recession. By most measures profits declined in the third and fourth quarters of last year, and they are expected to show another decline in the three-month period through the end of March. ``Most investors are resigned to weak earnings in the first half of 1990,'' observed Thomas Doerflinger at PaineWebber Inc. ``The next surprise is likely to be that earnings fail to improve much in the second half of 1990.'' A primary reason for this, Doerflinger argues, is the recent rise of interest rates, which stands to act as a drag on growth and to increase companies' interest costs at the expense of profits. ``Of course,'' he adds, ``rising U.S. rates partly reflect higher rates overseas. ``A significant risk for U.S. corporate profits is that these rate increases will suppress economic growth overseas. This would eliminate one of the few remaining bright spots for the earnings of U.S. companies.''

DOC.HEAD: USX Throws a Small Bone to Icahn, Symbolizing Lost Might of the Raiders
DOC.TEXT: Corporate raiders once used junk bonds like kryptonite to intimidate companies with takeover forays. But the sagging market for junk has given potential targets a lead shield to protect themselves, and the raiders are resorting to other, less powerful weapons. The latest example came this past week when USX Corp., harried by Carl Icahn, consented to his proposal for a non-binding shareholder vote on whether the company should vacate the steel business. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, once could have taken much more drastic action, ultimately a hostile takeover, backed by billions of dollars in borrowed money provided by eager banks and the sale of junk debt securities. ``This shows that raiders, without the junk market and with banks much more conservative, are now toothless and don't have the financing to back takeover threats,'' said Charles LaLoggia, author of a Special Situation Report, a Rochester, N.Y.-based investment newsletter that focuses on takeover stocks. ``It shows management is just able to say, `Go away. No. Leave.''' For USX, consenting to the May 7 shareholder vote was a shrewd move, takeover experts said, largely because the steel-and-energy giant relinquished practically nothing while giving the appearance of responsiveness. Icahn is considered to have a slight chance of winning majority support for his proposal, which would recommend that the nation's biggest steel company sell the steel operations because they aren't profitable enough. But even if he won, the company's board isn't required to oblige. Moreover, allowing the vote enables the board to deflect complaints that it isn't acting in the shareholders' best interests. ``It's like the line in `The Godfather:' `Keep your friends close, keep your enemies closer,''' LaLoggia said. ``It appears to accommodate Icahn and it avoids shareholder lawsuits.'' Others said the Icahn-USX arrangement reflects how takeover strategists are increasingly relying on shareholder votes to gain control of target companies because they can no longer rely on bank credit and the junk-bond market, which has slumped badly because of a dearth of buyers and a glut of sellers. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the biggest junk underwriter, collapsed a month ago. More than half a dozen large American corporations already are facing proxy fights, which are efforts by minority shareholders to put an issue to a vote at annual meetings. The objective is usually to sack the directors and replace them with allies who will take control or force the company's sale. The most prominent of these fights is an effort by Dallas investor Harold Simmons, who owns about 19 percent Lockheed Corp., to replace directors up for election with a slate of his own and nullify the aerospace giant's ``poison pill'' antitakeover defense. Other examples include UAL Corp., facing a proxy challenge by Coniston Partners, a New York-based takeover investment group, and Armstrong World Industries Inc., challenged by the Belzbergs, a wealthy Canadian family. The end of easily available money for takeovers isn't the only obstacle confronting the Icahns, Simmonses and Belzbergs who were once much more aggressive in their tactics. Corporate management has been strengthened by recent court decisions and a number of state antitakeover laws. Many takeover strategists are particularly alarmed about a proposed strengthening of a Pennsylvania law that could serve as a model for other states, which would require hostile buyers to surrender their profits from the sale of an acquired company. ``This bill is anti-capitalist and would set a dangerous precedent with far-reaching consequences,'' the dean of the takeover strategists, T. Boone Pickens, wrote recently in the newsletter of his Washington lobby group, the United Shareholders Association. ``With management untouchable by shareholders, no matter how poorly it performs, there will be little incentive for anyone to own stock.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _New weaknesses surfaced in American manufacturing. Domestic automakers said U.S. car and truck sales fell nearly 8 percent in February, the lowest showing in seven years, while Japanese automakers strengthened their share of the market. The government said U.S. factory orders fell 5.4 percent in January, the biggest drop in 15 years. _Stocks and bonds slumped at the end of the week, hurt by renewed fear of higher inflation. The catalyst for the drop was the government report on February unemployment, which showed the economy produced the most jobs in nearly two years. _The best-known soft-drink makers in the United States and France attempted to inject fresh fizz into classic flops. Coca-Cola Co. announced the test marketing of Coke II, five years after the introduction of a marketing debacle, New Coke. Perrier, which recalled its soda water worldwide because of benzene contamination, announced an ambitious campaign to relaunch it with an ambitious sales and advertising campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's New Transportation Plan Could Spur Muni Bond Industry
DOC.TEXT: The municipal bond market could be in for a major boost in the coming decade thanks to President Bush's new national transportation policy. The policy, released this past week, calls for shifting much of the cost of the nation's transportation system to state and local governments. It also envisions users of the system paying for upkeep as much as possible, and private investors taking a larger role in the funding. The result, experts say, should be greater sales of tax-exempt bonds by state and local governments, the historical way that highways, airports, ports and transit systems are paid for. ``It will cause a major increase in bond issuance over the next decade,'' predicted Peter J. Schmitt, chief operating officer of Financial Guaranty Insurance Co., which insures municipal bonds Other experts are more cautious. ``It is the beginning of a process. It may take a couple of years before you begin to see specific results from it,'' said Austin Koenen, chairman of the Public Securities Association, a trade group for companies that underwrite municipal bonds. For years, many groups, including the PSA, have been saying the nation's infrastructure _ roads, rails, airports and waterways _ needs a major upgrading. Koenen said Bush's plan is a recognition of this concern. The Bush policy outlines new ways for state and local governments to raise funds for transportation, such as airport passenger taxes and tolls on roads built with federal funds _ both of which are now prohibited. Koenen said this means the policy should favor the use of municipal revenue bonds, rather than general obligation bonds. General obligation bonds are backed by the general taxing authority of a government, while revenue bonds are tied to a specific revenue source linked to the project to be funded, such as tolls charged for use of a highway built with bonds. Another reason revenue bonds should be more popular than general obligation bonds is that raising taxes is a political pitfall for most state and local governments. Legislatures and voters are much more willing to approve bond issues if they are paid off by a fee tied to the project funded, instead of by a general tax on all residents. While the Bush plan is encouraging, the PSA said it will continue to press for easing of tax-code rules that it contends hinder the issuance of municipal bonds. Schmitt said the plan appears to favor increased use of public-private partnerships in funding transportation. But those partnerships were reined in by the 1986 code revision. ``You can't have it both ways,'' he said. The 1986 tax revision reduced the percentage of revenue from a municipal bond issue that may benefit private interests from 25 percent to 10 percent. The revision also put caps on each state on the amount of tax-exempt bond funding they may issue for private uses. The change was made in response to what was perceived to be abuse of the tax-exempt fund-raising ability of local governments for the benefit of private companies. But Bob Brown, a vice president at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the restriction should be eased for transportation projects, since transportation traditionally is a function of government. While the Bush policy statement appears to promote municipal bonds, Brown said it is more important as a recognition of the needs of the nation's transportation system. ``The real thing that drives the municipal market is not so much federal policy as the need for infrastructure,'' he said. ``What will have a much greater effect over the next five years is how people begin to look at infrastructure needs. Do they see that as a top priority to address at all levels of government?''

DOC.HEAD: National Lampoon Pitches New Image at Spring Break
DOC.TEXT: When things seemed darkest for the fraternity brothers in National Lampoon's movie ``Animal House,'' they staged a wild Roman toga party. Life sometimes imitates art. With circulation down and publication schedules scaled back at the 20-year-old humor and satire magazine, National Lampoon executives decided it was time to let loose. This month, National Lampoon is spending $500,000 to promote a revamped look to the college spring break crowd in Daytona Beach. The campaign will include billboards, sports contests, bikini competitions and, of course, a toga bash. ``We're going to the college students and saying, `Take a look at our magazine. We think you'll like it,''' said Michael Carr, a former advertising director at Playboy hired last year as publisher of New York-based National Lampoon. The April issue already shows the new direction of the magazine, which built its reputation in the 1970s on locker room-level guffaws and a sardonic eye. For the first time in many years, there is no nudity in the magazine. But it still contains many male-oriented sex jokes, a National Lampoon staple. Plans include improved graphics, more short fiction, articles on comedians and humor and an emphasis on listings and tips. ``We want to make it a guidebook to your funny bone,'' said Carr. Carr said none of the spring break promotions will feature alcohol, which showers most other activities for the estimated 400,000 college students expected in Daytona Beach this year. ``The days of the Fort Lauderdale-party-till-you-puke mentality is gone,'' said Carr. ``We want the kids to go home with good memories of spring break.'' ``Spring break is a marketing paradise,'' said James Spanfeller, associate publisher of Playboy magazine, which was launching its own three-week Daytona Beach promotions. The 1980s was a boom-time for comedy clubs and films, but the yuppie era was tough for National Lampoon, an outgrowth of The Harvard Lampoon in Cambridge, Mass. Circulation, which peaked at nearly 850,000 in 1974, fell to 230,000 before a slight rebound last year. In 1986, the magazine started publishing every two months, but Carr said monthly publication will resume with the 20th anniversary issue in October. Media analysts say part of the magazine's decline stemmed from its failure to keep pace with the growing sophistication and changing tastes of its readership _ defined by Carr as 80 percent male, about 28 years old, college-educated and earning $36,000 a year. ``A magazine must continually invigorate to bring in a new audience,'' said Hollywood, Calif-based producer Daniel Grodnik, who purchased National Lampoon Inc. last year. His partner in the venture is actor Tim Matheson, who played the character Otter in ``Animal House.'' On Friday, Grodnik and Matheson announced they had agreed to sell the company to J2, a home-video producer and distributor, in an exchange of stock valued at $4.67 million. Both will continue to run the company as a division of J2, which will provide additional capital for the magazine. The two investors hired Carr, several new writers and Billy Kimball, who edited The Harvard Lampoon's 1981 parody of People magazine. Carr says advertisers already have begun to respond to the shake-up. In its February issue, the 112-page National Lampoon had six pages of advertising. The 96-page April issue, which sells for $3.95, has 40 pages of ads, including big-budget companies such as Molson Beer, R.J. Reynolds and Playboy. In 1988, the most recent financial reports available, National Lampoon Inc. reported revenue of about $5 million, slightly down from 1987. But the report does not include the third of National Lampoon's ``vacation'' films, ``Christmas Vacation,'' which grossed more than $75 million at the box office following its late 1989 release. ``If the Lampoon will tone itself down and have that sophisticated look and content to match, advertisers will put their label on it,'' said Paul DuCharme, head of print advertising at Grey Advertising. But analysts note that other publications are competing for the chuckles of U.S. readers. Four-year-old Spy magazine, which often satirizes modern urban culture, announced last month it is seeking either a buyer or cash-rich investors for expansion. Time Warner Inc.'s 38-year-old Mad magazine focuses on a school-age crowd and reports a growing circulation of about 1.4 million worldwide. Problems, however, may loom for publications that cater to a mostly male readership, said David Orlow, chairman of Periodical Studies Service Inc. in New York. ``That usually means a lot of cigarette and alcohol ads,'' he said. ``The way things are going with public attitudes, it appears that type of advertising is on the decline.''

DOC.HEAD: Digital To Expand Voluntary Severance Program
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. said Friday it will cut thousands of employees from its payroll by expanding a voluntary severance program as it contends with a slumping U.S. computer market. Digital officials would not give specific figures on how many jobs would be eliminated, saying the plan was under preparation. But Brad Allen, manager of shareholder relations, said the number was ``in the ballpark'' of previous estimates by industry analysts. Analysts have said Digital, which employs about 125,900 people worldwide and more than 70,000 in the United States, wants to pare its payroll by at least 5,000 and eventually redeploy as many as 15,000 employees in new jobs. ``The momentum has picked up, the program definitely will be expanded,'' Allen said, adding the program was to be implemented by the end of the company's fiscal year on June 30. Digital spokeswoman Nikki Richardson said the severance program will be similar to a package offered last year to 700 employees at the company's manufacturing plant in Salem, N.H. Under that volunteer plan, which has been accepted by 260 workers so far, employees received a cash payment based on years of service, as well as medical, dental and life insurance coverage for one year. Workers with up to two years of service, for example, received 40 weeks of pay. Those with three to 10 years got 40 weeks, plus three weeks for each year between three and 10 years. ``We are looking at all transition programs on a business-by-business basis,'' Richardson said. Digital, the world's second-largest computer company after International Business Machines Corp., saw its earnings fall 39 percent for the six months ended Dec. 31. The company, based in suburban Maynard, blames the drop on a lackluster computer market in the United States, which has forced other companies to make cutbacks as well. Digital also has reassigned hundreds of employees from manufacturing to sales.

DOC.HEAD: Hunts Having Trouble Meeting Penrod Loan, May Lose Drilling Company
DOC.TEXT: A group of banks and investors may take control of Penrod Drilling Co. on March 31 because its owners, the Hunt brothers, are having problems raising cash for a loan payment, a newspaper reported Friday. The Dallas Morning News, quoting anonymous sources, said Penrod may not be able to meet the first of 32 payments on $525 million owed a group of six banks. Penrod was founded by the late billionaire H.L. Hunt and passed on through trusts to his children, William Herbert Hunt, Nelson Bunker Hunt and Lamar Hunt. If the Hunt brothers default on the payment, which includes $15 million in principal and about the same amount in interest, they would lose control of their 50 percent stake in Penrod. Leon Crozier, who leads Penrod's land-based drilling operations, said Friday the company had no comment on the report. The newspaper said control of the drilling company may eventually wind up with Fort Worth investor Richard E. Rainwater and his partners, including Energy Service Co. Rainwater's group has purchased 27 percent of Penrod's debt. The group this week bought Penrod debt held by Bank of America, according to a spokesman for the San Francisco-based bank. The Hunt family fortune has been entangled for almost a decade in a series of lawsuits, bankruptcies and battles with the Internal Revenue Service and various federal regulators. The half of Penrod owned by the Hunt brothers' personal trusts is pledged as collateral for the drilling equipment company's borrowing. In case of a default, the loan agreement calls for the brothers' stake to pass to whoever holds the notes. The newspaper also said the Hunts are negotiating with the banks to remove a claim on the future earnings of Placid Oil Co., the Hunts' oil exploration firm, in exchange for control of Penrod. As part of Penrod's 1988 restructuring, the banks were promised first claim to income from the oil company's projects. The banks gradually have been selling their 50 percent of Penrod's stock to contract drillers interested in acquiring Penrod's 40 offshore drilling rigs, considered to be among the most modern in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Shareholders' Environment Proposals On Proxy Statement
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. shareholders and environmentalists said Friday that their attempts to prod the giant oil company into a more environmentally sensitive direction could include a call at Exxon's annual meeting to oust its chairman. Six shareholder proposals on environmental issues have been cleared by the Securities and Exchange Commission for inclusion in Exxon's proxy statement and will be voted on at the company's April 25 annual meeting. The company opposes all six proposals, which among other things call for Exxon to ``take leadership in dealing with (the) damage'' caused by its Alaska oil spill. Another resolution for an environmental report card based on the Valdez Principles, which is a set of corporate guidelines calling for conservation, restoration of damaged environments, reduction of wastes and other moves to protect the environment. Shareholders were unable to get such measures in the proxy statement last year because the huge oil spill in Alaska, which created a lingering public outcry against Exxon, occurred after the deadline for submitting resolutions. Instead shareholders, including some representing pension funds with large holdings of Exxon stock, had to be content with questioning company leaders about the spill and demanding greater accountability. As occurred last year, some shareholders again are likely to ask at the annual meeting for the resignation of Lawrence G. Rawl, Exxon's chairman and chief executive officer, said Gray Davis, trustee for the California Public Employee Retirement System, the nation's largest public pension fund. ``I've never seen a less concerned and less tuned in CEO,'' said Davis, who also is comptroller for the state of California. ``Maybe it requires a new CEO to understand that America will not tolerate this.'' Davis said a shareholder request for Rawl to resign is ``obviously on the table and the outside directors should look seriously at making a management change.'' Davis said 8.24 million shares of Exxon stock owned by Calpers will be voted in favor of at least some of the environmental resolutions. New York City also will be tossing its 5.1 million Exxon shares into the environmental pool, said Tim Smith, executive director of InterFaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, which represents 250 religious groups nationwide, some of whom own Exxon stock. Together, the pension funds own less than 1 percent of Exxon's 1.3 billion outstanding shares. Smith, who helped draw up the Valdez Principles, said most of the 25 companies asked to approve the principles had agreed to submit a report describing their company's programs and progress toward achieving the objectives. Mobil Corp., Texaco Inc., Chevron Corp. and Amoco Corp. have agreed to supply a report in six months, preventing a shareholder resolution on the matter in their proxy statements, Smith said Several other big companies, including Exxon, Atlantic Richfield Co. and American Express Co., declined to provide the report card and will have resolutions put to a vote at upcoming meetings. ``There has been no response from Exxon. It surprises me because one of the things they said they are doing is this kind of report,'' said Smith. Brent Blackwelder, an Exxon shareholder and vice president of Friends of the Earth, a Washington D.C.-based environmental organization with 50,000 members, said his group endorses the resolutions and would support a change in Exxon management. Despite getting the resolutions included in Exxon's proxy, supporters concede it is unlikely they will be adopted because passage of shareholder proposals is rare. Nonetheless, environmentalists hope the proposals will increase pressure on Exxon to become more environmentally sensitive. ``At a minimum hopefully they will get the attention of the CEO and the board,'' Davis said.

DOC.HEAD: MCorp Sells Bank in Corpus Christi
DOC.TEXT: MCorp will sell its interest in MBank Corpus Christi to the bank's managers, company officials said Friday. It would be the second such transaction in less than two weeks. The deal, which is subject to regulatory and bankruptcy court approvals, would leave MCorp, once the state's second-largest bank holding company, with three subsidiaries to sell. A group of investors led by Jerry Gates, chairman and chief executive officer of MBank Corpus Christi, will become the bank's owner under an agreement with MCorp. The sale is expected to be complete by July 31. The bank had assets of $582 million and deposits of $502 million on Dec. 31, 1989. The bank's name will be changed to Corpus Christi National Bank, the name under which it was originally chartered 100 years ago. ``Over the past few months, as events unfolded which made it appear that local ownership of the bank was a possibility, we've received hundreds of comments from customers and community leaders expressing their support for the return of Corpus Christi National Bank,'' Gates said. Terms of the agreement call for MCorp to receive an undisclosed amount of assets, mostly loans and real estate, for the bank's stock. MBank Corpus Christi will simultaneously issue $20 million in new stock. MCorp, which has been in bankruptcy proceedings since March 1989, last week said it had reached an agreement to sell MBank El Paso to its managers. The Dallas-based firm is trying to sell its remaining banking subsidiaries in Brownsville, New Braunfels and Waco. ``We are looking to sell those assuming we can get what we view as adequate or proper value for the benefit of our shareholders,'' said MCorp spokesman Doug Hughes. The five banks remained with MCorp after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. stripped it of 20 banking subsidiaries following the bankruptcy filing. Those 20 banks were bought by Banc One Corp., an Ohio banking company, and now operate as Bank One-Texas. MCorp's federally assisted bailout was the third largest in history after those of Continental Illinois in 1984 and First Republic Corp. of Dallas in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Futures Gyrate In Hectic Week
DOC.TEXT: Coffee futures went from boiling hot on Monday, when prices went over $1 a pound, to ice cold on Friday, when they dropped 700 points. Technical factors and speculation about Brazilian coffee supplies helped trigger the late-week selloff. Everything looked sweet as the week began, with concern about tight availability of high-quality coffee boosting prices on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to eight-month highs. Coffee futures had fallen below 70 cents a pound last year as producers sold out their warehoused stocks, but the price moved higher as the supply-demand situation became more balanced. Monday was the fourth straight day of strength for the market, but the advances didn't have anything to do with any fresh news, traders said. There was civil strife in the Ivory Coast, a shortfall in Mexico's coffee supply, poor growing conditions in Colombia and a lack of availability from Ecuador. But traders essentially already known about those factors, analysts said. During the week, coffee prices started slipping. Then on Friday, futures tumbled on talk that Brazil was ready to put more of its crop on the world market. March's futures contract for coffee dipped to 95.18 cents a pound, falling 732 points in ``monster volume,'' said Bert Ruiz, a vice president of Balfour Maclaine Corp. The Brazilian coffee agency estimated Thursday that it had over 16 million bags on hand, Ruiz said. Although much of that coffee was not apparently of the finer, exportable grade, there apparently was enough to scare traders, many of whom were speculating coffee had been overbought earlier this week when the near-month contract topped $1.05 a pound, Ruiz said. Coffee settled 4.25 cents to 7.32 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at 95.18 cents. Here are some other weekly commodity price trends: Soybeans and corn prices advanced, but wheat futures fell on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat for delivery in March settled Friday at $3.83{ a bushel, falling from $3.88} a week earlier; March corn rose from $2.45} to $2.43\ a bushel; oats for March advance to $1.46 a bushel from $1.44\; and soybeans for March climbed from $5.68} to $5.87{ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, livestock and meat futures were higher. April cattle were 77.62 cents a pound, up from 76.25 cents; March feeder cattle advanced from 80.47 cents to 82.10 cents a pound; live hogs for April jumped from 50.67 cents to 51.92 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies in March went from 48.75 cents to 50.95 cents a pound. Precious metals declined on the Commodity Exchange in New York. March gold dropped from $403 to $399.80 a troy ounce; and March silver fell to $5.10 a troy ounce from $5.13. Energy products futures sank on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil for April dipped from $21.35 to $20.43 a barrel; April heating oil was down to 53.86 cents a gallon from 55.87 cents; and unleaded gasoline for April was 54.99 cents a gallon, down from 56.47 cents.

DOC.HEAD: English May Back User Fee On Futures Trades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is for Saturday PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Glenn English says he may reluctantly support a user fee on futures trades to fund tougher enforcement by the industry's federal regulator, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. In a speech Friday to the Futures Industry Association's annual convention, English also criticized the Securities and Exchange Commission's bid for jurisdiction over stock-index futures, calling it a bureaucratic ``power grab.'' English, D-Okla., sponsored a CFTC reauthorization bill passed last year by the House. The bill would increase the agency's budget by about 30 percent to $44 million over the next two years to pay for tougher policing of the nation's futures exchanges. The Bush administration has proposed an 11-cent user fee on every futures transaction to provide nearly all of the CFTC's revenue, a plan the industry strongly opposes. English, who chairs a House credit subcommittee with CFTC oversight authority, said he might support a smaller user fee to pay only for the proposed increase in the agency's budget. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has said it could back such a plan. English said he usually opposes user fees, which he also called taxes. But he said that ``given the realities of the budget we face today, if we can find no other way to meet the funding requirements that we have authorized in the House and Senate legislation, I would very reluctantly accept user fees in making up that difference.'' A version of English's bill has been approved by the Senate agriculture committee and a Senate vote is expected after Easter. User fees and jurisdictional issues are among the concerns being addressed by Congress in the debate over CFTC reauthorization in the wake of the 1987 stock-market crash and the federal investigation of trading fraud at the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Merc. On the question of regulatory jurisdiction over stock-index futures, English said the SEC is outmoded and lacks the expertise to effectively regulate futures markets. The SEC, which regulates the stock and bond markets, has been gaining congressional support in its long-running battle for control over index futures, which are regulated by the CFTC. Stock-index futures _ which are based on such indexes as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index _ enable investors to speculate on the stock market's general trend without actually having to buy hundreds of different issues. Strategies involving the simultaneous trading of stock-index futures and the stocks they represent _ known as index arbitrage _ has been blamed by some for causing excessive price volatility in the stock market. But English said the SEC has no business in the futures markets. ``The Securities and Exchange Commission ... has been living on its reputation and may in fact be archaic and old-fashioned in many of their methods,'' English said. He said the recent collapse of of the junk-bond giant Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. raised ``serious questions'' about whether the SEC ``can handle their own business, much less anyone else's.''
